PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Fadden moving forthwith:
That this House censures the Minister for Transport and Communications for:
(1) misleading the House by:
(a) his statements yesterday that the CAA had not compromised safety during the current pilots dispute;
(b) his statement that the Government has no part in licensing procedures for foreign pilots; and
(c) his statements that the testing of foreign pilots is being conducted in line with normal procedures; and
(2) failing in his Ministerial duties to ensure the continued maintenance of Australia's high civil aviation standards and calls for his immediate resignation.

This move by the Opposition is taken with the utmost seriousness. It is not a ploy on behalf of any sectional group within our community; indeed, it is a move on behalf of the entire community and especially the Australian travelling public. This pilots strike, which is now in its seventh week, has gone on and on. Right throughout the period we have been told that there has been absolutely no compromise of safety standards by the Government, by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), or by the domestic airlines in terms of the use of international foreign aircraft. Just yesterday in Question Time the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) said in reply to a question asked by the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford) that he was aware of allegations that had been made that the CAA had compromised safety during the dispute. He said:
I totally reject that charge. Both the Government and the CAA are concerned to ensure that, in rebuilding our domestic aviation system, Australia's high safety standards are fully maintained.

Later in that same reply he made reference to a situation that existed concerning an Air Maritime 737 going off course out of Sydney just one week ago. I would like to quote to the House from the document that was issued by Sydney air traffic control to Melbourne air traffic control, which was taking over that aircraft. The telex statement was from Sydney air traffic control to Melbourne. Advice was given as to the real situation of the Air Maritime 737 registered Foxtrot Uniform Alpha, which departed from Sydney Airport to Melbourne on a standard flight plan with an accepted clearance via Wollongong. This is a standard departure clearance passed by ground control. The flight plan should have taken him via Wollongong to Corryong but it turned right and proceeded to Shelleys, a point 73 miles south-west of Sydney on a completely different track from the airport. In the message from Sydney to Melbourne tower the controller, after setting out what had happened, said:

Thank heavens for radar. Sector controller tried to counsel pilot gently but has no doubt he was not understood. Would you please try to help these pilots understand the meaning of SFPDN plans and the difference between a Wol and a Sls dep. We of course will try to do the same.

That was a reference to the difference between a Wollongong and a Shelleys departure. In the Senate yesterday a matter was raised concerning the operational procedures of an America West aircraft at Adelaide on 22 September. That aircraft, another Boeing 737, registered November 166 Alpha Whiskey, at 1515 hours landed on runway 23 on 22 September and failed to obtain clearance to cross runway 12. It allegedly was taxiing at 60 kilometres per hour but, of course, no action was taken.

Worst of all has been the real concern of very senior officers within the Department of Civil Aviation as to what is going on. I will quote from two documents. The first was written by Captain G. Segan, the Acting Senior Examiner of Pilots, and is entitled `CAA Operational Standards'. In that document he says:
By now you will be aware of concerns by CAA officers-
he is writing to headquarters-
of the erosion of operational standards as a result of decisions made in the light of the extraordinary events of the last six weeks.
He lists a number of areas in which those safety standards have been compromised. In terms of granting of concessions this gentleman says in his report:

To my mind the granting of a concession is tantamount to providing permission to break the law, and such action should only be contemplated after proper consideration of all of the factors involved. In granting a concession, therefore, it would be important that the intent and reasons behind the original legislation be fully understood so that a proper evaluation of . . . an equivalent safety standard would be maintained. During the last few weeks I do not believe that this was done.

Our major error was to allow ourselves to be drawn into discussions with airline commercial management-a group who had no knowledge or interest in standards. Their approach was to attack our standards in an attempt to reduce training requirements and they were successful. Their only negotiating point was the threat of ministerial action and it is an indication of our lack of confidence that we did not call their bluff. As a result new standards were set by political blackmail and it is now highly unlikely that we can redeem this situation.
In terms of AICUS flying for foreign pilots, he states:

Our existing policy on the issue . . . to foreign licence holders was relatively well known . . . There should have been no concession against the ATPL requirement of 150 hours of AICUS flying any more than such concessions would have been applied to experienced RAAF VIP squadron pilots.
Talking about the French pilots, he says:
The fact that the French possessed a BAE 146 endorsement was irrelevant. The type endorsement on a licence attracts a requirement of 50 hours of AICUS flying.
This was not met. He also acknowledged that company procedures and practices detailed in operation manuals are well known to pilots. He also says:
. . . it could be argued that their difficulty with the English language would override any advantage that their type endorsement may have offered.
In other words, there were real problems in terms of those safety standards. In terms of flight rules and procedure examination he goes on to say:

Small wonder, therefore, that within a week of the commencement of their operation we have reports of ATC confusion due to non standard radio calls, and an RPT aircraft turning right in left hand traffic patterns. This Authority has a requirement to check all pilots whose first language was not English prior to the issue of a licence. It must be assumed that such a test would be somewhat subjective; clearly, a private pilot on holiday should not require the same command of the language as one on scheduled operations.

But of course, we know that in terms of the issuing of these particular licences this did not happen. There are reams and reams of examples of where these cases have been brought to our attention and where there has been nothing but breaching of our present standards and political interference in the certifying of licences for foreign pilots. Therefore, I submit that this matter is urgent. The censure motion should be debated now without delay. In terms of safety for Australia and of the misinformation that has been continually given to us by this Government, the matter must be brought to light. This censure motion should be debated immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. A motion to censure a Minister is not embarked upon lightly. The Opposition would only embark upon that course in two cases. There may be other rare and exceptional cases but what motivates us as an opposition are these two situations: Firstly, where a Minister is shown to have misled the Parliament and, secondly, where a Minister has failed in his duty. On the basis of the evidence that has come to our notice we have no hesitation in saying that this Minister, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), is guilty on both charges. There is no doubt whatsoever on the material that we have that this Minister has misled this Parliament. There is no doubt on the material that we have that this Minister has failed in his ministerial duties. I am not going to go into the substance of the allegations at this stage. What we say is that it is a matter of urgency; therefore, it justifies the setting aside of Standing Orders. The safety of the travelling public is at stake. The safety of the public travelling by civil aviation in this country is unfortunately, as a result of the failure of the responsibility of this particular Minister, at risk. That is a matter of very great urgency. It is a matter that certainly justifies the setting aside of Standing Orders so that the House can debate this particular motion.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, this is a matter of great seriousness. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) has already illustrated the situation. We want the Standing Orders set aside so that we can look in more detail at the two documents that the honourable member has referred to. Despite the fact that the honourable member has referred to some details, let us look at the summary of the documents that the honourable member for Fadden has referred to so that we can see the seriousness of the situation. The senior officer in the Civil Aviation Authority, concerned about operational safety standards and having worked through this trauma for the last few weeks, says that the events of recent weeks show three things. They show that concessions have been granted for purely political reasons. On this side of the House, we do not believe that concessions touching safety, touching the operational standard of civil aviation, should be made on political grounds. He says further that those concessions, granted purely for political reasons, have been made:
. . . against long-standing requirements without due consideration of equivalent safety factors.

If there were ever a smoking gun condemning a Minister and a government, this must be it. When a senior officer in a department or an authority concerned about safety says that not only has safety been abandoned but it has been abandoned for political reasons, then we say that the House has no choice but to set aside Standing Orders so that we can debate this matter in detail. This gentleman goes on to say that there has been a major communication breakdown between pilots flying aircraft which are carrying passengers and pilots who are still working in their management positions and who are tired and, believe it or not, are dealing with the Civil Aviation Authority in their spare time after they have finished their flying.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maximum hours.

—After they have finished flying not only maximum hours but also, in one case to which this gentleman refers, after they have exceeded limits. That is a disastrous situation. The potential for a tragedy in the civil aviation area in this country is great. Not only is that potential great but it is sheeted home to this Minister, whom we say should be censured, first, for misleading the Parliament and, second, for failing in the most flagrant and demonstrable way in his ministerial responsibilities to guarantee civil aviation safety in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not agree that there should be a suspension of Standing Orders. No evidence has been given this morning that was not available yesterday. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the House that the last motion was moved by a Minister. Standing order 193 provides:

INTERJECT.PARA: Provided that, on sitting Thursdays, any division called for in the House before 12.30 p.m. on a question, other than a motion moved by a Minister, shall stand deferred until 12.30 p.m.

That means that under the Standing Orders we cannot have a division on whether Standing Orders shall be suspended unless the House unanimously agrees. I would be willing to accept that, if everyone in the House agreed that that standing order should be put aside, we should put it aside. Is it the agreement of all members of the House that we should proceed to put the question that Standing Orders be suspended? Is there any objection? There being no objection, I will put the question--

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I indicate the Opposition's attitude to the proposition, Mr Speaker, could I seek your indulgence to ask the Leader of the House whether it is the Government's intention to take the censure motion later today?
—The Government will work out what to do about the censure motion when the Opposition moves the censure motion, if it moves it, later today, and we will give it a response then.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Fife

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the Leader of the House giving the undertaking that the Government will consider the censure motion later today, I indicate that we would like the vote to be taken forthwith and we will be giving the Government an opportunity later today to reconsider the matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Mr Jull's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987-88 taxpayer funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State public hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating;
important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and the purity of air and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (the peoples' arm of the UN), has proclaimed an Australian ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a safer and more peaceful future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that a world-wide ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5 1990 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly. This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global co-operation to stop the current destruction and start repairing our Earth by: growing billions of trees to replace forests lost and to replenish the atmosphere; hygienically composting all presently wasted bio-degradable materials to humus to revitalise soils; establishing globally, economically viable, permanent self-sustaining organic agriculture to end world hunger.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cohen (from nine citizens), Ms Crawford (from 36 citizens), Mr Downer (from 17 citizens), Mr Fitzgibbon (from 198 citizens), Mrs Harvey (from 12 citizens), Dr Hewson (from 12 citizens), Mr Howard (from 24 citizens), Mr Kerin (from 12 citizens) and Mr Moore (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:

1. Deplore the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme ``Authority only'' drug list and the delisting of frequently prescribed drugs without ensuring that alternative products are readily available.

2. Deplore the proposed restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will reduce both remuneration to pharmacists and the standard of professional service and counselling provided by pharmacists to ensure that patients follow appropriate medication usage regimes.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to reconsider the restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anderson (from 25 citizens), Mr Gorman (from 48 citizens), Mr Lee (from 120 citizens), Mr Peter Morris (from 11 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 20 citizens) and Mr John Scott (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:

Deplore the proposed changes to the method of Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration which will affect the quality of service and counselling the pharmacist will be able to provide to the public and which could force the closure of up to 30 per cent of Australia's pharmacies.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to reconsider these proposed changes to the method of Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration.

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 78 citizens), Mr Beale (from three citizens), Dr Blewett (from 39 citizens) and Mr Cadman (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain Citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House, the inability of State and Local Government, to meet satisfactory road maintenance and construction programmes due to chronically inadequate Federal Government Funding.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House direct the Federal Government of Australia to increase the allocation of Federal Fuel Excise to roads by 10 cents per litre, from existing taxes. Further that the allocation be adjusted proportionally, to the rise and fall of fuel prices, and that the increased allocation continue from the year 1990 to 2000 inclusive.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That your electors and citizens are suffering grievously from the present compulsion to pay excessive rates of interest on the loans which we have been or will be obliged to accept in order to purchase a home, and

That we ask the Parliament to make a new law before 30 June 1989 which will prevent any bank or financial institution from charging an annual interest rate in excess of thirteen and a half percent in respect of loans or mortgages the purpose of which is the procurement of a dwelling for habitation by the borrower and his or her immediate family, and

That the welfare and security of your electors require an early further reduction of home mortgage interest rates to a level not exceeding ten percent per annum, irrespective of any wage increases or tax remissions for which it may be proposed to legislate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal

The damaging effects to community pharmacy which will be caused by the most recent decision of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. We believe that if the decision stands, the entire Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will collapse. This will result in the loss of pharmaceutical benefits to all Australians and will hurt the aged and the chronically ill to the greatest extent.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:
Set aside the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal's decision and ensure pharmacists receive an adequate and fair payment for dispensing medication and provision of health care advice.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme

PETITION.TITLE: Conservation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of Australian citizens draws to the attention of the House that they are concerned at the threat to the environment which may result from an acceleration of the greenhouse effect. Your petitioners believe that urgent legislative action is necessary to protect the environment and reverse the damage already inflicted upon it. In particular, action is required to:
recycle products that save our trees and assist to eliminate waste;
stop deforestation of rain forests and provide funding to encourage tree planting;
ban the exporting and importing of chlorofluorocarbons with the same exceptions as those specified in the Ozone Protection Act;
ban all harmful chemicals, especially toxic bleaching chemicals used in paper mills throughout Australia;
monitor the disposal of waste chemicals and products by Australian firms;
punish illegal dumping of chemical waste products and accidental spillages;
introduce tax incentives for research, development, manufacturing and marketing of renewable energy alternatives and development of technology to reduce or avoid the use of chemical pollutants; and
recycle all household wastes.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take the necessary legislative action to promote all aspects of conservation and preserve our precious environment.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the House will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask the Parliament to urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography peddlers are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

the constant changes to retirement and veterans benefits.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully points out to the House that:-
Huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families,

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.
At the time of the election of the Hawke-Keating Government in 1983, mortgage interest rates were 12.7% and a tax rebate system then existed to assist other home buyers.

Now therefore, your petitioners request that the House require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are concerned at the threat to the environment that may result from an acceleration of the Greenhouse Effect.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government:
1 To ban immediately both the exporting and the importing of Chlorofluorocarbons (CFC's) with the same exceptions as those specified in the Ozone Protection Bill.
2 to introduce tax deductibility of-
(a) cost and installation of solar heating systems; and
(b) cost and installation of home insulation.
3 To introduce tax incentives for-
(a) research and development of renewable energy alternatives;
(b) manufacturing and marketing of renewable energy alternatives; and
(c) development of new technology to reduce or avoid the use of environmental pollutants.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will legislate to provide these facilities.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. the humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whilst acknowledging the Government's desire to contain the growth in health costs, the introduction of 61 new drugs to the `Authority Required' listing will result in potentially serious delays in patients receiving medication prescribed by their doctors.
Your petitioners request the house to immediately reverse the Government's decision and withdraw these drugs from the `Authority Required' list.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House, that pharmacists, in Australia, have had their very livelihood placed in jeopardy, by the totally unreasonable decisions, of the so called ``independent'' Pharmaceutical Benefits Tribunal, in drastically reducing the remuneration paid to pharmacists for dispensing of prescriptions under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
As a result of these decisions, the essential primary health care functions and services provided (largely free) by pharmacists to the public, have been seriously put at risk.

The replacement of such services could only be fulfilled by an already overtaxed medical profession and at a financial cost that would be virtually impossible to be funded by the Government or the Community.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to, as a matter of extreme urgency, negotiate with the appointed representatives of Australian pharmacists, to ensure that an equitable financial remuneration is granted to these pharmacists for dispensing prescriptions under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and so protect the essential services now provided by these pharmacists to the Community.

PETITION.TITLE: Brain Injury Therapy Centre at Eastwood, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of citizens of the Farrer electorate respectfully showeth that there is an urgent need for continuing research into the problems of patients, following brain trauma, assessed
`comatose', or
`vegetable'

and for all such patients to have Brain Injury Therapy readily available to them immediately following the Intensive Care Unit, in a special Coma Care/Brain Injury Therapy Unit, such therapy to involve paid Health Care Professionals, family members and volunteers, and later, where possible, on home based programmes, with daily access to the facilities of the Unit; hydrotherapy an essential component.

The aim is to assist each patient to attain his/her individual maximum potential, and reach the greatest degree of independence possible; a cost effective alternative to long term nursing home and terminal care centres.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will take action:
To ensure the continuation of the Brain Injury Therapy Centre at Eastwood NSW;
To enable a research programme to be carried out at the Brain Injury Therapy Centre with twenty `warehoused' patients for a minimum period of twelve months;
To have brain injury rehabilitation funded through Medicare;

To establish Coma Care/Brain Injury Therapy Centres in each major centre, providing intensive therapy of up to eight (8) hours on at least five (5) days of each week, involving paid Health Care Professionals, family members, and volunteers;

To provide adequate support to families who are willing to provide a home based Brain Injury Therapy programme for a patient who would otherwise be hospitalised. (Adequate support to include Respite Care of six (6) weeks per year, Attendant Care, and a patients' bed linen and napkin service).
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Federal fuel excise taxation has reached record levels resulting in high costs for fuel and causing severe hardship particularly for people in country areas.
At the same time there has been a considerable reduction in the amount of Federal fuel excise taxation spent on roads, reduced from 66 per cent in 1983 to 20 per cent in 1989.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House call on the Federal Government to take heed of the crisis situation facing small business, large fuel users and the crisis situation relating to road infrastructure and-
1. Reduce by half the CPI Federal fuel tax increases
2. Increase by half the proportion of Federal fuel taxation being spent on roads

PETITION.TITLE: Breast X-Ray Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of certain citizens, electors of the Division of Wannon draws to the attention of the House the following facts about breast cancer in women.
(i) One in fifteen women in Australia get breast cancer.
(ii) 2,500 Australian women each year die of breast cancer.
(iii) The chances of dying of breast cancer can be reduced by 70% by early detection.
(iv) Early detection is best done by regular breast X-rays or mammograms.
(v) Women in Sweden and other developed countries have breast X-rays every 18 months. This service is provided by government medical services.
(vi) Australia has one pilot project in providing regular breast X-rays.
(vii) The failure of the government to introduce a service for regular breast X-rays for all Australian women is taking the lives of 1750 Australian women each year.
Your petitioners implore the House to implement a programme for regular breast X-rays for all Australian women as soon as in humanly possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Airline Pilots Dispute
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia
Draws the attention of the House to the fact that recompense is being paid to the Domestic Airlines to cover wages of certain employees of the Airlines during the present industrial dispute.
No compensation is being paid to Flight Attendants of the Airlines and other sections of the Tourism and Hospitality Industries.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House demands the Government immediately pays compensation to all employees of the Airline Industry not covered by the present payments, and to other sections of the Tourism and Hospitality Industry also affected by the present industrial dispute-or alternatively, the immediate abolition of all payments to the Airline companies.

PETITION.TITLE: Naval Facilities: Jervis Bay
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives as assembled.

We, the undersigned concerned residents, visitors and holiday makers, reject the proposed military and industrial developments in Jervis Bay and support the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation 1986 which recommended that: ``the proposed Environmental Impact Study for naval development at Jervis Bay should be undertaken only when a comprehensive planning study and public review of naval facility requirements and alternative sites demonstrates that relocation to Jervis Bay is necessary; and the proposed development at Jervis Bay be considered and planned in the context of the overall proposal for Fleet facilities and bases around Australia''.
We call for your Honourable House to conduct a Public inquiry into the proposal to relocate naval facilities to Jervis Bay.

PETITION.TITLE: Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The 23rd of August 1989 is the 50th anniversary of the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact. This pact, signed by the foreign ministers of Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union, included three secret agreements by which eastern Europe was divided into Nazi German and Soviet spheres of influence, paving the way for World War II.

The pact led to the Soviet annexation of formerly independent Lithuania. Until the force of this pact is removed, it will be difficult for Lithuania and those other occupied nations to regain their rights of self-determination.
With this in mind, and appealing to an international sense of justice, your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government:
1. To demand that the Government of the USSR renounce the pact.
2. To demand that the Government of the USSR accede to the wishes of the Lithuanian people in their expressed wish for national sovereignty and independence.

3. To demand that members of the Soviet secret police (NKVD later the KGB) be brought to trial for carrying out vast deportations of Baltic citizens which brought death or displacement to over one-quarter of the population of the Baltic states.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television: Goulburn Valley and North-Eastern Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
The people throughout the Goulburn Valley and North-Eastern Victoria request equal access for the extension of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS).

We believe that we are being discriminated against by the Government, when our area has a high percentage of residents born overseas in a non-English speaking country, and the total population exceeds one hundred thousand people.

Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled to call on the Government to include our regional area along with the recently announced other nine regional areas to give us a ``Fair Go'' by extending SBS to our area.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dr Kim Jin-Yeop
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, wish to call upon the Australian Government to:
Protest in the strongest possible way to the Government of the Republic of Korea against the arrest and subsequent detention of Australian missionary and dentist Dr Kim Jin-Yeop.
Demand his immediate release by the South Korean authorities and his total exoneration of the charge of `knowingly aiding a North Korean agent'.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the Government to implement the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which ensures the availability of pharmaceutical benefits through local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Aerospace Agency
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

Whereas space technology involves many of the very highest engineering and scientific disciplines that Australia possesses, which may be applied at an international level to reap significant economic and technological return to the nation, and;
Since an appropriate space program for Australia must involve presently unco-ordinated industry, government and research agencies, united together with Federal Government funding;

Your petitioners therefore pray that you will support the establishment of an Australian Aerospace Agency to manage aerospace programs under a Federal Budget, promote technology transfer, and market our expertise overseas, while ensuring the continued operation of existing space-related facilities within the nation.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives that we strongly object to the Federal Government's high interest rate policies which are placing serious financial pressure on families.
In the past 12 months home loan interest rates have risen from 13.5% to 17% forcing many people to sell their homes or to delay the purchase of their first house.
We call on the House of Representatives to put pressure on the Government to change its policies to ease interest rates.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Insurance Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia and former employees of the Department of Community Services and Health draw attention of the House to the transfer of the functions of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (specifically Part VII of the National Health Act 1953 and the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Regulations) to Medicare (which is administered by the Health Insurance Commission) whereby the functions have been actually transferred without the permission of the House and without appropriate consultation with the employees involved and where the affected employees have not been given automatic rights of re-entry into the Commonwealth Public Service to which these employees have sought a career.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House either, disallows the transfer of the functions of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to the Health Insurance Commission, or where the House is of the opinion that these functions are best served by the Health Insurance Commission, then the House should demand that the affected employees either have the option to remain with the Commonwealth Public Service or the employees be given automatic rights of re-entry into the Commonwealth Public Service.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Barker points out to the House that there is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House urge TV stations to clean up their act and improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that
the high level of services currently offered by my pharmacist, a frontline provider of medicine, would be threatened if the Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme (PBS) is cut back.

the PBS is one of the most essential and enduring elements of our health care system and its future must not, and should not, be sacrificed by the Government's failure to recognise the extent to which it has placed the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) in jeopardy.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Members of the House of Representatives assembled undertake an urgent reconsideration of efforts to cut expenditure on the PBS by means of reducing pharmacists' remuneration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television: Northern Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

The residents of Northern Tasmania are disadvantaged by the lack of access to the Special Broadcasting Service. Northern Tasmania's migrant community, which is more physically and culturally isolated then their counterparts in more densely populated areas, are particularly deprived because of the lack of access to this service. Ethnic communities in Northern Tasmania can be small and scattered and they experience greater difficulty in establishing contact with others of their own ethnic background and have less opportunity for the sharing of information about community services.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:
Establish local transmission facilities to receive and locally transmit the SBS signal in Northern Tasmania.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Traditional Land
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament of Australia.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) In the current excisions policy there is a lack of understanding on the part of the Northern Territory Government concerning traditional ties between the Aborigines and their land.
(2) That the present excision guidelines are too harsh/inappropriate and restrict any attempts by Aboriginal people to claim back their traditional land.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) Act immediately so that outstanding excision applications can be processed.
(2) Correct the existing excision guidelines so that Aboriginal people can have a chance to claim back their traditional land.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE Videos, Films and Publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because Parliament has a direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in Videos, Films and Publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into television standards,
ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the programme limits of Television standards,
Control ALL censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the House to the Government's actions in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of service to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the House to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme, so as to guarantee the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) recognises the valuable contribution of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in improving the cultural, intellectual and political life of Australians;
(2) congratulates Radio Australia on the attainment of its 50th birthday; and
(3) calls on the Federal Government to provide sufficient funds to enable the Corporation to continue its vital role in the development of Australian democracy.

In speaking in support of my motion that the House recognise the valuable contribution of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in improving the life of Australians, I have to admit that this is not the first time I have taken the opportunity to support the ABC in this House. Australia is very fortunate to have a national broadcaster which is free of political and commercial control. I hasten to add that this does not mean that the Corporation is not subject to economic constraints. However, there is no excuse for the kind of editorial I read in yesterday's Australian. It states:

There he goes again . . . the managing director of the ABC, Mr David Hill, whingeing, once more, about . . . the need to spend millions of taxpayers' dollars-this time on upgrading the transmitters of Radio Australia.

The editorial then goes on to damn with faint praise. It ends with no proof at all for its assertion that the services of Radio Australia lack professional quality. I have recently returned from a visit to a number of countries in the South Pacific. I have heard nothing but praise for the broadcasts of Radio Australia. Does the writer of the editorial realise that the overseas audience for Radio Australia is far greater than the total population of Australia? I think not. Nor is there any realisation of the many complaints received from populations far distant from Australia because of the poor quality of Radio Australia's broadcasts as a result of the ancient transmitters at Shepparton.

Mention was made in the editorial of the first coup in Fiji in 1987 when complaints were made of the inaccuracy of Radio Australia's news broadcasts about the political situation in that country. I am not in a position to challenge the lapse in accuracy quoted by the editorial but I know that within days of the coup it was impossible to buy short wave radios in Suva and Nadi because the population knew that it could in future rely only on the broadcasts from Radio Australia for unbiased news of events in their own country and neighbouring countries.

A reasonable implication which emerges from the editorial is that the writer was asked to submit an editorial bucketing the ABC without regard to the facts. First of all, Radio Australia has provided a valuable service for 50 years, as unsolicited comments from credible sources have indicated since the service began. Secondly, it continues to attract very large audiences which overwhelmingly express satisfaction with its service. Finally, I would be interested to know who were the officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade who were frequently unenthusiastic about the broadcasts of Radio Australia, because that has not been my experience. I have not met those officials. Most of the departmental officials that I have talked to have had nothing but praise for the professional content of Radio Australia's broadcasts.

Of course, I will not suggest that there is not room for improvement. A review committee of the ABC's overseas service began its work in November 1988 and produced a report. Eighty-six submissions were received from organisations, employees, ex-employees and other interested individuals including two parliamentarians. Those submissions provided an overwhelming impression of support and goodwill towards Radio Australia. Only a few were excessively critical, with one submission advocating that Radio Australia be closed down-only one. Generally there was appreciation of the credible and informative news and current affairs programs and the value of the presentation of Australia's views to the region.

However, a number of problems emerged from the review committee involving necessary improvements in the review of program content and style of programming. There are declining audience levels and this is a concern, particularly in the Asian-Pacific region. But that is mainly due not to a lack of program content but to technical deficiencies particularly arising from the transmission facilities. In this respect the Australian newspaper editorial was particularly inaccurate. Anyone reading the editorial could assume that the ABC owned and controlled the transmitters. Why else would the editorial refer to the ABC as a `bottomless pit' for funding? In fact, the transmitters are currently operated by Telecom Australia and are owned by the Department of Transport and Communications. The transmitters located at Shepparton are many years old, so old that they have wooden support structures. A potential fire is a constant hazard.

In congratulating Radio Australia on its fiftieth birthday, I regret that I often find it necessary to refute the inaccuracies of many of the ABC's critics, who appear to have a wish to denigrate Australia's major public broadcaster because it is public, it is objective and it is not subject to business and political influences.

The $30m needed to upgrade Radio Australia's transmitters to world class standard is a small price to pay to ensure that the ABC's large overseas audience is able to hear Radio Australia's services free of technical deficiencies. The Government should, as a matter of urgency in order to provide an unbiased news and information service to our more eastern Asian neighbours, provide funding to develop modern transmitter facilities in north Queensland. In addition, there is a need to develop an offshore capacity and two further transmitters at Darwin to increase broadcast capacity into South East Asia. It would be also a practical move to allow the ABC to own and control the new radio transmitters rather than continuing the outmoded system whereby control is exercised by Telecom Australia and the Department of Transport and Communications.

In a speech I made supporting the ABC on 30 August I commented that I considered it most unfortunate that, as a government, once again we find ourselves embroiled with the ABC in yet another funding row. Since I made that speech I have had the opportunity to look at the detailed figures for ABC funding for 1988-89 compared to 1987-88. Whilst I will not buy into the argument, it is very clear that the ABC had expected to be totally covered for inflation in its 1988-89 funding allocation. That was certainly my impression from reading all the ABC Review of National Broadcasting Policy documents and the comments of the previous Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the figures contained in the Budget.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Funding base ...
Funding Base ...

First year indexation (1988-89)
Actual Inflation (non farm deflator) 9.3%

Less Efficiency Dividend (1.25%) ...

Estimated non farm deflator indexed ...
