TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. These figures show clearly that the inflationary supplement was cash limited to 5.5 per cent and actually provided only half of the actual annual inflation level of 9.3 per cent. What is worse is that this shortfall will be carried forward into 1989-90, thus compounding the shortfall in the second year. The upshot of this is that the ABC has suffered a cumulative shortfall of $32.5m. In this respect I hope that the Federal Government can do something to assist the ABC in overcoming the financial problems occasioned by what appears to me to be a technical difference of opinion between the previous Minister, Senator Evans, and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in the framing of the budgetary allocation for the ABC. I ask the Government to look again at all the papers submitted at the time of the ABC policy review. If it does I think it will find that everybody participating in the debate had expected that the ABC's funding would be maintained in real terms for a three-year period, subject to the ABC accepting the terms of the review-to which the ABC Board agreed.

SPEECH.PARA: In commenting about the valuable contribution of the ABC in improving the cultural, intellectual and political life of Australians, I could list many of those programs in both radio and television which I, as a confirmed admirer of the ABC, listen to and watch with pleasure. Occasionally, I enjoy programs on commercial radio and television but for my most constant enjoyment I prefer ABC programs. Basically, I find its choice of programs more stimulating and entertaining. Here I do not include films because they are really derived from a different medium. However, as program preferences are mainly a personal matter I will restrict myself to admitting that my favourite radio programs are news and current affairs, the Science Report and, of course, I must not forget John Cargher's musical programs. My favourite ABC television programs include Four Corners, the Big Gig, Countrywide, the Investigators and Hypotheticals. Obviously I could go on.

I would like to complete my speech by making some additional comments about the report of the Review of National Broadcasting Policy, which was released on 26 February 1988 by the then Minister, Senator Gareth Evans. At some time in the future I hope to publish a joint paper which was written by Dr Terry King and me on the review of both the ABC and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS). In the meantime I will confine myself to a more modest contribution to this debate, which I am sure will be ongoing.

The 1988 Labor Party platform makes it clear that the ALP is `committed to the retention of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation as a wholly publicly-owned enterprise' and to `the development of the ABC as an innovative and independent broadcaster'. The 1988 platform also states that it will:
ensure that adequate funds are provided to maintain and extend the production of national, State and regional television and radio broadcasting without advertising or corporate sponsorship.
With regard to Channel 28, it also states that there will be:

consultation with the ethnic communities to enhance the operations of Channel 28 so that it can fulfil its charter of presenting multicultural Australian programs rather than simply acting as a conduit for overseas programming.

The problem is that it is impossible to equate those policies with the thrust of the various policy review proposals that were released only a few months before, and a few months after the conference which committed the Labor Party to that platform. It should be noted here that, even on economic grounds, it is extremely difficult to justify the Government's drive to divest itself of whatever degree of financial responsibility for national broadcasting it can get away with so far as the Party is concerned.

The possibility of advertising or sponsorship on either ABC or SBS television has not been greeted by the advertising industry with anything vaguely resembling wild enthusiasm. For example, the advertising newsletter Adbrief came to the conclusion that the comparatively small audience of the ABC would deter most agencies and advertisers from using it. Mind you, I am not quite sure that the audience is as small as has been put. Later figures show that that audience is much larger than had previously been thought. The managing director of one multinational agency suggested that whilst the commercial broadcasters were currently content to poach the occasional program or personality from the ABC, if they were faced with its competition for advertising revenue they would block it completely. The ABC would suffer even more and the SBS would be nowhere. Alex Hamill, the head of Australia's leading agency, indicated that if, as Senator Evans insisted in the policy review paper, there were to be strict limits on the commercialisation of the national broadcasters-restricting advertising to particular programs or accepting sponsorship but not straight advertisements-potential advertisers and sponsors would be even less enthusiastic. All in all, we could not expect, he said, anything more than a very moderate reward for placing at stake a fair degree of principle about the integrity of the national broadcasting services.

The importance, the value, of national broadcasting cannot be measured simply in terms of budget savings of tens, hundreds, or even millions of dollars. Instead, we must try to envisage the incalculable damage which could be done to Australian nationhood were we ever to lose an independent and healthy national broadcasting service, with the print media, radio and television all either totally or partially controlled by commercial interests-the Bonds, Packers and Murdochs of this world. Nothing in recent history suggests that such forces are any less likely today to attempt to manipulate the mass media to their own advantage than they were when Labor opposed the commercialisation of the ABC less than a decade ago.

I do not want to take up my full time as others wish to speak. Otherwise I would have liked to go on to talk about the comments made by the Canadian scientist and broadcaster Professor David Suzuki about the problems concerning the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation in Canada. I will not say any more. I urge support of the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise to support the motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). The motion says:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House recognises the valuable contribution the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has made in improving the cultural, intellectual and political life of Australia.

It is fairly difficult to imagine Australia without the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). We are very much a society that relies on information. In many ways we are an information starved society. In such a society, the ABC is one of our most vital sources of information. The ABC has had many strengths. One of these has been the fact that it is government funded. As such it can cater to minority tastes. It has not had to worry as much about ratings as have commercial stations. This, along with government funding and the ability to cater to minority tastes, has been a great strength. Its size has been terribly important. To put this in some perspective, a program such as Indian Pacific has had a listenership of about half a million people, which is greater than the number who read the current affairs pages of the Age and the Sydney Morning Herald.

Its range of programs has been quite marvellous. As a practising physician prior to entering parliament, there were many times when I was looking after people in hospital who were recuperating from surgery. Many times people said to me that in that post-operative period it was Radio Australia that kept them sane. The range and diversity of programs kept them going when they were too weak to do much else. The ABC has certainly contributed to our political life. There are some very notable examples here. Probably the best is Four Corners. ABC television is probably justified by the Four Corners program alone, with its exposure of the corruption in one of our States. The subsequent Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct will go down as a feather in its cap. The ABC's recent reporting of the Tiananmen Square tragedy and PM's coverage of the overthrow of Marcos both stand out as shining examples of ABC reporting. We can count on the ABC being anywhere in the world that really matters to us.

Part of the honourable member for La Trobe's motion talks about cultural life, and certainly the ABC's orchestras spring to mind. It is perhaps hard to imagine some State governments sponsoring orchestras and here the ABC fills a gap very valuably. It has a proud record with other areas of music, too. I remember the jazz programs on the ABC, particularly in the 1970s. I have always had a very great fondness for jazz and have appreciated the ABC's attention to it. In the area of sport the ABC has pioneered televised cricket. That has now gone to commercial stations but the ABC has taken up other sports which are having a growing following, such as indoor cricket, netball and lawn bowls. The appreciation of the ABC's coverage of lawn bowls was made evident to me as one of the first things that happened to me after I was elected to this place was that I was inundated with letters from bowlers in my electorate when Jack High temporarily went off Channel 2.

The ABC is, quite frankly, the best source of information in a world where newspapers and television seem to be narrowing our information base. That is why the ABC is especially important to us. Overseas, economies of scale seem to be bringing us formula programs. That threatens our evolving culture and our own view of the world. It is vitally important that a country such as ours have correspondents in its region, and even outside its region, who will report back. For example, the ABC's correspondents in the Middle East ensure that we do not just get a superpower view of what is going on there.

The second part of the honourable member for La Trobe's motion congratulates Radio Australia on the attainment of its fiftieth birthday. Congratulations should also go to Mr Peter Barnett, who has recently retired as head of Radio Australia. After being a foreign correspondent he has held the position of director with enormous success. To me what is important about Radio Australia is that it remains a broadcaster which reflects our view of the region. As such it is important that Radio Australia not pull its punches. I have some concern that in having a career diplomat as head of Radio Australia it could be said that we may pull our punches to suit the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Obviously we will watch the track record of the new head of Radio Australia with interest and hope he follows the independent and distinguished line of Mr Peter Barnett.

It is very important for us that we do not have the type of news management on Radio Australia that has occurred with other broadcasts, such as Radio America. I hope that Radio Australia maintains its independent line. To me the very essence of democracy is the free flow of information and the free flow of political opinions. The charge is frequently levelled against the ABC that it is a biased organisation. I think it is very difficult for any program to be totally free of bias. I am not too concerned about bias per se, but I am concerned with balance. On the whole I think the ABC does try to be balanced, even if we on this side of the House may be annoyed by individual programs from time to time.

The final part of the motion moved by the honourable member for La Trobe calls on the Federal Government to provide sufficient funds to enable the Corporation to continue its vital role in the development of Australian democracy. Many people would see that the ABC is under some threat. It costs a great deal of money and it is paid for by the Government. Perhaps as parliamentarians we are very sensitive to criticism and that too poses some threat to the ABC. It certainly seems that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is somewhat sensitive to the ABC's criticism. He is rarely heard on the ABC other than when when he is talking to Pru Goward about his pyjamas or the like. Anything heard on AM or PM seems to be prerecorded. However, that is not the point. I am here to congratulate the ABC and I would hope that the ABC can continue its role free of fear or favour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) warmly welcomes the election of Mr Tadeusz Mazowiecki as Primer Minister of Poland and congratulates Solidarity on its success; and
(2) calls on all democratically elected governments to support the new Polish Government as it attempts the difficult task of achieving economic recovery.

The formation of a Solidarity based Government in Poland marks the first attempt at a peaceful transition from a communist regime to one with a non-communist leadership and substantial political pluralism. While non-communist authoritarian systems have made the transition to democracy, there is no precedent for what seems to be under way in Poland. As Lech Walesa said recently, `Nobody has previously taken the road that leads from socialism to capitalism'. The Polish developments are important for Australia because of their intrinsic significance and because Australia has direct interests in East-West security. The next Polish Government faces severe economic problems with high inflation, low output, outdated manufacturing plant and an exhausted and alienated work force. A Solidarity led Government must try to cope with these problems and simultaneously set up a new structure of political authority. The Solidarity movement will clearly face substantial internal strains as well as it moves from being a repressed opposition force to leading the government.

The political and economic problems facing the Solidarity led government indicate that there is no room for complacency in the West about prospects for change in Poland. Gorbachev's courageous and audacious policies in Soviet Union domestic and foreign affairs have created a window of opportunity for peaceful change in eastern Europe which Hungary and Poland in particular are seeking to use. Change in eastern Europe, however, needs to be well conducted and effectively implemented, otherwise it will not be lasting. It is clearly in the interests of Western states to support the process of reform in Poland so as to maximise Solidarity's capacity to achieve success. Aid and support must clearly be given in a cautious manner so that it is not seen to be aiming at compromising Soviet interests and not bringing into question Poland's membership of the Warsaw Pact alliance. This point was made recently by the senior American analyst Brzezinski. What is needed from the West is a combination of material support and rhetorical restraint.

There are several ways that the West can help. Poland clearly needs substantial amounts of capital to make it possible and feasible for the economy to revive. There are critical shortages of both consumer goods and capital equipment. The West can help substantially by acting to alleviate this capital shortfall. There are grounds for concern that, so far, Western countries are not responding to the pace of change of events in Poland and to the critical need to support moves towards pluralism and democracy in a sufficiently concrete and not just a rhetorical way. So far the United States has committed just $120m in aid to Poland, which is only one-fifth of the cost of one Stealth bomber.

The European Community and other interested Western states could organise programs to allow a substantial number of Poles to gain skills in running economic enterprises. Western countries could encourage the process of economic reform and recovery by providing wider market access to Polish exports. It is clearly anomalous that exports from East Germany freely enter the European Community through the Federal Republic of Germany while Poland's exports cannot.

A number of other steps can also be taken. One is obviously debt relief. Poland is one of the major debtor countries, yet the flexibility offered by Treasury Secretary Brady's plan should be applied to Poland in the way that it is being applied to developing countries. That would include rescheduling debt reduction and interest rate reduction. Australia could respond to the need for support by giving some aid-perhaps one-off aid; maybe food aid. Such aid at this crucial time of the change of government would be particularly appropriate. We could also offer training programs and market access to Polish goods. The private sector, too, should be offering institutional help. Poland desperately needs management and banking skills. Our own banks could be involved there. Australian companies could be involved in joint ventures and in investment in Poland. That kind of cooperation would be enormously valuable to Poland as well as to Australia in building up Australian markets.

At present there is a sense of hope in Poland. The key requirement is for a change of ways of thinking, from the Government doing everything to much more self-help. The West did not create the problems of postwar Poland, but it is very much in the interests of Western countries to support those who are working peacefully, valiantly and intelligently for political and economic renewal in Poland. Despite this being a time of economic restraint in Australia, this issue deserves not only our close interest but also our strong economic and political support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this motion, as I believe everybody in this House would. The motion puts two things: that we warmly welcome the election of Mr Tadeusz Mazowiecki as Prime Minister of Poland, and congratulate Solidarity on its success; and that we call on all democratically elected governments to support the new Polish Government as it attempts the difficult task of achieving economic recovery. To say that the task is difficult is a major understatement. I address three subjects: first, the trend of change that we have seen within the Soviet empire; second, the emergence of a government which is, in essential respects, a democratic government; and, third, the problems that that government faces and what should be the response of Western governments to those problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The trends of change under Mr Gorbachev are known; the goals and the ultimate agenda are not. But broadly within the Soviet empire we have seen a loosening of the reins, particularly in eastern Europe. We have seen a resurgence in the old empire, inherited from the Tsars, of nationalism, and we have seen in eastern Europe the permitting, for whatever reasons, and after great struggle-I speak here of the Polish people-of political developments that would never have been contemplated by Gorbachev's predecessors.

We now have the most constructive period in East-West relations that we have seen since the Second World War. When we look at developments within the old Tsarist empire and the new empire that was acquired in and after the Second World War, we are probably seeing developments which are more hopeful than anything that has happened since the 1917 Revolution. This does not mean that the millenium has arrived; nor that the changes that have taken place are irreversible. But it does mean that we have entered a hopeful and constructive time for the resolution of some of the main issues that have plagued us and have plagued peace for decades.

I now move on to Poland's situation. Poland exemplifies the best of what has taken place and the best that we can hope for. We have seen elections, admittedly in part rigged, and following those elections we have seen the installation of a recognisably democratic government. I remind the House of the composition of that Government. Four ministries have been accorded to the Farmers Party: agriculture, justice, environment and health. The Social-Democrat Party holds the commerce and technical development ministries. Defence, the interior, transport and foreign trade were assigned to the Polish United Worker Party-the Communist Party. I read from the Solidarity newsletter of 1 September 1989:

The foreign affairs ministry, though doggedly claimed by the communist party as its birthright, passed over to Solidarnosc, which also took charge of the main economic posts in addition to culture, education, communication and labour.

That is nothing short of astonishing. However, this change would never have come about without the struggle that was engaged in by Solidarity and by all the members of the Polish community who fought for freedom. As Mr Walesa reminds us when he recalls the spirit of August 1980:

We are celebrating the ninth anniversary of the August Agreements. On 31 August 1980 as chairman of the inter-enterprise strike committee . . . I signed the document that laid the cornerstone for NSZZ Solidarnosc-
that is, the Solidarity movement-
and changed the course of Polish history. The years that have passed since have not been easy-many battles were lost and won.

Then a year ago, the August 1988 strikes opened up a new road for Poland. The electoral results in this June proved decisively that our nation does not want piecemeal and slow change. It wants a fundamental breakthrough, it wants equality of civil rights, it wants full democracy and a healthy economy.

That is a marvellous achievement. What are the problems that Poland faces? What is the response that the West should give? Some of the problems have been referred to by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). Some of the details were outlined by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a short time ago. He was speaking of the current food shortages. He said:
In fact, the current acute food supply shortages in Poland are symptoms of an economic crisis of unprecedented proportion.

Clear signs of breakdown appeared this spring and the awareness of impending crisis impelled the authorities to make haste in signing the contract at the Round Table. April and May brought near economic collapse. The deficit, which totalled 2.6 billion in April, nearly doubled within a month to 3.5 billion zlotys . . .

He went on to list the falls in production that have taken place in Poland in May as against the previous year-by 5.3 per cent for the electric machinery industry, 3.5 per cent for non-ferrous metals, 11 per cent in the automobile industry, 7.5 cent in the footwear industry. He said:
A final indicator sums up the situation: this May, the railway, freight, and maritime networks transported 13 per cent less goods than in 1988.

The calls for aid are understandable and I believe that we must do whatever we practically can to help Poland. If the crisis worsens it could become a catastrophe. If that happened what would be the shape of the government that might then emerge? The aim of Western help, in which the major democracies must join, must be to rebuild the capital infrastructure of Poland and to raise standards of living, particularly in basic areas such as availability of food, clothing and other everyday family household goods. But it is no good throwing money at the problem, even though the rescheduling of Poland's immense foreign debt is going to be necessary as an ongoing process.

Let me list some of the specifics that I believe need to be addressed urgently: a system of commercial banks to help finance economic reconstruction; government guarantees of foreign investment so that private foreign investment flows into Poland; and an urgent review of the means of channelling foreign investment and expertise into food production to alleviate food shortages and into small business to alleviate other shortages. Remember that small businesses can move more quickly than large businesses. Broadly, and before major commitments are given, there should be an urgent and wide-ranging review of the economy to recommend areas of major foreign investment, especially in areas of shortage. Poland does not need any more white elephants. An equally wide-ranging reform should be made by the Polish Government in restrictions on private sector investment, both local and foreign, because private sector investment in the long run must be the engine which will power regrowth in the Polish economy.

Let me conclude with the following comments. The failure of Poland as a democratic government could presage failure of democratic reform elsewhere in eastern Europe or could block moves to democratic reform such as we see now in Hungary and we hope for in Czechoslovakia and even, perhaps against all rational expectations, in East Germany. The economic collapse of Poland would almost of necessity bring about the collapse of the Government. What government would then be installed? There would, I fear, be a reversion to all that has failed and all that has subjugated the Polish people. It is vital therefore that the Polish Government and the Polish people be supported by all practical means so that democracy becomes embedded in the Polish system. There is no time to lose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure for me to second the motion of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) welcoming the election of the Solidarity Government in Poland under Prime Minister Mazowiecki and calling on democratic governments around the world to assist Poland in its difficult task of achieving economic recovery. Like all honourable members, I have been following with interest events in Poland over the last few years, especially its move towards democracy since the fledgling days of Solidarity. It is a matter of great joy to all of us, I dare say, as well as to the thousands of Polish Australians that we represent, that democracy has been reborn in Poland and that the political will of the Polish people is being reflected in its government.

SPEECH.PARA: In Poland, however, as in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), political reforms are not enough. After years of manipulation and central control, the economy is in a parlous state with hyper-inflation and the collapse of supply. The top priority of the Polish Government and its supporters in the West must be to reform and revitalise that economy. Opinion is far from united about how this should be done. Many experts suggest a transfer of state property to private owners. Others, however, see dangers in fully-fledged privatisation for an economy which is devoid of competition and markets. They say that the first step should be autonomisation, not privatisation, and that privatisation would only replace the economic dictatorship of the communist state with that of privately held monopolies. Different economists have different priorities but it is certain that over the next few months some fairly draconian measures will have to be taken to tame the hyper-inflation, restore price stability, build Poland's private sector and put the sprawling government sector under some sort of discipline.

The Polish economic Minister last month presented the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank with a timetable of reforms over the next six months. Subsidies are to be cut sharply, prices liberated from decades of arbitrary administrative controls, and the highly overvalued zloty is to be devalued. These changes will produce a corrective inflation on top of the existing rate of 50 per cent a month.

As honourable as these plans may be, they are fraught with danger. We see how in the Soviet Union economic and political reforms have quite reasonably raised the aspirations and expectations of the Soviet people for higher wages, better supply of consumer goods and a higher standard of living. But when change is slow people get impatient and frustrated-hence the industrial and civil unrest taking place in the USSR at the moment. There are always political opportunists inside a country who seek to gain popularity by saying that they can do something better and faster. In Poland the planned reforms will inevitably bring in the first instance a drop in wages and higher inflation, which are not things which make governments popular. Poland, of course, is not the beast that the Soviet Union is; it is much smaller, less racially diverse and more manageable. But since it seems as though things will need to get worse before they get better there is every likelihood that the same kind of civil unrest will take place in Poland. One can only hope that good sense, patience and optimism will prevail.

Meaningful change in Poland can only occur with Western support, both moral and material, as the honourable member for Fraser has already said. Australia can certainly play its part in this process. Australia has accepted an invitation from the European Commission to follow up the Group of Seven economic summit proposals on coordinated Western assistance to Poland and Hungary. Australia has attended two meetings of the Group of Twenty-four in Brussels. Recently we announced a number of assistance measures. These include the provision of the Australian system of tariff preferences to Poland and Hungary, the commencement of negotiations for double taxation agreements, and the use of trade development centres. Australia already has a $200m credit facility with Poland. We are also considering a food package for Poland, investment protection agreements and postgraduate training assistance.

But, as the honourable member for Fraser has put it very forcefully, there is no doubt a lot more that the Australian Government, banks and business can do for Poland. The same can be said for other Western economies. The amount of money Poland needs now is a pittance of the collective economies of the Western nations. I join the honourable member for Fraser in urging the Australian Government and Australian business and those of other Western nations to reach a little bit deeper into their pockets when it comes to assistance for Poland.

Finally, I can only reiterate the sentiments that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) expressed in this chamber on 17 August when he welcomed the new Polish Government and pledged Australia's support for the political, social and economic reforms ahead. We can only wish the Government and the people of Poland courage and patience and, ultimately, success in the huge task they have in front of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to join other members in supporting the motion. I also wish the new Polish Government well. I have a copy of the speech by Premier Mazowiecki to the Parliament in September this year and I will comment on some of his remarks. He commenced his speech with the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: I come here as a Solidarity man who is faithful to the legacy of August of 1980. In my view, that legacy is above all a great all-embracing call from the community to be treated seriously, to have the right to decide their own future as a nation . . .

I was fortunate enough to be in Warsaw in December 1980. We would all recall that there had been yet another summer of dispute in Gdansk. The workers of Solidarity had said that they had had enough with the way that Poland had been run and interfered with by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) and that they were seeking to establish Poland as a more democratic state. At that time there was no doubt that the Russian tanks were sitting precisely at the border of the USSR and Poland. It was not a very comfortable time to be visiting. I was able to interview the leader of Solidarity in Warsaw. I remember that we had to sneak away rather cautiously one night and have private discussions in his unit. We were fairly sure that that conversation would be taped. That fellow, and I guess all the Solidarity leaders, were remarkable for their courage. I think they understood-all Poles would understand this better than any Australian-that Poland had been the punching bag of Europe for many years. It had been invaded from the west and the east. These people were under considerable pressure. It was not an easy thing simply to form a free trade union movement and to challenge the power of the state, but Lech Walesa and others had the courage to do that. It was a remarkable opportunity for me to speak to those fellows.
I later interviewed a political correspondent with the party newspaper called Polityka. We talked about political censorship and freedom of the press. He remarked:
An editor in Poland doesn't need a set of rules or a political boss to tell him what to do or what not to print, he just needs a map.

I think he was perfectly right. Poland's geography has determined much of its history because it literally has rested between the two major camps of European and Russian power. The Poles have been imposed upon for a long time and that is why Mazowiecki made the following remarks in his speech about the geopolitical position of Poland:

The situation of Poland in the last 45 years was largely determined by tensions and conflicts in global policy. Today, the end of the cold war creates for us a chance to realise our national aspirations in accordance with modern trends in global policy.
He further made the point:

If the day comes when the security of Europe no longer requires the existence of military blocs, we shall greet this fact without regret. We believe that such a day will come. For today, it is important that all treaties and military alliances should only concern the external security of their member states, and not their internal political and economic order. We greet . . . very sign that this understanding of international relations is taking root in our part of Europe.

Mazowiecki was saying to the Russians, `Whilst we value an external treaty for the security of Poland and we remain your colleagues and part of the Warsaw Pact, you really should now stop interfering in our internal affairs'. It is a remarkable change in Polish political events that a free trade union movement can now stand alongside the Communist Party itself and other democratic movements within Poland and actually run the country. Mazowiecki has set himself a fairly difficult task. He has said that the test of Polish democracy will be the success of the economy. He is perhaps a little too harsh on himself because I would imagine that the Poles have got used to not only fairly poor economic conditions, but also very poor political government. I do not think the Poles will be so harsh on this new democratic government that they will seek to throw it out if all is not well in the near future. That should not be any comfort to the Western powers. Those powers need to help Poland; they need to assist its economic reconstruction so as to take pressure off the new and emerging democracy in Poland.
Another amazing fact about Polish political life is the flexibility of the Pole. Again in an article I wrote in 1980 I stated:
The fact is that a significant proportion of the Polish adult population is at one and the same time Catholic, a member of PZPR-
that is, the Communist Party-
and now a member of Solidarnosc.

The Poles are not fools. They understand that Polish life requires those elements-communism as given to them by the USSR, Catholicism, for which they fought and bled for a thousand years, and now this free trade union movement-but that any one individual adult could be a member of all three institutions. I think that indicates that the Poles are flexible enough and mature enough not to be too hard on their new government. It will be a very difficult couple of years for the Poles as they reconstruct their economy and make it more of a free market economy, but I suspect that they will lend even further support to their new Premier, to Solidarity, and to relations between Solidarity and the Communist Party. I wish them well in that.

Could I just cast my eye across the enormous number of changes that Mazowiecki is promising his people. He is suggesting that change is so fundamental that for the first time since World War II the Polish Army should not be used to keep the Poles in order but, in fact, should be governed by the Government in order to keep the Poles free from intruders. It is true that the Polish militia, if you like, has been used to keep the Poles in order, not their enemies.

The sorts of economic reforms that Mazowiecki outlined in his speech were as follows: he wishes to reduce the Government's budget deficit; he wishes to increase what he calls the discipline of tax collection-obviously a whole lot of state enterprises were not very good at paying their taxes; he wants to change the property ownership system so that there is an open market in land in Poland; he wants to allow employees to purchase company shares in these new enterprises; he wants to establish a stock exchange so that there truly is a free market; he wants to revoke the central distribution of market prices; and he wants to allow the zloty to be convertible into other currencies. He wants to break the monopoly in the food market so that eventually food prices for Poles will fall.

Prime Minister Mazowiecki is very critical of the system of public finance in Poland. He wants a fundamental reform to the tax system and to impose what he calls a genuine tax on personal income. I have not yet understood the next remark in his speech, which is:
However, the scale of its progressiveness will not be in conflict with the basic goal, which is to tap the huge reserves of human initiative and enterprise to be found in our society.

I do not know whether he wants a progressive income tax scale or a regressive income tax scale. Maybe one should read more into that remark. He wants to create a banking system and lift administrative control over prices. Above all, he wants the working people to realise that some unemployment will be created, as there is a shift into new industries, and that there will be a need for retraining, retooling and reskilling in the work force-the sort of language that we use. He understands that that needs to take place as Poland moves into a new economy.

The depth of Poland's economic difficulties is enormous. The inflation rate in Poland is around 4,000 per cent, which means that there is no way in which the Polish Government can deliver a reasonable inflation rate in the next few years. It is simply impossible. Again, when I read Mazowiecki's speech I suspect he is being a little too harsh when he suggests that his Government will be governed in the short term by its ability to solve the economic problems of Poland. He is trying to solve the economic problems of 50 years. He will not be able to do it, but he is quite entitled to call on all of those who believe in a new and democratic Poland to give Poland the greatest possible assistance to achieve that democracy in its affairs which it has been denied for so long. I wish the new Polish Government well, and especially the Polish people as they seek to renew their social, economic and political lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very early on the new Prime Minister of Poland, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, identified Poland's economic problems as being its gravest danger when he asserted:

SPEECH.PARA: Poland cannot afford ideological experiments any more.

He promised to return to a free market economy, as Lech Walesa had earlier indicated. The new Polish Prime Minister has also promised a return to a legal system that guarantees individual rights. The motion we are addressing today states, in part:
calls on all democratically elected governments to support the new Polish Government as it attempts the difficult task of achieving economic recovery.
It is no wonder that Prime Minister Mazowiecki identified Poland's economy as being the country's gravest concern because it is, indeed, in a very grave situation.

The communist government's greatest policy folly was to allow Western banks to make huge, unsecured loans at ridiculous interest rates during the 1970s. This policy has done nothing for the Polish people except to accrue a massive foreign debt of $US40 billion. In the present circumstances in Poland this debt is impossible to pay off, and it grows daily with compound interest. The shelves of Polish shops are empty and the Polish currency, the zloty, has all but collapsed.

What Poland desperately needs, and needs now, is at least a three-year constructive aid package that will deliver sufficient quantities of food and consumer goods to allow Prime Minister Mazowiecki the time and opportunity to reconstruct Poland's economy. All Western democracies-particularly the United States of America and those in Europe, but also Australia-must do all that they possibly can to ensure that Poland is given both the time and the opportunity it needs to restructure its economy along free market lines. Unfortunately, until very recently, that response has not been forthcoming in the way that it perhaps should have been. However, it is gratifying to see that President Bush of the United States announced today that he will ask Congress for an additional $US200m-$A257.56m-in aid to Poland as part of a projected $US1 billion-$A1.29 billion-in Western assistance to back Warsaw's move towards a market economy. The new aid, which will be in grant form and contingent on Warsaw's agreement to an International Monetary Fund economic stabilisation plan, will be in addition to the $US100m, or $A128.78m, in food assistance and $US120m-$A154.54m-in economic aid previously promised by President Bush. We will all welcome those moves by the United States Administration because there is no doubt that there is a school of thought that the Polish Communist Party and its former parliamentary allies are using the new Prime Minister and Solidarity as a tool to obtain Western aid. If that aid had not been forthcoming, they would have been among the first to force the new Polish Administration to accept responsibility for the subsequent failures.

That is a very positive note on which to end this debate on Poland. I am sure we all welcome the request that President Bush will be putting to the United States Congress as a major step in pushing the Polish economy towards a concrete road to recovery, therefore guaranteeing its political stability and future as a democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House requests the Federal Government not to forward any new listing to the World Heritage Commission until approval has been given by the responsible State and local governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get stuck into it, Max.

—I can assure my friend and colleague the honourable member for Franklin that I certainly intend to do that. If one looks objectively at the procedure for World Heritage Committee listings, one can only conclude that it is a dog's breakfast. No-one really knows what the procedure is to be. There are no guidelines for nominating listings to the World Heritage Committee. There are no criteria. There is no set procedure that can be adopted, and people in the community-investors and those in industry-have no idea of the procedure to be adopted. The only procedure we can be certain of is that the final approval will be given by Senator Richardson and his colleagues, because they will simply override any criteria or objectives which might come from any of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: Huge areas of Australia are under threat of being locked up from all forms of development. In my own State of Tasmania-which is, of course, my prime concern-25 per cent of the land area is locked up in World Heritage listing. That means that 25 per cent of Tasmania is controlled from Paris-not Tasmania and not Australia. Similar things are happening in north Queensland; there are threats to large areas of southern New South Wales; and, in the electorate of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), huge forest areas are also under grave threat.

I want to concentrate my comments this morning on what is happening in Tasmania, and what has happened in recent times. As I said, 25 per cent of the land area in Tasmania is now locked up in World Heritage listings. Because this issue is of such importance to Tasmania, I am disappointed that we will not hear a response during this debate from the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr). As this is of prime concern to his electorate and the State of Tasmania, I would have thought that he would be here to offer some comments. I accept that we will get a response from the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), who represents an urban inner city area of Melbourne. We need to understand that this is typical of how the Australian Labor Party uses this issue. The Labor Party uses conservation in general, but more particularly listings for the World Heritage Committee, for purely political reasons in order to win votes in the metropolitan areas of Melbourne and Sydney. It is typical of that objective by the Labor Party that a member from the metropolitan area of Melbourne responds to this motion instead of the honourable member for Denison who ought to have the interests of Tasmania as his prime objective.

I will press on with the reasons why I bring this motion forward today. In Tasmania we have just witnessed the election of a new government. One might dispute whether it was legitimately elected because there was a huge swing against the Labor Party which came out losing heavily. However, because of a deal that was done between the Labor Party and the greens in Tasmania it became the Government. Within nine weeks of that new Government's taking office, another huge slice of Tasmania was being offered to the World Heritage Committee in Paris. The area of World Heritage listing in Tasmania was effectively doubled by the nomination brought forward by the Field Government after only nine weeks in office. One might speculate as to whether that nomination by the Field Government was a genuine one or whether it was driven by the extremist conservation movement headed by Dr Bob Brown. It is my suspicion that it was the agenda of Dr Bob Brown that forced that nomination for World Heritage listing. After the Field Government had nominated the areas that it concluded were appropriate for nomination on 6 September the Advocate newspaper reported:

The leader of the Independents, Dr Brown, said that Government decision fell well short of including all areas of World Heritage value and he would continue to fight to have more land included before the listing was sent to Paris.

Dr Brown was not content with just 25 per cent of Tasmania; he wanted more. He made the statement after the State Government had determined the areas that it thought appropriate. It is interesting to see what Senator Richardson had to say. The Advocate reports:
`The balance is almost right-but not quite,' he said . . .
It is the latest indication by Senator Richardson and his staff that it is he, and nobody else, who draws boundary lines on Tasmanian maps.
The Advocate also reports:

The Federal Minister for the Environment, Senator Richardson, said last night that there would almost certainly be Federal Government changes to the World Heritage boundaries announced by the Premier, Mr Field.
Senator Richardson said that the Premier had `almost, but not quite' got the proper balance between conservation and the preservation of jobs.

One might well question who is governing Tasmania. Is it the elected Labor Government? Is it Premier Field? Is it Dr Bob Brown or is it Senator Graham Richardson, who is governing Tasmania from the Federal Parliament? Quite rightly, any Tasmanian government should be able to determine what developments it wants and its own economic program. It ought also to have the flexibility to be able to put that program into effect. But in Tasmania and, I suspect, in other States, prospective developments such as those proposed for the Gippsland electorate and for north Queensland do not go ahead because of the intervention of the Federal Government using, in particular, the pretext of protecting the natural environment.

What effect is that having? We have already gone through the debilitating debate about the proposed pulp mill for Wesley Vale. A major company was prepared to spend $1,000m to set up a processing plant that would develop Australia's natural resources into a value-added product. That project would not have cut down one extra tree. Each year three million tonnes of woodchips are exported to Japan. The Wesley Vale project was designed to put 1.8 million tonnes of woodchips into processed paper and 1.2 million tonnes would have been exported to Japan. The result of the Wesley Vale debate is that we will not process that paper in Australia. We will still send three million tonnes of woodchips to Japan and we will then buy back the paper from the Japanese which, in turn, will make our balance of payments worse.

Only last week the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) described the woodchip industry in rather colourful and expressive language, but he was absolutely right. He said that the Federal Government must reassess its policies on the pulp and paper industry and, in particular, it must have policies that will allow Australian industries to process our resources. Senator Button knows that we cannot continue with an economic or industrial program that sends off our raw materials to another country and then buys back the finished product. That is economic madness, but that is what the Federal Government is doing because it is driven by the extremist environmental movement and Senator Richardson. I strongly suggest that Senator Button had in mind that we keep our raw materials in Australia and use them for our economic benefit-to create jobs and economic activity and to help the economy back on the rails. Unfortunately, Senator Button seems to be a voice in the wilderness within the Government because all the Government is being dictated by is the need to win votes in metropolitan Melbourne and Sydney and it will distort any of our economic prospects for that purpose.

The debate in Tasmania has not yet concluded. We have been through the dilemma of Wesley Vale, but that is not the end of it. I know of another project in Tasmania that proposes to invest about $700m in further processing our timber resources. It does not propose to cut down any more trees; it simply proposes to process that material into downsteam products. I wonder what the response from Senator Richardson will be. I wonder what the response from the extremist environmental movement will be because it seems that it is that movement which dictates the policy to both the Tasmanian Government and the Federal Government. I suggest that Dr Bob Brown and his colleagues have made captive servants of the Tasmanian Premier and his Ministers in Tasmania and also have Senator Richardson acting as their agent in the Federal Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have their backs to the wall, Max.

—The honourable member is quite right. I suggest that, if we are to get the economy of the country back on the rails, we cannot do it while we continually transfer the control and the management of our land areas in this country to an undetermined body of people based in Paris while at the same time responding to the extremist environmental movement by locking up the resources of the country.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment the Government is caught in the same dilemma in considering the development of Coronation Hill in Kakadu National Park. The Government is locked into a bind. It is caught between our balance of payments problem and, therefore, the urgency of developing our national resources and the demands made on it by the extremist environmental movement, which wants to preclude that type of economic development. The Government simply wants to win votes in metropolitan Melbourne and Sydney.

I urge the Government-and this is why I have moved this motion today-to tell those people who would retard the development of our economy and the job opportunities for our young people, who will be the nucleus, the heart and soul, of this country, and in the process give them little hope, that they are not acting in an Australian way; that we want to provide opportunities; and that we will no longer tolerate being dictated to by a small minority of extremists.

My motion requests that any new listing to the World Heritage Committee be first considered and approved by the appropriate State and local governments. In the new listings that have just gone forward covering areas in Tasmania, no consideration was given to local government; as I understand it, it was not even informed of the areas to be nominated until they had been announced by Senator Richardson. There was no discussion with industry organisations-the forestry industry, the mining industry or any other industry group-and not even with the trade union movement. When the State Government made its recommendation about listing, that recommendation was overruled by the Federal Government. That situation is clearly unacceptable in any democracy. The Federal Government ought to determine guidelines and proper criteria for any new World Heritage listings.

What is desperately needed from the Federal Government, and what is more important than having criteria and guidelines for the World Heritage listing, are guidelines for industrial development. We cannot have potential investors who come forward with plans for industrial development feeling that their investments will be jeopardised because they do not know how the Federal Government will respond. If the Federal Government is to give confidence to investors and companies-the Australian people-it must give clearer guidelines. We can then be confident that, when new ideas and potential investments emerge, they have a good chance of being accepted and going ahead. New economic developments can then take place and new job opportunities can be created.

In conclusion, I ask the Federal Government to steer away from its blind adherence to the demands made on it by the extremist environmental movement and give more consideration to what is needed for development and for future opportunities in this country rather than be restricted by the demands of the extremist environmental movement and the narrow objective of simply winning votes in Melbourne and Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of threshold points. The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) indicated implicitly that because I serve a constituency in the Melbourne area somehow I ought to be precluded from putting a view on this matter, as some of the issues that he adverted to affected Tasmania. As the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) knows, in terms of background and credentials I in fact come from the bush, not from a metropolitan electorate.
—I always thought there was something wrong with you.

—If the honourable member thinks there is something wrong with people who come from the bush, that is something he should be accountable for. I certainly do not hold that view. It is not really apposite to much, but my father was a timber worker for many years until he suffered a quite serious injury as a timber cutter. For the rest of his working life he worked in a factory producing paper from pulped timber. So I have a family background in an area that may surprise the honourable member for Lyons.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I should make a couple of quite important points about these issues. My colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) is not here. It was a bit unkind of the honourable member for Lyons to somehow imply that he should be. As the honourable member for Lyons would know, I had priority on the speaking list on this topic, so the honourable member for Denison had no choice but not to be here. He is in here so often that I suspect he is running out of favours.

TALK.START.PARA: —He never talks on this issue, though.

—That is entirely misleading and incorrect. If the honourable member were to look at the parliamentary record and numerous public statements made by the honourable member for Denison he would see that he is incorrect. But I will not be drawn by the honourable member for Gippsland. I want to make a couple of important points. The first is that the motion that the honourable member for Lyons has put before the House is somewhat ambiguous or moderate in its terminology. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House requests the Federal Government not to forward any new listing to the World Heritage Commission until approval has been given by the responsible State and local governments.

If one were to strip away that terminology one would see that in essence the honourable member for Lyons proposes a course of action which would allow any State or local government effectively to veto a World Heritage nomination. The record of State and local governments in these issues gives very little ground for confidence that they would properly discharge their responsibilities. The Commonwealth Government, the Hawke Government, views its responsibilities under the World Heritage convention very seriously indeed. A nominated area or property in the World Heritage listing has to have a special and unique place not only in Australia but in the world.

I have here a speech made by Mr Jim Thorsell, the Executive Officer of the Commission on National Parks and Protected Areas under the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. I very strongly commend a reading of this speech by an internationally acknowledged expert in this field, someone who has international bipartisan support for the extraordinary contribution he has made to these very important issues.

The honourable member for Lyons talked about opportunities for young Australians. In a very real sense the issue of environment and conservation takes particular notice of young people. In essence, it is all about this Parliament making decisions that will be relevant not only in the next three years, five years or 10 years but for hundreds of years. There is a most important change in attitude to environmental issues. They are about sustainable development; they are about the future of this planet. The honourable member for Lyons is a bit slow to come to grips with these issues, as many other people are, but they are important issues. Sustainable development does not mean that one simply has no development. That would constitute an absurdity.

In my view, providing the environmental safeguards can be satisfied and the legal rights of the Aboriginal people in that area can be accommodated, Coronation Hill ought to proceed. The driving force for that is, in part, our current account difficulties. My main motivation for coming to that decision is that I am confident that the trade-off, the balance, between environmental considerations and development can be achieved. I believe that it will be achieved with the effluxion of time.

In relation to our whole range of other areas of importance it is worth making the point that every nomination in Australia placed before the World Heritage Committee has been accepted to date. When listing properties on the World Heritage List the Australian Government has obviously been conscious of its responsibility not only simply to list but also to manage and to preserve those areas in the future. Naturally the Government-this is not a matter of assertion by me but a matter of record-seeks the full cooperation of all parties; that is, not only of State governments and local governments but also of industries and, for example, the tourist industry. To date that form of cooperation has been extremely successful. With the exception of a couple of very black marks in a couple of areas overwhelmingly it has been very successful indeed.

Everyone here understands the attitude of the Queensland Government in relation to the wet tropics area of north-east Queensland where the Commonwealth had to deal with what I would regard-I think most people would regard-as a reactionary government in that area. First of all in that Government we had a person whom I regarded as a discredited thug-Bjelke-Petersen. Then we had Michael Ahern and now we have Mr Cooper. Those people are not remotely interested in anything other than supporting developers. As recently as last week on the Four Corners program we had the expose of the National Party Government in Queensland acting in a highly corrupt way by transferring leasehold arrangements in the Cape York area into outright ownership by particular groups. I noticed one case where for $80,000 a leasehold property was transferred by the National Party Government to full ownership by a National Party member. This ought to be public property. A couple of weeks later the National Party member sold the land for $5m. That is not bad money and not bad crookery.

I hope those people are brought to account. I dearly hope that there is a mechanism available to ensure that the people who were involved in that skulduggery, that theft of public property, that corruption in action, are brought to account. When Max Burr talks about any nomination having the full support of the--

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member will refer to other members by their correct titles.

—I take the point, Mr Deputy Speaker. When the honourable member for Lyons talks about the nomination having the full support of the State Government he cannot reckon on a government like that National Party Government in Queensland. Things are changing. It is worth making the point that in Tasmania, in the context of the Franklin, originally the Franklin was an agreed nomination by the Tasmanian Government, as the honourable member for Lyons well knows. In terms of the contemporary situation there are throughout the country a whole range of discussions going on: in relation to Shark Bay in Western Australia; in relation to the Nullarbor Plain by the Western Australian and South Australian governments which are working on a World Heritage nomination. The Victorian, New South Wales and Australian Capital Territory governments are working on trying to retain the Australian Alps, that pristine alpine area. In a different context, in terms of the urban aspect that the honourable member for Lyons adverted to earlier, the Rocks in Sydney were nearly bowled over 15 years ago. I well remember the debate at the time. But now people are starting to recognise the intrinsic value of such areas not only for honourable members sitting in this place who can wander down there but for future generations, the very young Australians to whom the honourable member for Lyons referred.

SPEECH.PARA: From the very outset of this debate on the wet tropics, for example, the Government talked to the Queensland National Party with a view to cooperating on management. It was not talking about vetos. It was talking about arriving at a consensus opinion. Of course, the Queensland Government would have nothing of that. It was in the High Court of Australia. We had the sad spectacle of Queensland Government representatives trooping overseas to try to challenge in Paris the relevant nomination. This Government will continue to seek cooperative management arrangements in relation to north Queensland but we must also acknowledge that at the end of the day, as is obvious from the nature of the convention, the Federal Government has the final responsibility. I think that that is an important responsibility.

In my view the Australian Government ought to have a far greater range of powers in relation to environmental and conservation issues than it has now-I go much further than the honourable member for Lyons-but all in the context of sustainable development-the balance between development, jobs, the current account and also the very important environmental considerations that have been referred to. It is also worth making the point that in terms of the World Heritage nominations the four criteria that have to be satisfied are very rigorous. We cannot just roll up, throw a bit of paper around and get a nomination. It is very serious. That is why I think the speech by Jim Thorsell is so important. He is perhaps the most internationally well-respected person in this jurisdiction not only in terms of the broad issues but also in terms of the technical criteria. Mr Thorsell described the World Heritage nominations as:
. . . if you like, the `Nobel Prize' or `Hall of Fame' for protected areas.
My impression here can be briefly and squarely stated: Australia has done more to implement the World Heritage Convention than any other single country.

My own experience, after evaluating more that 50 World Heritage nominations from 26 countries, is that two stood out in terms of their solid and scientific documentation and both these were from Australia.

He went on to endorse very strongly the role of the Australian Government in these areas. He said that Australia's efforts in the promotion of public awareness of the heritage concept have also been exemplary. I think that the honourable member for Lyons is being too political when he simply asserts that these matters are raised to garner votes in metropolitan areas. I think that will happen. But I do not think that is remotely relevant. I do not believe that any Australian, whether living in a metropolitan or non-metropolitan area, should be prejudiced in putting a view about environmental matters that these days do not only extend beyond State boundaries; for goodness sake they extend globally. That is why this Government is supporting, for example, the world park concept in Antarctica.
