SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House notes the urgent need to promote the use of native saltbush in Australia as a means of protecting the environment as well as providing invaluable stock feed crops.

Recently I had a visit from a very old friend, an agricultural scientist and a former New South Wales Western Lands Commissioner, Mr Dick Condon. Mr Condon reintroduced me to the unique qualities of the Australian native plant atriplex nummularia, known as old-man saltbush. I have now become a fan of that amazing plant. It is my belief that saltbush can provide an answer to many environmental problems in this country as well as being a source of income for land-holders.

Many people in Australia are aware of the salinity problems that we face, particularly in the middle Murray areas of Victoria and New South Wales and certain upland areas. We are desperately looking for solutions to this problem and perhaps the solution does not lie in huge and costly engineering works that often concentrate the environmental problems into local areas which themselves become environmental disasters. The answer may lie in the native plant old-man saltbush which has a component of almost every vegetation type in Australia from the middle reaches of the Murray-Darling and Lake Eyre Basin as far north as Hughenden in Queensland and westward to the Indian Ocean.

But Australia has had to reimport the knowledge of the outstanding qualities and productivity of this vegetation from South Africa. There, it has been possible to re-establish old-man saltbush in a plantation mode and to use it as a living haystack drought reserve. The South Africans have begun to recognise that saltbush is more than a drought reserve and have begun to use it as a means of increasing farm-earning capacity. Some are replacing lucerne stands as they run out with old-man saltbush plantations because they are easier to manage, little problem with waterlogging, are more productive as a grazing plant and, most importantly, once planted last forever.

Old-man saltbush has had a reputation in Australia of being a very drought-resistant plant, but it had to be handled carefully because it had been wiped out by heavy grazing over large areas in outback Australia. In higher rainfall areas it had been purposely eradicated because it was a harbour for rabbits. Conditions in the original settlement leases in New South Wales required that land be cleared to develop it for cropping and pastures. In the process, we went close to eliminating the one plant which has the capacity to maintain the native environment and sustainable and profitable agriculture. With the knowledge we now have, most of which has come from South Africa, we can use it to rescue our farming, grazing and irrigation areas which are being destroyed by salinity.

The productivity of old-man saltbush is such that in areas where it can be grown in Australia-on any soil type and anywhere the acidity is not below pH 5.5-it can be used to avoid the need for farm reconstruction, whether necessary because of declining terms of trade, because productivity and profitability are declining as a result of increasing salinity, or a variety of other reasons.

Comparing old-man saltbush as a drought reserve forage with lucerne hay, we find that lucerne hay will cost the user about $5 a bale by the time he transports it and feeds it out. That is sufficient to feed 25 sheep on a maintenance ration for a day at a cost of 20c per sheep per day. A 15-month-old plant of old-man saltbush will feed one sheep for two days and provide a high protein, high fibre, high carbohydrate, low fat, living green feed for an outlay of 30c, which is equivalent to 15c per sheep per day for first grazing, but free feed for the next 160 years.

Old-man saltbush and other atriplex species and several other genera in the family chenopodioceae belong to an unusual group of plants with a C4 photosynthetic pathway, most plants having a C3 photosynthetic pathway, for fixing carbon dioxide. The C4 pathway enables the old-man saltbush to fix carbon dioxide from the atmosphere at a much greater rate than C3 plants, with the result that old-man saltbush can produce forage of a quality equivalent to lucerne with only one-third the water usage per unit of dry matter production.

TALK.START.PARA: —Remarkable.

—It is remarkable. Of course, the honourable member for Parkes has much saltbush growing in his electorate. Old-man saltbush is thus an exceptional producer of high quality, high protein forage which is equal to or better than lucerne, with high carbohydrates, high fibre but low fat, which can be fed all the year round to provide for feed gaps occasioned by regular summer drought in southern Australia, regular winter drought in northern Australia, irregular drought anywhere at any time, or regular winter cold on the slopes and tablelands. Except for highly acidic soils with a pH of less than 5.5, it can be grown on any soil type anywhere throughout the whole profile.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a deep-rooting plant with roots up to four metres in depth. Not many plants send their root structures down to four metres. It is thus able to use deep-seated moisture well below the range of most pasture and crop plants and most trees and shrubs. The high salt cell sap enables it to withdraw a percentage of soil moisture to much lower levels than most other plants. In addition, it actually grows better in salt affected soils or in saline waters much above the salinity of sea water. It is hardly believable, but that is the way it is. It thrives on waterlogging, with soil surface under water for six months or more at a time. One of the problems we are facing in the Riverina at the moment is that unexpected rainfalls have flooded pasturelands and destroyed the native vegetation for a number of years to come.

Apparently, old-man saltbush can withstand flooding over a long period. Its high productivity and affinity for saline conditions means that it can be used to reclaim land devastated by salt and restore such lands to extraordinary levels of productivity. An important consideration for farm reconstruction consequent on declining productivity or declining terms of trade is that, in spite of the high cost of establishment, plantations of old-man saltbush are cheaper per additional sheep area than acquiring additional land. Dryland and irrigation salinity pose the greatest threat to Australia's agricultural and pastoral environment and the economic and social fabric of the rural and urban communities in the areas badly affected. Plantations of old-man saltbush provide a means of bringing all forms of salinity under control and of reversing the decline in farm productivity consequent upon increasing salinity on individual farms.

If undertaken on a suitably large scale in both recharge areas-that is, non-acid soil-and discharge areas, plantings of old-man saltbush will provide the means of substantially reducing the flow of saline ground waters into river systems at a small fraction of the cost of large-scale tree planting. Today I received in the mail from the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics a map showing the shallow ground water and salinity of the Murray Basin. To say the least, it concerned me greatly. If old-man saltbush has the qualities that I am sure it possesses, it is time experimental plots were planted in strategic locations all over the Murray Basin area as well as in dry saline affected land. This should be done as a matter of urgency.

Funds should be allocated to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and other Commonwealth agricultural research groups, as well as State agricultural bodies and various universities, to test the qualities of this plant. While the present trend may be towards the planting of trees for environmental purposes, there is no need to remind the House that trees take many years to mature, they are generally not salt tolerant, and they are expensive to plant. In many cases the solution may be a combined tree-saltbush planting exercise that will provide not only a pump for the saline water table but also a renewable agricultural fodder resource.

Let me just reiterate that old-man saltbush is much more than a living haystack drought reserve. It is especially useful for restoring salted and eroded lands to high levels of productivity-to levels better than local native pastures. Except in highly acidic soils, it can be used to lower water tables in salted flats and recharge areas on adjoining slopes; it can be irrigated with saline waters, including bore waters unfit for irrigation or stock watering, or with fresh water on land that needs only rough preparation for irrigation. That is, it does not need the expensive lasering systems that are in common usage today. It needs only two or three irrigations per year and will give better returns from grazing than irrigated pastures or field crops. It is much better for improving farm earning capacity than any other approach, including sown pastures, dryland cropping and acquiring additional land, with all the inherent problems that that entails. If clearing is necessary, old-man saltbush can get the same result on a much smaller cleared area and will minimise the destruction of our native trees. It can be used as a living, all-the-year-round drought forage which does not have to be bought, transported, stored or fed out.

Planting old-man saltbush costs from $600 to $1,000 per hectare, depending on rainfall and irrigation, but the returns quickly recover the cost of planting, especially if the 100 per cent tax deductability is used. I believe that its main use, and the one I am concerned about, is the reclamation of irrigation lands destroyed by salt, using old-man saltbush as a means of restoring such land to a high level of productivity and reducing water table levels.

Old-man saltbush is a deep-rooting species with horizontal surface roots at a depth of one metre to 1 1/2 metres radiating outwards for several metres. Vertical taproots push downwards from these roots to a depth of four metres. It is therefore able to explore enormous volumes of soil to levels much below the root systems of rice, other field crops, pastures, fruit trees and most eucalypts. That is important because we have heard so much about planting eucalypts to overcome the salt water problem. Although the latter are often mooted as having value for reclaiming salted land, they are comparatively shallow rooting and provide no return to the landholder other than shade and shelter.

It is expected that old-man saltbush will be able to thrive on an underground source of saline water and thereby keep water tables at a reasonable level. The obvious site for the project I spoke about before is an irrigation area, perhaps in northern Victoria or southern New South Wales. I believe that the sooner a project such us that is undertaken the sooner we will know just how valuable this plant is to us.

I do not know how many members have travelled into the outback in recent times but I am sure that they have seen the multitude of wild flowers, particularly in the western part of New South Wales and other areas. One point I would like to make about old-man saltbush, particularly if it is trimmed, is that it can have a very attractive appearance. I notice that in a number of areas it is being used as a plant to beautify areas. The Broken Hill airport is a case in point. Around the actual airport facility a lot of saltbush has been planted, making it an attractive addition to the trees already planted there. I have said that I am a fan of old-man saltbush. It is very valuable for reclaiming salinated land, as a means of preventing soil erosion, as a means of providing a very valuable income for the farming community and it is also an attractive plant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the outset I commend the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) for the excellent research that he has put into old-man saltbush. The number of country members from both sides who are in the House to hear the debate about the prevention of soil erosion and soil degradation shows that they are very concerned about that indeed. Many of the problems that I have in my huge electorate of Grey were outlined by the previous speaker. Members of the House might not be aware of the fact that there is no piped water supply in a number of communities in my electorate. Unfortunately, there is no piped water west of Ceduna. Hopefully the State Government in South Australia will cooperate with the Federal Government so that we can soon get a piped water supply to those people west of Ceduna, a facility that some of the people in regional areas and cities take for granted. The honourable member for Riverina-Darling pointed out some of the difficulties that the people whom we represent in country areas and in the bush have to face every day. I think it is very fitting that this was put on the agenda for discussion.

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of Cleve on the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia a number of people, particularly the Jericho family, are doing a tremendous amount of work planting trees to overcome some of the problems of soil degradation and soil erosion. These people have been in this field for a long period. I am sure that members who are concerned about soil degradation and who want to see what can be effected by planned tree growing would be most welcome to look at the Jericho farming area near Cleve to see the outstanding success that these people have had. As the honourable member for Riverina-Darling points out, trees take a long time to grow. If old-man saltbush is as effective as the honourable member has pointed out-I am sure he is correct-then we on this side of the House will certainly be very supportive of that. I will be having discussions with the honourable member shortly to make arrangements to have discussions with the relevant Minister to see whether finances can be made available so that the program which he has outlined can come into effect. It is very important that as we come up to the reality of the fact that there is much desert that can be reclaimed by the growing of old-man saltbush and trees-certainly in my electorate-we undertake a planned program to bring this to fruition. I conclude by saying that the honourable member for Riverina-Darling is to be commended for bringing this important subject before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in the grievance debate today and I would like to reassure the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), as he leaves the chamber, that, far from resenting the intrusion into my grievance debating time, I consider the question of the pilots strike to be so important as to justify precisely the action that the Opposition has taken. I say that, Mr Deputy Speaker, because prior to entering this House I was a resident of a small country town in South Australia known as Waikerie. The town is synonymous with citrus growing and the sport of gliding. It was compulsory, almost, for all residents of the town to learn to fly fixed-wing gliders, just as a part of residency. As a result of that experience, I grew up with a great deal of appreciation of the importance of flying safely. In the days before there was regular radio contact with every glider, it was very important to be sure that all other glider pilots were determined to turn the same way in a thermal as you were turning. I would have thought that the emphasis on air safety that has been given priority in debate this morning by the Opposition, which has attempted to raise this issue time and time again, should be applauded by the community and acknowledged by the Government for the important matter that it is.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that the pilots strike is doing this nation a great deal of economic damage. But I want to use my introductory remarks to the grievance debate to make the even more pertinent point that this same strike is doing extraordinary economic damage to my home State of South Australia. It has been estimated that cab drivers alone in Adelaide are losing $34,000 a day because of the pilots strike; that the Convention Centre is $370,000 down in revenue; that the Hilton and the Hyatt hotels between them have had 4,000 bookings cancelled. As a South Australian I am concerned. Every South Australian in this chamber is concerned, and I would hope that the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, the Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon, is concerned about the possible implications of the pilots strike for South Australia's Grand Prix, which last year brought 15,000 visitors into South Australia by air.

However, I rise today not to lay emphasis on the pilots strike but to draw the attention of the House and the nation to another matter which has been overshadowed by the pilots strike but which is of fundamental importance to every rural Australian in this House, including the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons), who is at the table and who has a rural electorate. That matter is the question of the cessation of live sheep exports. This has been a matter of major concern to every rural Australian but it is a matter which, from a press point of view, has been largely overshadowed by the impact of the pilots strike. The cessation of live sheep exports to Saudi Arabia means that a $100m market has been lost to Australia's primary producers. We should think of the impact of that alone on our balance of payments, already rushing in the wrong direction. A total industry worth $198m-almost $200m-is at risk; has been largely ignored by the press; has not even been aired by the Government this week; and, in fact, it is at risk simply because of unsubstantiated allegations of disease in Australia's livestock.

The history of the dispute is that on 23 July of this year the Mawashi Tabuk entered the port of Jeddah and 80,000 sheep on board were alleged to have been infected by the bluetongue virus. On 31 July that ship was ordered out of port. Four other ships followed the Mawashi Tabuk. They were alleged to have livestock on them infected by bluetongue, sheep pox or some other unspecified disease. Tests were also conducted in the Middle East for brucella melitensis, but this has not yet been cited as a reason for rejection. The point that needs to be made is that brucella melitensis has never been recorded in Australian sheep flocks; neither has bluetongue; neither has sheep pox-those are alleged to have been the diseases that justified these ships being sent out of port and the livestock on them not being received by the Saudi Arabians.

Not surprisingly, there is always someone anxious to make capital out of someone else's misfortune and the animal liberationists and the animal welfare people have been quick to attach their flag to the mast. And I notice that in yesterday's Australian Mr Graeme McEwen, the President of the Australian and New Zealand Federation of Animal Societies, was critical of the whole livestock exporting industry, particularly the live sheep exporting industry.

I have to emphasise that the importance of this industry to rural Australia cannot be overstated. Wethers, the principal part of the live sheep exporting business, play a key role in our balanced approach to agriculture in allowing farmers to have some lay paddocks and enabling them to have a total management structure on their farms. Yet we have seen no real action from the Government in terms of resolving this disastrous dispute. As I said earlier, the value of the live sheep trade in Australia has been estimated at almost $200m and that trade is of particular importance to my own State of South Australia.

I must point out that the Opposition has not been politically motivated in the way in which it has dealt with this live sheep dispute. In fact, to date we have been totally supportive of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin)--

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been very responsible.

—As the honourable member for Dawson says, we have acted in a very responsible way. I do not intend to change that today. Too much is at stake for us to play politics with this industry. We recognise that the absence of the Saudi agricultural Minister, Dr Abdul Al Shaikh, who is overseas-it is presumed he will return some time next week-has made negotiations very difficult. We have not been critical of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and it would be easier to maintain that responsible stance if, on some occasions, it were reciprocated.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, I raise this matter in the grievance debate because I want to highlight the impact of the live sheep export dispute on the Australian economy and more particularly on Australian farmers and on the farmers in the electorate of Wakefield. Summer is coming. With summer will come a shortage of feed and wethers that were being held in anticipation of the opportunity to ship them overseas will have to be destroyed in the paddock. Who will want to buy them as feed shortages increase around Australia?

As if the impact on my farmers were not enough, I have in my own electorate a feed mill, Johnson's Feed Mill at Kapunda, almost totally dedicated to the production of pelletised livestock feed for livestock being exported overseas by ship. It is a problem that I share with the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who also has a major mill in his electorate. Johnson's Feed Mill at Kapunda is in a small South Australian town of 2,700 people, just an hour north of Adelaide-an almost idyllic setting at the northern end of the Barossa Valley. Between 30,000 and 40,000 tonnes of cereal hay is bought by Johnson's every year. It has an annual turnover of something like $12m. It happens to supply most of the feed for all the livestock leaving South Australia; 32 people employed in Kapunda are directly affected by what will happen to Johnson's.

I picked up today's Australian and noticed that the Government proposes to pay $701,735 to help with Ansett's wages bill. I ask the Minister at the table: What does the Government propose to do for those directly affected by its failure to successfully negotiate our way out of the live sheep export dispute? I have people in Kapunda directly affected; the member for O'Connor has people in his electorate directly affected; farmers around Australia are directly affected and the Government needs to take action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am angry, and I am going to stay angry with this Government until we receive some justice for the former prisoners of war who served this nation in a time of peril in the Second World War. The Australians who were taken prisoner of war by the Japanese in Malaya, Singapore, and what was then the Dutch East Indies, suffered as no other group has suffered to defend our nation, our freedom and our democratic way of life. During their captivity, ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese experienced slave labour, starvation, sickening brutality, inhumane treatment and neglect. I want from this Government some justice for these men in the last few eventide years they have left on this planet. I am sick and tired of hearing supercilious sympathy that Ministers in this Government have expressed to me on this issue. I do not want sympathy; I want compassion and I want real compensation for these people.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Government for the crumbs that fell from its table in the recent budget for the former prisoners of war of the Japanese. Some of the benefits stolen from those prisoners of war in the May statement of 1985 and the Budget of 1987 have been restored. For that I am grateful. But crumbs are not enough. The benefits introduced in this year's Budget are estimated by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to cost around $700,000 whilst the Government this year will retain a Budget surplus of at least $9 billion. But the entitlements accorded to these service men and women in the Budget are really not enough. Are they really an attempt to alleviate the hardships and continuing suffering of these men and women?

I raise, once again, my demands for justice and compassion for this special group of Australian people. I am calling for two concessions from this Government. I am calling for the establishment of a special pension which should be called `the former Japanese prisoner-of-war disablement adjustment'. This should be set at 200 per cent of the general rate of veterans' pensions and should compensate for the withdrawal in the previous Budgets of the right of veterans to apply for the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension. The eligibility for this special pension should be assessed in the same way as the TPI pension was assessed. I am also arguing for the right of these former Japanese prisoners of war to end their days in nursing homes free of charge if they so desire. This is a privilege which was made available to all veterans with war disabilities and they were entitled to that prior to the Budget of 1987.

I want to reiterate the substantial medical evidence behind my claims. The facts are stark, yet horrifyingly real. A total of 550,000 Australians served in all theatres of war. Of these, 19,000 were killed in action-that is 3 1/2 per cent. There were 22,000 Australians taken prisoner of war, of whom 14,000 returned to these shores. More than 36 per cent of those imprisoned by the Japanese died in captivity. That is a startling figure. These prisoners of war of the Japanese were regularly exposed to numerous infections, including diphtheria, bacterial dysentery, respiratory infection, tropical ulcers, malaria and various gastro-intestinal infections. As a consequence of this exposure, the incidence of potentially fatal disease amongst ex-prisoners of war, compared with non-prisoners of war, is excessively high.

I state once again just some of the poignant clinical evidence which is the basis of my claim. Beri-beri was contracted by 83 per cent of prisoners of war, but only one per cent of non-prisoners of war. What we call `happy feet'-itchy or painful feet associated with vitamin deficiency-was developed in 49 per cent of ex-prisoners of war, as compared with 4 per cent of non-prisoners of war. Cholera was contracted by 7 per cent of ex-prisoners of war whilst this crippling disease was not found amongst any other servicemen serving in that theatre of war. While a long period has elapsed since the inhumane imprisonment of these men and women, some physical and mental effects, resulting from their suffering during the war years, have only become apparent in recent years.

To this day these former Japanese prisoners of war therefore continue to suffer and die as a direct result of what occurred during those 3 1/2 years of deprivation. From 1945 to 1959 their death rate was four times higher than that of other servicemen. Since then they have been dying at a 20 per cent higher rate. They still suffer more from duodenal ulcers, from psychiatric disorders and from gastric diseases than non-prisoners of war.

What concerns and disturbs me greatly is the attitude of the Department of Veterans' Affairs towards just compensation for these former Japanese prisoners of war. That attitude is difficult to comprehend. The Department clearly acknowledges that these service men and women are a special case. It clearly acknowledges that after their imprisonment by the Japanese in 1942 these people suffered conditions of protracted, intense emotional and physical deprivation. I will quote from the Department of Veterans' Affairs handbook explaining the benefits coming out of the recent Budget that was handed down a few weeks ago. It says:

It is generally accepted by the community that the ex-prisoners of war (Japanese) suffered particular privations during their war service and that these privations have had a lasting effect on their health and on the well being of their families . . . Medical research has shown that the ex-prisoners of war (Japanese) are more likely than other veterans to suffer from a range of particular diseases.

Yet the Department then goes on to all but ignore the continuing plight of these service men and women. The Department will do nothing at all to rock the boat or to upset its outdated dogma. I stress that its dogma is outdated. I will again quote to the House from the briefing paper prepared by the Department of Veterans' Affairs which was sent to the Australian Labor Party Caucus to try to counter my arguments to the committee on community affairs and welfare. It shows the reasons why the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which, more than anyone else, should be supporting the claims for justice for the former Japanese prisoners of war, has become the stumbling block to any real progress on this issue. The briefing paper says this:
The move from the focus on demonstrated need to one of perceived characteristic of a particular group would be to undermine the integrity of the present system.

I stress the words `to undermine'. To give justice to the prisoners of war would undermine the system. Well, it is about time, I think, that the Department had some compassion and started putting some strength behind its recommendations to the Cabinet that those prisoners of war really deserve compensation. This Government must stop being blinded by the hidebound opinions of the top brass of the Returned Services League and the upper echelons of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Both these groups have consistently worked against the interests of ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese. They have accepted both the logic and the vast array of evidence behind my claims, but they have failed to act upon them. If the Department recognises that the former prisoners of war of the Japanese are a special group, why does it not do something about it?

Finally, I will give the details again. Of the 22,000 of our men who left these shores and went to the front line to face the Japanese, 6,500 are left. They are dying at a rate of over 300 a year. More than 2,000 of them are now getting the TPI pension. If 25 per cent of the 4,500 not receiving the TPI applied for this new special pension after a period of three years, it would cost the Government about $5.6m a year. It is politicians and governments who send people to war, so it is about time that this Government faced up to its responsibility and gave compassionate and just compensation to these prisoners of war in the last few eventide years of their lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to raise in the grievance debate the plight of exporters held to ransom by Australia's archaic ports and the monopoly control of those ports by the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and compare the Government's attitude to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) with its attitude to waterfront reform.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Government's attitude towards the AFAP. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wants to smash the Federation and rebuild the aviation industry in Australia from the bottom up. He wants to prevent a wages blow-out, which is commendable in itself, and he wants to win at all costs against the AFAP. The Government and the airlines are working together to break the AFAP. The Federation has committed the sin of working outside the system. The Prime Minister has encouraged the airlines not to negotiate a settlement in this dispute which has gone on for 57 days. The Government has encouraged the strike breaking activity of introducing pilots from overseas. It has encouraged the lockout arrangements where the pilots are not able to work for their airlines. Of course, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), Bill Kelty, does not agree with the Federation's arrangement because it is outside the system and it is outside the guidelines of the ACTU.

Let us compare this with the attitude of the Prime Minister and the Government to the waterfront-a stark contrast to the strong statements made about the pilots. We see the headlines in the Sydney Morning Herald, `Slow motion on the waterfront'. We see in the Australian Financial Review, `Claytons agreement on waterfront reform'. What a change from the headlines we have been reading in recent weeks about the pilots. The main point about the waterfront is the fact that the Government is in a situation where it is negotiating to bring about no change in reality in the conditions on the waterfront.

The Waterfront Industry Reform Authority is a new committee that has been created to look at the in-principle agreement which has three key elements: three years to implement the reforms of the Inter-State Commission report; total union control; and no hard and fast deadlines to achieve these reforms. I would like to draw the House's attention to the background of the Inter-State Commission's report on the waterfront. It appears that a report appears every five to 10 years on the waterfront and this is just another one of a long line of reports. It is a good report and identifies the major problem. All parties agreed that there was a need for change, especially the exporters of grain, coal and wool. The report indicates the ineffective management on the waterfront, the poor work force training and career arrangements, the introspective industrial relations attitudes, poor response to user needs, the under-utilisation of expensive facilities, especially in the bulk grain facilities and the container terminals, and the abuse of monopoly powers, particularly by the union movement. Add to this a litany of problems. The report goes on to identify high costs, endemic unreliability of those surrounding the waterfront, the high level of disputation, the inappropriate manning levels and work practices, poor discipline, poor motivation by the work force and a pervasive lack of competition in the whole waterfront area.

The Government saw itself as having a role by introducing the Inter-State Commission report in the hope of cleaning up the waterfront. The coalition would go along with that. The parties involved-the stevedores, the unions and the shipowners-have always seen short term solutions to any particular problems that have emerged on the waterfront. As long as a ship could be turned around the shipowner, the stevedore or the farmers would pay up and no one would be particularly responsible. The stevedoring industry is at the heart of the problem and the Commission's report had this to say:
At the heart of the Commission's proposed waterfront plan is the modification of the employment arrangements.

Enterprise employment was the thrust of the Inter-State Commission report-that is, that the stevedores should employ their own men and not rely on the pooling arrangements that have been the norm on the waterfront. The competition within the labour market was a point the report identified quite clearly. Page 33 of that report indicates that union monopolies weaken competition within the labour market. How true that is, particularly on the waterfront. Yet on the next page the report says it is unrealistic to have non-union labour on the waterfront, despite the fact that a number of the witnesses brought forward, such as the IDF, said that there ought to be some competition on the waterfront to take away the monopoly power of the Waterside Workers Federation. What a difference between the Government's attitude to union monopoly on the waterfront and the attitude of the Prime Minister to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots.

I wish to draw the House's attention to the historical position on the waterfront. It is a very tough and hard place to work; conditions were poor historically; and the employers themselves were bad and employed the worst kinds of management. Hard physical work was involved and this led to an esprit de corps and a camaraderie amongst those workers in the Waterside Workers Federation. Of course, this led to a monopoly position which has been exploited both politically and commercially by the Waterside Workers Federation. This in turn led to a stranglehold both on Australia's exports and on those companies which wanted to import goods to Australia.

Historically, we saw the notorious bull pen in Sydney and other ports around Australia where men who were selected from the pool of labour to work on a particular day developed a set of industrial attitudes from that time which have not helped. The Waterside Workers Federation has been a well led union, with some very good leaders. The workers pay high union dues and boast a 95 per cent union turnout for election ballots, unlike other unions around Australia. Of course, some fundamental changes have taken place on the waterfront. Containerisation of goods, which took place around the world, made a major impact here in Australia and the bulk handling of commodities such as grain and coal changed a number of the requirements of the waterfront. Fewer men were required and a reduction of the numbers took place. But the monopoly position of the Waterside Workers Federation remained. With new technology old attitudes remained in place.

The Government is reluctantly addressing the change and the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, yet another committee, has put out an in-principle agreement-38 pages of procrastination. Tas Bull himself is on the record as saying that the Waterside Workers Federation will negotiate through yet another committee to maintain the status quo. The key features of the in-principle agreement are that it will take three years to complete and there will be union control of negotiations and no hiring or firing by the employers. Even the name of the in-principle agreement suggests a backing off from these key issues. The major agreement is that the parties have each acknowledged and accepted the need for fundamental, structural and attitudinal change in the waterfront industry. The question is whether there will be the will to implement the changes.

The parties to these agreements are the ACTU and 10 unions and, on the employers' side, the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour along with some joint venture stevedores in some of the smaller ports. There will be progressive implementation. What a wonderful terminology that is-allowing Tas Bull and the Waterside Workers Federation to go slow in implementing some of these changes. There will be negotiation between employers and unions for enterprise agreements. Paragraph 5.1 stipulates three years for the agreement to come into operation. The early retirements in the document indicate a reduced number of personnel on the waterfront by a net 2,000 men and a rejuvenation of the work force by introducing 1,000 new personnel who are under the age of 50. The interesting point about these requirements is that those who receive early retirement have to be members of the union. The recruitment makes no adjustment for a change in attitude by the new waterside workers who might come and work in that arena. The compulsory redundancy ensures that those new men employed will maintain that monopoly position where they cannot be fired and redundancy will be a last resort. The port transitional lists is another name for the old pooling arrangements.

Waterfront reform is slow, it is union dominated and it is strangling the export industries in their endeavours to export products around the world. The Labor Government and the Prime Minister are keen to smash the Australian Federation of Air Pilots but the Hawke Government and the Australian Labor Party are applying intensive care surgery to maintain life in the ailing Waterside Workers Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to draw the attention of the House and, indeed, of those listening to this debate to a very important issue in my electorate, namely, the future of the land known as Glenthorne, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) land at the corner of Main South Road and Majors Road on O'Halloran Hill. There have been some suggestions that this land might be used for housing, something which I have been resisting and which I believe will now not occur as a result of some developments on that line.

SPEECH.PARA: I first want to mention the history of this beautiful property. It was land taken up by Major O'Halloran very early in the history of South Australia. Major O'Halloran arrived in Australia on 15 November 1838 on the Rajastan, very shortly after the date of proclamation of South Australia, and moved to O'Halloran Hill in January 1839. He brought with him a prefabricated wooden house which he called Lizard Lodge because he was descended from a proud old Irish clan, an early chieftain of which was saved from the enemies by a lizard crawling on his face. That was why the house was first called Lizard Lodge and now, of course, it is known as Glenthorne. He built a stone house there and there was a stone coach house built also in April 1839 which had a couple of shot holes so that people could protect themselves from the Aboriginals who were there at that time. Major O'Halloran became a very famous figure in the history of South Australia. He was a member of the first elected Legislative Assembly in 1857 and he was the first chairman of what became the Marion District Council. He was a prominent churchman and when he died at the ripe old age of 73 he was buried in the Christ Church cemetery on O'Halloran Hill in 1870.

That is the history of this property. It was acquired by the Commonwealth in 1913 as a remount centre and during World War I it served for training horses, mainly for shipment to India. I am told that it was also used for that purpose during the Boer War and it was also used as a remount centre during the Second World War. In fact, a constituent of mine, Mr Col Riley of Morphett Vale, who was stationed there in the Second World War tells me that in 1941 there were about 1,200 troops based there. I am sure that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons), who is at the table, will be interested in that. There were 2,000 or 3,000 horses there; it was the headquarters of the 8th Auxiliary Horse Transport Company and the 3rd Australian Remount Company. We forget that in those days horses were used-very largely to save petrol-to deliver supplies and ordnance. One particular use was to carry wood for cooking, which was much used during the war. Heavy Clydesdales were used to move guns around, timber and so on and the hack horses that were bred there were used for officers to ride around on. Mr Riley tells me that his grandfather who went to the Boer War got his horse from there in 1899, just as many others did later.

The place is absolutely beautiful and has been well looked after and well restored. The CSIRO leases two-thirds of the property-the whole property is 220 hectares-to the Waite Institute in South Australia and it is farmed in an ecologically sensitive and environmentally productive way with contour ploughing and so forth. In my opinion, it would be an absolute tragedy if this part of the landscape of the southern suburbs of Adelaide were to be sold off for housing. I am very pleased to say that I believe that as a result of efforts that have been made, that will not happen. Many people in the south have actually moved to that area because of the large areas of open space which once existed and to some extent still exist. The vineyards are being sold off and cut up for housing and the beaches are being increasingly encroached upon, so I believe it is very important that we preserve this area for the future.

I had the very great privilege of walking and driving around the Glenthorne property three or four weeks ago. Mr Blair Cowan, the manager of the farm, took me around and it was quite beautiful, in the midst of suburbs, to find a dam where ducks were nesting and to look at the spring lambs which are now there. That kind of pleasure can be available for everybody. Not many people are fortunate enough to live in an urban environment in which they can go past an area such as this as part of their daily life. Glenthorne helps to provide that opportunity, and I believe that it should be left either as it is, or possibly developed in the future, revegetated as a native flora and fauna park or possibly used as a demonstration farm promoting environmentally sensitive farming practices, as happens now. If we think that there is pressure on open space now, we should ask, for goodness sake, what will it be like in 20 years time.

I undertook a survey of opinion in my electorate about the future of this property when a proposal was put forward a couple of months ago when a developer expressed interest in buying this land. The response was simply astonishing. I sent out a questionnaire and people simply had to answer the question-`yes, I am happy for Glenthorne to be sold off and cut up for housing' or `no, I do not want Glenthorne sold off for housing, it should be left as it is with the option for future non-housing use'. I have had more than 5,000 responses to that questionnaire. Of those, 18 responses were in favour of cutting up the place for housing and the remainder were in favour of leaving it as I had suggested, or developing it in an open space way for various purposes. I would just like to quote from several of the letters that accompanied the questionnaires. One said:

It is rare in cities to still have that amount of land still as open paddocks so close to the business centre and it is certainly worth preserving. It is lovely to see the lambs in spring and the native birds during the summer feeding while traffic roars up and down the South Road. It gives the area a rural touch while still allowing us the benefits of suburban living. The possibility of this land becoming a park or a sanctuary is great and is certainly something which I would support.
That is one letter. Here is another:

The Glenthorne countryside is the only green belt break between the city and the suburbs in the south. We feel that if the CSIRO want to give up the land it should be developed as a native flora and fauna park, incorporating a demonstration farm in ecological farming practices, so that the younger generation can enjoy the future, and people can learn and experience the beauty of nature.
Here is another extract from a letter:

I have lived in the South for 29 years, nearly all my life, I am 31. (Port Noarlunga, O'Halloran Hill and now Hackam). I have two young children, one 20 months and one eight weeks old, and I would like them to see the sheep and especially the baby lambs like I did every time we travelled the South Road. I wish you success with this one.
Here is another one:

My wife and I purchased our home in Trott Park because of the views looking over these beautiful paddocks with a rural setting for our retirement. . . It is a coincidence receiving your letter. This past week I spoke to a gentleman at the ``farm'' about how much we enjoyed the sheep and lambs in the paddocks directly behind us. My wife and I do care about this beautiful land. Thank you for caring.
And so on and so forth. I will not quote all of these because there are so many of them, and they all express the same sorts of views.

Bolstered by this expression of opinion I wrote to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) again-I had first written to him on this matter months ago, and had spoken to him-and in my letter of 18 September I said:
I firmly believe that if discussions-
to which he refers in earlier letters-
are to continue, the option of a wholesale sell-off of Glenthorne for residential housing development should be ruled out from the very start.

I am pleased to say that I have had further discussions with the Minister today. I have received a very encouraging response and with the cooperation of the State Government-which I have to acknowledge has also taken the attitude all along that this Commonwealth land should not be sold for that purpose, and which does have zoning responsibility for it-I anticipate very shortly the kind of outcome which will please everybody in the south, with a very few exceptions. This will enable the preservation of a kind of lifestyle in that part of the world which, I am sure, will be popular there and of which I am very proud to have been part of achieving. In short, it looks as though Glenthorne will be saved for the future; will be saved for our children; and the value of that will be more and more appreciated as time goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disturbed and disappointed with the Australian Government's blind, uncritical and almost fawning support for an overseas terrorist organisation that has committed, and indeed is continuing to commit, horrific atrocities against several hundred members of the human race. I refer to the South West Africa People's Organisation (SWAPO), a communist-backed terrorist group, which has been trying to win control of Namibia, mainly through violent means. It is structured along undemocratic lines, with bases in Angola and other countries, such as Zambia.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of SWAPO can be traced back to the 1950s and it has been led for most of its existence by a Mr Sam Nujoma. It has trained many of its recruits in Algeria, Tanzania, China and the Soviet Union. In 1966, after the International Court of Justice threw out the challenge from Liberia and Ethiopia that South Africa should not be in Namibia, or South West Africa as it was called at the time, SWAPO declared from Dar-es-Salaam that it no longer had any alternative `but to rise in arms to bring about our liberation'. Armed clashes between SWAPO and both security forces and Owambo chiefs in the north of the country followed soon after. The Soviets increasingly financed SWAPO's operations in return for SWAPO more and more closely following the USSR's ideological line. In 1976, when Shipanga challenged Nujoma's leadership of SWAPO, he and 1,000 of his followers were thrown into detention and a new SWAPO program was drawn up, based on Marxist-Leninist principles. Fortunately, Shipanga was released in 1978, after pressure from such groups as the International Red Cross.

A brief history of Namibia is, perhaps, relevant here: it is a country about the size of New South Wales, and 62 per cent of its population of 1 1/4 million live in the north. It is dry, often barren country; it is inhabited by 11 ethnic groups and 11 different languages are spoken. It is Africa's fourth largest mineral producer and is especially rich in gem quality diamonds, uranium and some gold. It has good potential in tourism with its game parks in particular, and in fishing. However, I note that the Eastern bloc countries are exploiting its territorial waters with no payment. It has a very good infrastructure due to South Africa having pumped in billions of rand over the years. I am referring to its roads, its rail network, its excellent international airport, particularly by African standards, its top class hotels and its telephone network.

Namibia was in German hands from the 1880s until South Africa took over in 1915, in World War I, in a similar way to that in which Australia took over control of Papua New Guinea. South Africa reported regularly to the League of Nations Mandates Commission about this country until the League was disbanded in 1946. After a continuing verbal skirmish between South Africa and the United Nations as to who should have control of Namibia and when and how independence of that nation should take place, agreement was all but reached on this matter in 1978 for independence to go ahead immediately. Regrettably, civil war flared up in neighbouring Angola to the north between the MPLA and UNITA and this conflict became a testing ground for superpower rivalries. For example, several tens of thousands of Cuban troops poured into Angola to act as Soviet surrogates there.

In addition, SWAPO, with what amounted to encouragement from the United Nations, set up bases in Angola from which to launch terrorist attacks into Namibia. South Africa was forced to make incursions into Angola against some of the SWAPO bases, although it is to be stressed not against the Angolan or Cuban forces there. When agreement was finally reached last year on withdrawal of Cuban forces and moves towards peace in Angola, the independence of Namibia again became an imminent possibility. Unfortunately the Angolan conflict had delayed Namibia's independence by more than a decade.

However, it is now possible for United Nations resolution 435 of September 1978, relating to Namibia's independence, to go ahead. Under the present agreement SWAPO forces agreed to remain north of the sixteenth parallel and United Nations peacekeeping forces, including Australian troops, would monitor the transition phase to an internationally supervised free and fair general election in November this year. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It will be a proportional representation election and a two-thirds majority will be needed to rule. Despite all the hype from the Socialist Left around the world, including Australia, considerable opposition is growing against SWAPO in Namibia and there are doubts as to whether it will even get its necessary majority, let alone the clean sweep that it has been expected to obtain. This is despite its having the enormous advantage of being an Owambo-based organisation which is as large as all the other ethnic groups combined.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for SWAPO's growing un- popularity are three-fold. Firstly, no sooner had their leader, Sam Nujoma, given his absolute guarantee in writing that SWAPO would scrupulously observe the cease-fire and avoid all violence from 1 April this year than heavily armed SWAPO troops made numerous incursions into Namibia. This was an abominable act calculated to take advantage of the cease-fire and is well documented. Secondly, SWAPO misappropriated United Nations funds, including Australian funds, by accepting aid to look after a stated 69,000 refugees when only 35,000 were present. This excess money should be handed back after United Nations inquiry into this fraudulent exercise. Thirdly, and most importantly, horrific accounts are now coming through from refugees who are returning of appalling maltreatments of political prisoners and refugees by SWAPO. Some 1,400 prisoners are still believed to be held by this organisation. Over the last 13 years there have been certainly several hundred, if perhaps not thousands, of victims. They have usually been arrested; accused of being South African spies on trumped up charges; beaten for hours with clubs and radio antenna wire; they have been dropped into seven-metre deep hot, dank, stinking mud pits and incarcerated there for years.
I quote the case of one woman, mentioned by John Carlin in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald article of 19 September. She is a 24-year-old woman, Elizabeth Simasiku. She was eight years--

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Archbishop David Penman-Dividend Imputation System-Charles Joseph La Trobe-Community Pharmacists-Regreening of Australia: Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers-Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education-Queensland Government-Live Sheep Exports

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my 90 seconds today, I wish to record my profound respect and affection for the late Archbishop David Penman. Australia has lost one of its most important leaders at the young age of 53 years. He was not only respected throughout the world as a church leader, but also was loved as the friend of millions.

SPEECH.PARA: David Penman was as wonderful a human being as any of us is likely to meet. He strove for human rights, justice, tolerance and love throughout the world. He built bridges between people of different colours and creeds and is loved in countries as diverse as Iran, Lebanon, Pakistan, Ethiopia and South Africa. He loved his native New Zealand and his adopted Australia and followed our sports with the passion he brought to a range of issues such as poverty, labour relations, multiculturalism, a free media, understanding Islam, and women priests. David's great self-deprecating humour led to his having, probably, the biggest collection of ornamental wombats in the world. My wife, Julie, and son, Scobie, join me in sending love to his widow, Jean, and their children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw to the attention of the House problems with the dividend imputation system, introduced on 1 July 1987. A number of constituents in my electorate have found to their disgust that the dividend imputation system has discriminatory consequences for low income earners, such as pensioners and retirees, who are trying to increase their income by investing in companies with franked dividends.

SPEECH.PARA: The system was introduced to overcome the previous harsh double taxation on dividends. Under the old system tax was imposed on the profit of companies twice-firstly, by taxing the profits of the company itself and, secondly, by taxing the dividends received by shareholders. Now, when an investor receives a franked dividend, however, he receives a credit for the tax already paid by the company and, effectively tax free, these imputed or franked dividends are very attractive to investors.

The trap for unwary players, however, is that the shareholder is only entitled to a rebate, or a reduction in tax liability, equal to the amount of his imputation credit. Unfortunately, this means that while many low income earners, pensioners and others, were attracted as investors to companies with franked dividends, they have not been able to reap the full benefit. For example, assuming a pensioner receives a total dividend of $1,000 from his share portfolio, 49 per cent of this will be paid by the company in tax. The pensioner, or a shareholder, will then be left with 51 per cent, or $510. While he or she will have to disclose and pay tax on the full $1,000, that person can claim a credit for the tax already paid by the company up to the amount of their tax payable. But the problem arises where the shareholder is only liable to $400 tax; he can only claim this and he loses the benefit of the extra $90. Because of the nature of their small tax liability it means that, in the main, pensioners and low income earners are discriminated against. If they had higher incomes, they could offset more of the tax already paid by the company. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) should introduce legislation to prevent this trap from catching low income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity today to point out to the House that the Federal seat of La Trobe was named after Charles Joseph La Trobe, who was a previous Victorian Governor. People often get confused and think that the seat was named after La Trobe University, or La Trobe Valley, but of course that is not the case. However, it is the case that on 3 September 1839 Governor La Trobe arrived as the Superintendent of the Port Phillip district. This week there was a gathering of his family, his descendants in Victoria, at his cottage. They were there to commemorate the 150th anniversary of his arrival in Melbourne. The occasion was marked by the planting of a 150th anniversary tree. As the member whose electorate is named after Charles Joseph La Trobe, I thought it most appropriate to point out this matter to the House and, indeed, to wish the family of Governor La Trobe well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with a great deal of pleasure to use my 90 seconds to speak on behalf of three groups in Australia: the pharmacists, the pharmacy assistants, and the people they serve-the ordinary Australians who depend on the friendly family chemist. I think it is fair to point out that something like 20,000 pharmacy assistants are under threat from the present situation where the chemist dispensing fees are being reduced by 23 per cent. But I am most concerned about the ordinary citizens of Australia who are concerned and do care about the situation and the future of the pharmacists.

SPEECH.PARA: I have here some 5,000 letters from my constituents to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) asking him to do something personally. At the appropriate time, as soon as my speaking time is expired, I will ask the very friendly, very kindly Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons), who is at the table, whether I can give him a couple of plastic bags full of letters to deliver personally to the Prime Minister with my compliments-and his compliments. This issue is of vital importance to every person in Australia. I will have another 5,000 letters coming early next week and I will deliver those personally to the Prime Minister as well. This makes the point that the people of Australia are deeply concerned when they are prepared to sit down, write letters and put them in envelopes. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last month I was pleased to be part of a ceremony celebrating the planting of the one millionth tree by the Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers (ATCV). The tree itself was planted by celebrated conservationist and artist Clifton Pugh. The next tree representing the start of the second million trees, was planted by noted broadcasting gardener and conservationist Kevin Heinz, a resident of Montrose in my electorate of Streeton.

SPEECH.PARA: With the efforts like this by the ATCV, the objective announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to plant one billion trees by the year 2000 becomes more than a possibility. A properly constructed program can make the regreening of Australia a fact. Australia has fragile soils, limited water and a rising water table, along with increased salinity. Our past deforestation has contributed to this deterioration of the Australian environment and to the greenhouse effect. The solution demands a vast reafforestation program, as outlined by the Prime Minister.

The program need not be expensive. According to Rural Trees Australia Ltd, the use of the rapidly developing technology of direct seeding would mean Australia's 150,000 professional farmers could plant two billion trees, committing on average no more than 13.5 hectares of their land, at an average cost of $1,350. Urban dwellers could also `reforest' the suburbs in private gardens and public parklands. The ATCV has set the example of direct tree planting. Its slogan `the working environmentalist' is truly earned. I congratulate the movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of the clear-cut statement made by officers of the Civil Aviation Authority that during the pilots dispute `new standards were set by political blackmail'; that the CAA has granted concessions for purely political reasons against long-standing requirements; and that the Minister's own office was utilised to bring pressure to bear to expedite approvals? —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of comments made by Mr Ian Webber, chairman of the employee relations committee of the Business Council of Australia (BCA), in the Australian this morning, which criticise the focus of award restructuring on the manufacturing sector? Further, has the Minister seen the BCA publication, launched today, on enterprise-based bargaining units?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's question goes to probably the most important issue that is before us today-that of improving productivity and restructuring our industries to make them internationally competitive. I have seen briefly the report that the honourable member has referred to. I have not had an opportunity to go through it in detail but I understand the views put by Mr Webber. They are somewhat in contradiction with the viewpoint of the BCA President, but I will come to that in a moment. It is quite natural that award restructuring should focus in the early stages upon manufacturing, particularly the metal trades industry. It is in manufacturing that we have the fastest growth in activity in world trade, and we need, more than anything else, to improve our performance in that area. Similarly, the metal industry award is a key award in the whole wage-setting process.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said, it is quite natural that the metal trades industry should figure very prominently very early in the award restructuring process. That point was also made, as I mentioned, by the BCA President, Dean Wills, in a recent letter to the Prime Minister in which he emphasised the need for improvement in the metal trades industry.
The award restructuring will be what the industry and managers make it. The mechanism--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is determined not to understand what award restructuring is about. To do everything possible to block the improvement that is coming, on the other side they mouth these platitudes about productivity. Productivity begins with improving arrangements in the workplace and with award restructuring. It is something that this Government is determined to do. Members of the Opposition can stay on the wayside by themselves, but if they have any concern about our country at all they should not get in the way of the process. Industry wants it. The process is not helped when the shadow Minister for industrial relations gets up on his high horse and criticises industry leaders and business for their support of the accord, of stability and of restraint in wage cost growth. Members of the Opposition should get off the tram, get out of the way and cease being an obstruction.

ANSWER.PARA: Progress in award restructuring will be that which managers initiate. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission in its recent decision has set the mechanisms in place for progress to be made. But nothing will move unless managers move. If there is benign and sloppy management and if we have sloths in industry, progress will not be made. The work force will participate. The trade union movement is leading in this process and the Government is giving support to it. But industry itself and industry managers must initiate processes in their own workplaces.

The report to which the honourable member referred also mentioned-and I know that this is a matter in which she has had a direct personal interest-the reduction in the number of unions. In this country we are going through the most radical restructuring of our industries ever attempted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fewer unions.

—Exactly. But there is something positive about it. We cannot afford the proliferation of unions that we have and engage in the restructuring that is under way. We on this side of the House are doing something in a positive way-not in the sniping, sneering way of members of the Opposition, making cracks all the time, putting the trade union movement down.
—Order!

—The Opposition is trying to block exchange between industry, management and the trade union movement. We are encouraging the process. We have to move towards a position where there are far fewer unions, which need to be industry unions. This Government is providing support and making available on a case by case basis financial assistance for the amalgamation of unions. Those amalgamations must be towards an industry union and they must be amalgamations that will substantially assist the process of award restructuring. The same initiative was pooh-poohed by those who sit opposite at the last time of sitting. This Government is right behind it. We will continue on it. The Opposition's industrial relations policy is irrelevant, as is its whole approach to this issue.

—Following the answer the Minister for Transport and Communications gave to the honourable member for Fadden, how does the Minister equate his advice to the House yesterday that `the Government was not involved in the process' of licensing foreign pilots with the memo from the Acting General Manager of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), Mr Lewino, which states that Ansett Airlines of Australia relief check captain, Captain Smith, threatened him `with going over his head' and that subsequently contact was made by Captain Smith and the General Manager of Ansett `via Minister Willis's office'? —My question concerns the arrangements the Reserve Bank of Australia has with banks on non-callable deposits. Is the Treasurer aware that a complaint has been made to the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) regarding the change to the Reserve Bank non-callable deposit arrangements with the banks? TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the fact that the honourable member for Ryan has today formally complained to the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) and requested it to inquire into last week's deal between me, as he put it, the Reserve Bank and the big four banks. ANSWER.PARA: To date, there has been no formal complaint to the Commission. Today I've changed that.

He said that price fixing arrangements were illegal. He went on to say that the bank's role was `to pave the way for the banks to lock interest rates in at the same level'. He went on then to make the following outrageous claim:
Mr Moore said all banking consumers were potentially disadvantaged because the competitive edge has been removed-

as if the Liberal Party ever worried about competitive edges in banking! The fact is that this is the first appearance by the honourable member for Ryan since his Four Corners appearance. The extent of his first appearance on behalf of the Liberal Party was to formally complain about the holding of interest rates at 17 per cent. TALK.START.PARA: —You are the high interest lot.
—You have made a major political mistake, brother, and you are not getting off the hook. The honourable member for Ryan stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Their role was to pave the way for the banks to lock interest rates in at the same level.

This is what he is complaining about-an arrangement which has the trading banks of this country indicating that they need not lift housing interest rates beyond 17 per cent. The honourable member for Ryan has taken, on behalf of the Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! the honourable member for Ryan can ask a question if he wants to.

—He has actually made a formal complaint and invited the Trade Practices Commission to investigate the arrangement. Then he makes the point that the Crown shield does not apply to the four banks and therefore he is suggesting that the four banks--
—It does.
—The honourable member states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government and the Reserve Bank are both protected by Crown shield-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is quite right.

—Right. So the honourable member is trying to get the banks to arrange with the TPC to unlock an arrangement which leaves interest rates at 17 per cent. That is what he is about. He has finally shown his hand. He has been in here for months trailing his coat on interest rates, and now he has made this step to actually try to increase them to 18 per cent by trying to nullify the set of arrangements concluded between the banks and the Government last week. The only implication of what he has done is to say that the four banks are not immune from the Trade Practices Act, and this agreement must be thoroughly examined.
—It is your policy.
—I warn the honourable member for Ryan.
—This is an important matter. The honourable member has taken a major step to raise housing loan interest rates and--
—Order!
—Professor Baxt is reported in today's newspaper as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, we don't have any evidence of collusion or an agreement. Secondly, the basis of the action is to try to keep interest rates down and that would seem to have a benefit to the public at large.

Dead right, Professor Baxt. Here is the Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission saying that there was no evidence of collusion, and then he goes on to say that the basis of the action is to hold interest rates down. The honourable member for Ryan is challenging that arrangement. He is saying to him, `Investigate the arrangement', because he wants interest rates to rise. Need I say that if, in fact, the basis of the honourable member's claim to Professor Baxt were to be upheld, then the same arrangement which holds interest rates at 13 1/2 per cent for pre-1986 borrowers would also be invalid. So arrangements which the Government makes under monetary policy in relation to housing interest rates in the past under regulations which were established under previous Liberal governments, and which obtained when this Government came to office, are ultra vires the Trade Practices Act, then so would be the 13 1/2 per cent. The Federal Opposition would carry the odium of lifting the pre-1986 mortgage interest rate from 13 1/2 per cent-the honourable member for Flinders will not be smiling very much when he gets the rest of this; it will take the smile off his kisser-to a market rate and the existing mortgage interest rate rising from 17 to 18 per cent. That is what they are complaining about. Yesterday--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we get some silence around here?
—Order! By continuing to interject, all members do is take up the time of Question Time.

—Yesterday the honourable member for Wentworth put out a high-handed statement saying that `arrangements between the Crown, in this case the Reserve Bank . . . are immune . . .' He said, `I am advised that . . . is totally wrong . . .' A reasonably alert journalist said, `Who advised you?'. Do honourable members know what he said?-`Neil Brown'. Then today the honourable member for Ryan contradicts the honourable member for Wentworth and Mr Brown by saying that the Commonwealth Government and the Reserve Bank are both protected by the Crown shield. The honourable member for Ryan is totally up-ending the view put by the honourable member for Wentworth. Those opposite have really got their act together over there, have they not? But the big step taken by the Liberal Party of Australia was to formally seek to unwind an arrangement that is holding housing interest rates at 17 per cent. Were the action of the honourable member for Ryan to succeed, the only effect would be to lift interest rates to 18 per cent. The Opposition will carry the odium for this move whether it succeeds or not, and it will not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask: Is it a fact that the check captain responsible for endorsing foreign pilots, Captain Smith, was an Ansett Airlines of Australia employee and approved by Mr Radnedge, who was not an employee of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) but was in fact an employee of East West Airlines Ltd, and, therefore, to quote a Department memo, `There was no way Radnedge could have afforded to fail Smith on that check'? Is it further a fact that according to the CAA Acting General Manager, Safety, in Western Australia, Mr Scaife, Captain Smith had `a known history for deliberately breaking rules'? Do these facts support the Minister's claim yesterday that normal procedures were used by the CAA to check pilots' competence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, the document on which the honourable member for Hume is relying is a document which was addressed to Mr Freeland, the Chief Executive of the Civil Aviation Authority, from his Acting General Manager in the Victoria-Tasmania Division of the Authority. It was dated 28 September. The first that Mr Freeland knew about this document was when he got phone calls from the press yesterday asking him questions about it. It was in the hands of the press before it was in the hands of Mr Freeland; in fact, he still has not received the original. I mention that as background because this document, which was obviously leaked by someone to the newspapers, on the face of it was prepared for the Chief Executive but one wonders exactly for whom it was prepared. The reality is, as I said yesterday, that the normal procedure was for pilots to be authorised by check captains of the airlines or by examiners employed by the Civil Aviation Authority. That was the normal procedure, and that is the procedure that has been used.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the use of Captain Radnedge is concerned, it is a fact that Captain Radnedge was the Civil Aviation Authority's examiner of airmen in Western Australia. He had been employed by East West Airlines and, in the absence of the Civil Aviation Authority having an examiner of airmen in Western Australia, Captain Radnedge was loaned back to the Civil Aviation Authority for one day and in that capacity as consultant performed the licence approval. Of course, until a few days before, he had been the examiner of airmen. If Opposition members want to suggest that he was not qualified to do that, that is a ridiculous assertion. The man had been the Civil Aviation Authority's examiner of airmen in Western Australia for some time and was obviously qualified to conduct the tests. In any case, he approved Captain Smith, who went on to become the check captain for Ansett Western Australia. Captain Smith trained the French pilots, who were subsequently authorised and licensed to operate flights in Australia. They were approved by BAe captains, who are check captains and conduct this kind of activity around the world, and also subsequently by Ansett's own check captain. There can be no suggestion that Captain Smith was not qualified to train to undertake the task for which he was approved by Captain Radnedge, so the whole point of the question disappears.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to claims published in some South Australian newspapers about the possible impact on Port Lincoln of a moratorium on southern bluefin tuna fishing? Why is the Government seeking such a moratorium and what is the attitude of people in the tuna industry to the proposal? Will the Minister ensure that the relevant department makes direct contact with the people involved in the southern bluefin tuna industry in Port Lincoln so that they may have an input to any decisions made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Grey for his question and particularly for the moderate manner in which he has raised it, which was different from when he raised the matter privately. It may be helpful to honourable members if I answer the second part of the question first, which concerns the background to the problem.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1988, at the conclusion of a scientific meeting between Australia, New Zealand and Japan, scientists from those countries put a recommendation to the trilateral management group that the only safe catch level for bluefin tuna would be zero. The report went on to say that if managers feel that other considerations prevent an immediate reduction of this magnitude, the unanimous feeling of the scientists was that the immediate reduction should be at least half of the current catches.
