The quota cuts which were effected last year as a result of the advice reduced catch levels to nearly half the previous year's level. These cuts were seen as a first step towards achieving the necessary stock recovery. I should say that the industry accepted those cuts in a most responsible manner. No doubt these reductions caused difficulties across all major sectors of the fishery in southern Australia, which is the concern of the honourable member for Grey and particularly his constituents in Port Lincoln. There has also been an adverse effect in Western Australia, Japan and New Zealand.

Population analysis by Australian scientists during the last 12 months has shown that there is no improvement in parental biomass as far as the fish are concerned, leading Australian scientists to continue their recommendation at this year's trilateral meeting. Acting on that information, the Government has decided to press for a global moratorium on the taking of southern bluefin tuna. New Zealand is supporting Australia's call for the zero catch level, which was the original recommendation. The Australian Government has never countenanced a unilateral moratorium. That would make no sense for the interests of either the Australian industry or the fish stock, which is the concern of the scientists.

However, the Government believes that without a drastic catch reduction there is a very real possibility that the industry will suffer a complete collapse. The purpose of pressing for a moratorium this year is to allow a recovery of southern bluefin tuna stocks. It is important to prevent parent stock declining to a point from which it cannot recover. If this is not achieved and there is a stock collapse the Australian industry, which is valued at about $45m-the figure referred to in the press report that has been drawn to my attention-would become zero for many years. At least a moratorium would give a chance of stock recovery. Only if the stocks are allowed to recover can a profitable tuna industry exist in the long term. That, of course, would benefit both tuna fishers and Australia as a whole.

Briefly turning to the first part of the question, the Government is aware that any decision regarding this fishery will have an impact on Port Lincoln as the bulk of the southern bluefin tuna fishery is located there. The Government is concerned at the industry's lack of support for that moratorium. It places Australia in a very difficult negotiating position when the industry takes an opposing view to that which the Government is putting. Of course, the Government recognises that in the short term a moratorium will cause hardship among southern bluefin tuna fishers, but the stage has been reached where tough decisions are needed if the fishery is to be saved from commercial and possible biological extinction, because that is what we are facing. The Government is not afraid to take those decisions for the long term benefit of the industry. The negotiations on the southern bluefin tuna quotas will recommence in Canberra on 8 October. I am not in a position at this stage, of course, to foreshadow the outcome of those discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—This may not be of particular interest to the honourable member but it is of some interest to the honourable member for Grey and people who are interested in agriculture in this country. The third part of the question related to representatives of the Australian Fisheries Service and whether they would go to Port Lincoln and other ports involved in the southern bluefin tuna fishery industry to explain whatever decision is made in relation to the quota levels for 1989-90. That will be attended to.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact, as alleged by Mr Lewino in his statement of 28 September, that all the French BAe146 pilots examined by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) gave exactly the same answer to virtually every question, including those that they got wrong?

—I understand that at some stage there was concern by the CAA that there could have been some collusion in relation to the tests conducted for the French pilots because there was apparent commonality in some of the errors that the pilots made in the answers they gave. In subsequent examination by the CAA as to why that had occurred, it became clear that it was mainly because the instructors who were assisting them to prepare for the examination had given them advice which was not correct. Therefore, they obviously gave the wrong answers.

—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of any progress being made towards meeting the objectives of the Government's science and technology statement earlier this year, and, in particular, of any progress being made with the Prime Minister's Science Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward very much to chairing the first meeting of the Prime Minister's Science Council in Canberra tomorrow. I think the honourable member would agree that this is an important step which reflects and will promote growing national recognition of the political, economic and social impact of science and technology on this country. For the first time a national forum will be convened at the highest level. It will consist of senior Ministers, the leaders of Australian science, business interests-including large and newly emerging businesses and industries-and also trade union representatives. The establishment of the Prime Minister's Science Council was announced in the May statement Science and Technology for Australia, and for the information of the House I table a document showing the membership of the Council. Another part of the machinery that we have established since May to raise the role and the profile of science is a coordination committee on science and technology which is now operating to share information on research activities spread across a range of Commonwealth departments. This is obviously a highly desirable innovation.

ANSWER.PARA: The two main items for tomorrow's initial meeting of the Prime Minister's Science Council will, I imagine, be of interest to the honourable member and the House generally. First, in the morning session there will be consideration of the adequacy of the national response to climate change, especially the greenhouse effect. The second major item the Council will consider will be Australia's core capacity in science and technology and our ability to respond to a uniquely rapid period of change internationally. So the honourable gentleman can see that the Science Council is in no sense merely an academic exercise. On the contrary, it is designed to help us as a nation to address at the highest possible level current concrete issues of significance and to encourage an enhanced role for science and technology in Australian society and the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Flinders will cease interjecting.

—I can also say that the Council will be joined for each discussion by relevant scientists and business people familiar with the particular issues to be considered by the Council, some of whom have been invited to present papers to the Council. The papers on these important subjects will be published after the meeting. In conclusion, I am confident that the Prime Minister's Science Council will play an important role in raising Australia's capacity and understanding in science and technology. Not only the Government but also the House as a whole and the nation should be indebted to those distinguished representatives who have indicated their preparedness to join us and work with us on the Council for the benefit of this country's interests.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to advice forwarded by the Australian Flight Attendants Association (AFAA) to his colleague the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support concerning a Liberian registered and Irish operated Boeing 707 aircraft. Does this advice indicate that the AFAA was extremely dissatisfied with the safety standards of the aircraft and that it did not meet the Australian standards for flight attendants? Did the AFAA suggest that it might be necessary to use Irish flight attendants because its members might decline to work on the aircraft? Does the aircraft-Liberian registered and Irish operated-normally operate as a cargo carrier in Europe? What action has been taken, given that the aircraft is shortly due to fly with Australian Airlines?

—It is true that such an aircraft has been leased by Australian Airlines with a view to operations in Australia. The aircraft has not yet been approved by the Civil Aviation Authority and it is not flying. The CAA has yet to decide whether it will provide that approval.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It concerns the recent developments in the Soviet Union and eastern Europe, developments which have taken an even more dramatic turn in recent weeks. How does the Government propose to respond, or how is it responding, to these developments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As have all honourable members, the Government has been following recent developments in the Soviet Union and eastern Europe with interest. Indeed, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, in particular, have recently indicated their interest in this matter and have had lengthy discussions with experts on the region from inside and outside government. As has been frequently said in this place by the Prime Minister, we are privileged to live in a period when there is enormous opportunity for the world. Developments which seemed inconceivable only months ago, let alone before then, now seem possible. We on this side are convinced, particularly as a result of discussions held between the Prime Minister and President Gorbachev, that Mr Gorbachev is determined that further developments will require large changes in Soviet domestic and foreign policies. Change of the magnitude that he is attempting will be always difficult and sometimes painful. As has been indicated by the Prime Minister so often, we can only wish him well in that regard.
—Table the answer. We cannot hear it.
—Order! The reason it is difficult to hear is that so many members are interjecting.

—None of us should underestimate the problems inherent in modernising the Soviet economy, which is one of the most significant factors in this whole matter, or in making its political system more democratic. I doubt whether even those opposite would dispute that. I certainly do not have any naive view that President Gorbachev's success is inevitable, unfortunately, but the policies he is pursuing are important to the emergence of a less confrontationist international environment overall. We now see signs that we will all benefit from such an environment.

ANSWER.PARA: A dramatic example is worth noting with respect to the positive effect of the current changes. That has been seen, of course, in Hungary, which the Prime Minister visited recently and which hosted a Cairns Group meeting last year, and in Poland. Both countries are undergoing far-reaching changes which offer prospects of great benefit to their people and to the world. The position on this has been made very clear by both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The difficulties faced by both countries are daunting. Australia, along with a group of 23 other Western nations, has been able to participate in a coordinated effort to assist them during this critical period of adjustment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. As the Prime Minister handed those notes to the Minister, thus removing individual confidentiality, could those notes be now tabled?
—The honourable member for Farrer said that they are notes. If the Minister was quoting from notes he does not have to table them.
—I take a further point of order, Mr Speaker. From where I sit, it is difficult to see. If they were documents, I ask that he table those documents.
—Was the Minister quoting from a document?
—I was quoting from notes.
—Order! The Chair is required to ask the Minister the question. The Minister has answered the question. The Minister is not required to table notes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr N.A. Brown

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Transport and Communications recall telling the Parliament yesterday that an Air Maritime Boeing 737, about which there was some concern, was, to use the Minister's words, `flying in accordance with its flight plan'?. Now that the Minister has hopefully had an opportunity to verify the facts about this matter, is it a fact that the aircraft was 76 kilometres off course? I ask the Minister whether it is a fact that the transcript of conversation from air traffic control, which I have here, states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Thank heavens for radar, Sector Control tried to counsel pilot gently, but has no doubt he was not understood. Would you please try to help these pilots understand the meaning of standard flight procedures and the difference between a Wollongong and a Shelley's departure. We, of course, will try to do the same.
Can the Minister explain the obvious discrepancy between what he told the House yesterday about this disturbing safety infringement and the known facts?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no discrepancy between what I told the House yesterday and the facts; the discrepancy is between the allegations in the question and the facts. The facts of the situation are simply these: As I said yesterday, the Air Maritime flight was not off course; it was on course. My advice on that comes from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation which--
—Have you read that?

—Yes. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has conducted an inquiry into this alleged incident and has found that, although the air traffic controller thought that the plane was off course, it was in fact on course. The air traffic controller was simply wrong.
—I can't believe it!
—Order! The honourable member for Farrer will cease interjecting. The Minister will wait until the House comes to order.
—The air traffic controller was wrong, did you say?
—The air traffic controller was wrong in suggesting that it was off course.
—The Minister will wait until the House comes to order.
—The air traffic controller was wrong!
—The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.
—How did he get from Canberra to Melbourne?
—The honourable member for Menzies asked a question; he might wait for the answer. I call the Minister.

—As I said, the air traffic controller assumed that the plane was off course because it was not on a common path-the common path of departure from Sydney. It was on its intended flight path, and it was an appropriate flight path; it involved no pilot error. There was no suggestion that it was off course at all.
—Order!

—This allegation has been found by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation to be without any foundation whatever; that is, there is no truth in the allegation that the flight was 76 kilometres or 40 kilometres off course; it was on course. They are the facts.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health.
—Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber. I warn the honourable member for Flinders.

—Has there been a significant increase in the number of Medicare services which are direct billed at no direct charge to patients? Has this trend been reflected Australia-wide, including Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Oxley for his question and take the opportunity to congratulate him on his first year's service in this Parliament. He is the only honourable member on this side of the House whose service has been unique to the new Parliament House. In asking this question he recognises the great community benefit, particularly to the least well-off in the community-not a group of great interest to those opposite; that is why they are chattering away. But at least he recognises that the bulk billing process is of benefit to the least well-off in the community.

ANSWER.PARA: Last month I indicated that community support for Medicare had reached an all time high of 71 per cent and increasingly was being accepted as a part of Australian life. That same research reveals that one of the main perceived advantages of Medicare to the Australian people is that it financially helps the less well-off and includes direct billing. Indeed, over two-thirds of those surveyed-68 per cent-think that direct billing is a good thing. Less than one in five people-some 19 per cent-oppose direct billing. The honourable member for Tangney should take those statistics into account in his planning.

Today I am pleased to be able to report that the figures for the June quarter 1989 show that direct billing of all medical services is at the highest level yet. Fifty-six per cent of all services are now direct billed, up 10 percentage points since 1985 and up three percentage points since last year. For general practitioners (GPs) the level of direct billing is even higher. Almost two-thirds-65 per cent-of all GP services are now directly billed; that is, they are provided at no cost to the patient. This is up 12 per cent on 1985 and 3 1/2 percentage points over the last year.

The honourable member for Oxley will be interested to know that this trend is reflected Australia-wide. In Queensland the level of direct billing of all medical services is up four percentage points to 58.4 per cent. Direct billing of GP services in the last year in Queensland has risen by five percentage points to 67.5 per cent of all services. I am also particularly pleased that the ACT, where bulk billing has been disappointing in the past, is at last beginning to catch up to the rest of the nation. The level of direct billing of all medical services in the ACT has risen by six percentage points-the highest rise in the last year-to 36.5 per cent, while the level of direct billing of GP services in the last year rose from 41.4 per cent to 47.7 per cent.

We can now say that general practitioners, particularly in the ACT, are clearly recognising the importance of direct billing, bulk billing, for the least well-off. While there is strong community support for that, while increasingly the medical profession is observing direct billing practices, I notice that in one of those leaks we get about Opposition health policy-all we have had about it for roughly five years is leaks-the Medical Observer of 3 August states that direct billing for the general community is not to be a feature of the new Liberal health scheme. That is more proof that whatever proposal comes forward from the Opposition benefits the well off perhaps but certainly disadvantages the least well-off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I wish to ask the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) whether the Government is prepared to debate now the censure motion against the Minister for Transport and Communications, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), which the Government prevented the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) moving this morning.
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move that:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Minister for Transport and Communications for:
(1) misleading the House by:
(a) his statements yesterday that the CAA had not compromised safety during the current pilots' dispute;
(b) his statement that the Government has no part in licensing procedures for foreign pilots; and
(c) his statements that the testing of foreign pilots is being conducted in line with normal procedures; and
(2) failing in his Ministerial duties to ensure the continued maintenance of Australia's high civil aviation standards and calls for his immediate resignation.

Here we are in the seventh week of the pilots dispute, with a country that is bleeding and with a government that keeps telling us that we will now get back to 50 per cent of our normal services. We have been told that by next week we will have 60 per cent of normal air services operating. If we go back through the history of this dispute we will see that by now, from statements by Ministers of this Government and from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in particular, we should have the entire fleets of Pan American World Airways, British Airways and United Airlines Inc. flying around Australia. In fact, we have become the Liberia of the South Pacific. We have in Australia a makeshift fleet of aircraft flying, aircraft from the most amazing places. It is true that we have aircraft from France, from the United States and now from the United Kingdom. The latest arrival is a Liberian registered, Irish operated, 22-year-old Boeing 707 aircraft used for freight duty in Europe. It has been hired by Australian Airlines Ltd. It is now before the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) to receive approval for Australian Airlines to use it to fly regular passenger traffic in Australia. I was delighted to hear the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) say that that application has not yet been approved.

This situation really points to the fact that there is a world shortage of aircraft, a world shortage of pilots, and that this Government has misled the people of Australia virtually from day one of this particular dispute. All the way through we have heard of these tremendous percentages of services that are allegedly operating around Australia. We keep hearing stories of these magnificent charter aircraft that will arrive in Australia at the end of the charter season. How many do we have? We have two 737 aircraft from a French charter company and one inter-European charter aircraft from Great Britain, owned by Aspro Holidays. I suggest that the line of the Government obviously will be that `Aspro will ease it'. I tell the Government that the travelling public of Australia will not play a part in this particular government operation because it knows that it is virtually impossible to book services in advance; it is virtually impossible to travel when it wants to, and it is virtually impossible to travel more than one leg of a journey at a time.

We have had the Minister for Transport and Communications in here today at Question Time making denials of reports that have been given to his Department by very senior officers. These people are not the flunkies of the Civil Aviation Authority; these men hold very senior positions within the Department; these men are, in fact, responsible for the air safety standards of Australia; these men are expressing very grave concern at what is happening in civil aviation in Australia. Australia has always had a very proud international aviation record. We have prided ourselves in having one of the best aviation records in the world. Yet in the last seven weeks or so we have seen this particularly proud record being diluted all the time when compromises have been made. We have seen our aviation industry taken over by a group of pilots from the United Kingdom, the United States, France, Hungary and now from Yugoslavia. Where will the next pilots come from? Maybe it will be Ireland if ever this 707 aircraft gets off the deck. But who knows?

The plain facts are that we have a very serious situation in Australia. It is not good enough for the Minister to come in here and say that the reports that have come from very senior officers in his Department are to be scoffed at. All the way through the Government has led us to believe that there will be no compromise of safety whatsoever. We have just heard the Minister for Transport and Communications deliver his statement as to what happened with the Air Maritime aircraft the other day out of Sydney. I hope that in his reply to me today the Minister will also answer these questions: Has he yet received an air safety incident report regarding the flight of an Air Maritime 737 aircraft last night, 4 October, on approach into Sydney? Is it a fact that Air Traffic Control in Sydney directed that aircraft to fly to 3,000 feet but not below the distance measuring equipment step process? Is it a fact that that aircraft either ignored or did not understand that instruction and was in general air traffic space at 3,000 feet over the city of Camden?

We want an answer to those questions because that event is the subject of an air safety incident report and we want to know what happened. This sort of thing is going on despite the fact that even the Government's propaganda unit, the National Media Liaison Service, has produced a statement from the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly) who, through the Government propaganda machine, has continually given us assurances that there will be no breaches of Australian air safety standards. We have already introduced to the House evidence that there have been very great difficulties with the French pilots passing the examination set by the Civil Aviation Authority. I think it is really sad when we look at this particular report from Mr Lewino to read what he has had to say about some of the things that have happened. The Minister should really address himself to what is the true situation of the working conditions and the times worked by the management pilots in the airlines. Mr Lewino in his statement says:

A more serious consequence, which has manifested itself over the last week, is that the operational managers are becoming fatigued. They are flying to the full limit of flight and crew duty rules (in one case, over these limits) and attempting to perform their normal management functions as well. I have received several telephone call from managers, trying to catch up with their work during the brief turn-around between flights. Also, although nominally on a `rest day' at home, managers continue to perform management tasks by the telephone.

Over the three-day period, 23-25 September, Ansett requested three extension of flight and crew duty time. I raised this with Ansett's Director of Operations, Captain Dorward, on the 26th. He was annoyed as he had directed no such requests should be made and undertook to repeat this instruction. At the time, Captain Dorward stated that working to the prescribed limit was very tiring for management pilots and he could not accept any increase.
There is other evidence of fatigue. Normally, cool calm managers are becoming terse . . . and they look tired. People like Captain Dorward seem to have aged several years.

The report then contains this line which we must take notice of because we understand that everything is normal and we hope that there will not be any other directions from the Minister or from the Department. In this particular document Mr Lewino goes on to say:

As a result of this development, I have directed my RPT Examiners to increase their line surveillance of Ansett operations and to be on particular lookout for evidence of fatigue induced errors, unreasonable irritability, etc. I have asked to be immediately informed of all such observations as I believe it may be necessary to impose additional rest periods on management pilots.

That certainly is a responsible situation. But the plain facts are that, to maintain the Prime Minister's motley collection of airlines in Australia, these fellows have had not only to be able to work to the limit but, in one case, to go over the limit. I move on to the situation that has been pooh-poohed by the Minister in the Parliament today. I raise the situation of Captain Colin Smith, who was brought to head a program of training for the foreign BAe146 pilots from France and Hungary who were drawn from Thomas Nationwide Transport's cargo operation in Europe. This report states:

Captain Smith had previously been with Ansett WA and had retained his currency with their operations during regular visits to Perth. It was arranged for Captain Smith to have his NZ check captain status validated for Australia by undertaking a flight test with Captain Radnedge. This officer had, until a few weeks ago, been the CAA's BAe 146 Examiner in Perth. He had resigned to take a position with East West but was made available to the CAA, on a ``free consultancy'' basis, to perform the test. Captain Smith passed and was verbally advised by my Senior RPT Examiner, Captain Jones, that he was approved as an Ansett check captain. This has not been confirmed in writing, as will be explained later.
The only concern about Captain Smith at that stage was advice from Mr Scaife, AGM (SR) in WA, that he had a known history at deliberately breaking rules.
In particular, he had been approved to give a demonstration flight at an air show and had exceeded the safety limitation laid down in the approval.
It goes on to say:

I first became personally concerned about Captain Smith on 14 September, when he rang me about the Instrument Rating theory exams of the six French pilots. This exam had been completed the previous day and the examination officers in both Vic./Tas. and HQ became concerned when the answers on the papers were virtually identical. Cheating was suspected and Mr Thomas, acting AGM (OPS), advised me he intended to declare the results invalid. He agreed to defer doing this for a few hours while I investigated the matter as I believed another explanation was possible. Before attempting the exam, the French pilots had been given intensive coaching by two instructors and I thought it was possible the common answers to the exam might be due to the effectiveness of this specific purpose training. As Captain Smith was unavailable, I arranged through Ansett's Training Manager for Mr Fry, my senior Examination Officer, and Mr Moss, my Investigation Officer, to interview the instructors on an `informal' basis. I sent Mr Moss along as he developed over the years a proven ability to detect liars. By asking the instructors certain questions from the exam paper which all of the French pilots had answered incorrectly it was established that in two areas the instructors gave exactly the same erroneous answer as the French. Mr Moss was also of the opinion that the instructors spoke frankly and were unlikely to be involved in any cheating. The meeting with the first instructor, which took place in a room in Ansett's training facility, was amicable and the instructor thanked my officers for pointing out where his instruction was inaccurate.
I was therefore surprised when Captain Smith rang me in a highly emotional state and accused me of deliberately sabotaging the training of the French pilots . . .
This saga goes on. The report continues:

The next morning Mr Thomas arrived in Melbourne to handle the America West arrangements. I informed him of our concerns about Captain Smith and that I intended to withdraw his check pilot approval. In return, Mr Thomas advised that Captain Smith and Mr McMahon, Ansett's GM, had contacted him late the previous evening, via Minister Willis' office, to protest at the French requirements.

We heard at Question Time today that this was quite a normal procedure; that all this went through the office. I am not quite sure how many people in the House know Mr Graham McMahon. He is a most assertive character, and I can imagine exactly what that conversation was likely to have been when it went through the Minister's office. The plain facts are that we have a very difficult situation in terms of what really happened with those examinations in Western Australia, and we have a very serious concern in regard to the certifying of the Air Maritime pilots' licences because of their lack of capacity to understand the English language. All of these things must really worry the members of this House and the public of Australia if we are to maintain those safety standards to the degree that we believe they should be maintained.

Let me quote a little further from the document concerning this examiner, Captain Smith. This incident just kept going on between Ansett, the CAA, the Minister's office and everyone else who was involved. One of the quotations in this report concerns Mr Alan Rainbird. Mr Rainbird, of course, is one of the most senior executives of the Civil Aviation Authority. Mr Rainbird said that he doubted this particular officer's report on the pilot. Mr Lewino said:
I gained the impression he thought my judgement was distorted as a result of this. Also, that my differences with Captain Smith were known to everybody from the `Prime Minister on down'.
So there is no doubt that the Prime Minister has been involved in this incident about this check captain. The report continues:

Again I reached the impression that there was a belief my concerns about Captain Smith's suitability as a check pilot was unjustified and the result of personal dislike. I suggested that Captain Segen, Captain Radbone and Mr Scaife be approached to gain other opinions but Mr Rainbird declined.

In other words, the senior officers of the CAA had decided that Captain Smith was probably not the right person to undertake the duties of a check captain on these foreign pilots flying around Western Australia in BAe 146s. Of course everybody from the Prime Minister down knew the story about Captain Smith. We know, through the Minister's office, that there was intervention about the certifying of Captain Smith as a check officer for the BAe 146s as well. I believe that that should give us a great deal of concern.

We do have a great deal of concern about what is going on in the aviation industry in Australia today. We are concerned that the pilots who are flying are being pushed to their limits. We are concerned that people are now on the verge of being overworked. We are concerned that normal instructions from air traffic control are not being understood by some of these pilots. We are concerned that we now have a mixture of international pilots flying around Australia who may not have the capacity to understand the English language to the extent that they should have to fly regular passenger traffic in Australia. Yet we have been told by the Government all the way through that everything is all right. Everything is not all right. Concerns are coming from all over Australia.

Let me make it perfectly clear that it is not only our judgment that things are not what they should be. There have been some changes in the procedures for the certification of aircraft in Australia during the period of this dispute. It is interesting to note in a CAA circular to all its managers around Australia headed `Surveillance of Foreign and Military Operations' that military aircraft are the responsibility of the Department of Defence. We have no problems there. The circular states:
Foreign aircraft conducting commercial operations into and/or within Australia are in two categories . . .
We have in that category overseas carriers who are presently carrying domestic traffic. That circular sums up the situation of these foreign charter airlines. It states:

Foreign operators authorised to operate on Australian domestic routes. At present there is only one prospective operator in this category, that is America West. It is envisaged that America West's aircraft (B737) and crews will operate under dry lease arrangements to Ansett and under the provisions of Ansett's Air Operators' Certificate. Technical surveillance of America West in Australia will remain the responsibility of the US FAA and that Authority will position staff in Australia for that purpose.

Do we have any evidence that staff have been stationed in Australia for that purpose? I know that America West carries its own engineer on each of its flights. It is interesting that Australian engineers are not allowed anywhere near these foreign aircraft. The circular goes on to say:
However, it is envisaged that operational surveillance will be the responsibility of the CAA.

It mentions operational surveillance but there is nothing about the airworthiness of these aircraft. I think that must give us some cause for concern as well, especially when we see some of the types of aircraft that are presently coming into Australia.

I repeat that a number of honourable members in this House have expressed a great deal of concern to me at the reports they are getting about the Liberian Boeing 707 that is yet to be certified by the CAA. I just hope that we will not have a problem with the Minister. Although the CAA has not provided that certification we do not want to see any short cuts whatsoever on that aircraft. We have had reports about cracked frames on the landing gear, about door seals not working properly, and about harness restraints on the seats within aircraft not being right. All these things must be of concern and they must be checked out before any thought of certification can be given to that aircraft.

Right throughout this pilots dispute this House and this nation have been given information all the way down the line that, frankly, is not true. The information that has been provided by the Prime Minister in terms of the seating capacity that is available in Australia is not true. The information about the number of aircraft that will be operating in Australia also is not true. If we are to reach the level of passenger traffic that is required to meet the Prime Minister's numbers, regarding the percentage of available seats around Australia, today there should be 157 Boeing 737 flights full up with 130 people on each aircraft. That is not happening.

We have not been told the truth in this instance. We have not been told the truth about what has been going on in the CAA. We have not been told the truth about the adjustments that have been made to safety standards. This Minister is responsible and because he has not been completely truthful with us he deserves to be censured. The Opposition parties call on this Minister to resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion that has been moved by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) accuses me of misleading the House in various respects and calls for my resignation. Anyone listening to what he had to say in his 20 minutes would hardly feel that he had enough information or anything like an argument which would justify censure of me, let alone cause my resignation. Let me say emphatically that I stand absolutely by the statements I made to this House yesterday during Question Time. I refute absolutely any suggestion that I have misled the House. Nothing that has been said by the honourable member for Fadden today could in any way lead any objective listener to believe that I had misled the House.

SPEECH.PARA: In the formal motion, which the honourable member hardly spoke to, he said that I had misled the House in my statements yesterday that the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) had not compromised safety during the current pilots dispute. The CAA has a statutory obligation to ensure that there will be a safe aviation operation in this country. In my view, the CAA carries out that obligation with considerable expertise, but of course not without internal dispute sometimes as to what should happen. It does not mean that it is a unanimous organisation in which everybody views every situation absolutely and in the exact same way. There will be differences of opinion at times. Where there are those differences of opinion obviously the senior officers with responsibility should take the final decision. That is essentially all that we have before us at present.

The documents leaked from within the CAA even before they reached the senior officers to whom they were intended to go have simply indicated that there is a difference of view within the organisation. That difference of view needs to be looked at, particularly in the case of Mr Lewino, because the circumstance which he is describing has not been properly stated and has been supplemented by other actions since he finished that report. Essentially what Mr Lewino is saying in his lengthy document, which was quoted at some length by the honourable member for Fadden, is that he was concerned about Captain Smith. He did not like him particularly. He thought his manner was not so terrific and he was therefore concerned about the BAe146 operation for Ansett Western Australia. I think the reality of the situation is that Mr Lewino had a difference of opinion with his senior officials about, firstly, the capacities of Captain Smith and, secondly, whether the BAe check captains who were in Australia were appropriate persons to approve the French pilots for flight operations in Australia.

The BAe check captains are highly experienced pilots who have set up BAe 146 operations in various countries around the world, including Australia. These same BAe check captains are the people who came to Australia five years ago when the 146 operation was set up in Western Australia. They effectively established that operation. They participated in the compilation of the operations manual for Ansett Western Australia BAe 146 operations. They trained the Ansett Western Australia pilots and conducted flight checks of those pilots who were being endorsed on the 146, the new aircraft at that time. Who could argue that these BAe check captains who were in Australia and who set up the Ansett Western Australia operation when it first started are not appropriate persons now to approve the French pilots for their capacity to operate the service in Western Australia? Given those circumstances-they may not have been known to Mr Lewino; he does not refer to them in his lengthy document-it was the view of the senior officers of the CAA that there was no reason not to approve a circumstance in which the BAe check captains were deemed to be the appropriate persons who could approve the French pilots for operations in Western Australia. That is what happened.

Mr Lewino was also saying that he thought the senior check captain of the Ansett operation should conduct the approval. That also happened. The very day this document was written, 28 September, Captain Hanrahan from the Ansett check and training operation went to Western Australia and conducted his own independent and additional check of the French pilots. He also approved them. So there can be no doubt whatsoever that the French pilots flying in Western Australia have been properly authorised by people who are reputable and fully qualified to approve the operations by those pilots of 146 flights in Western Australia. I think any other conclusion that can be drawn in those circumstances obviously falls to the ground.

It has also been said that there are other concerns, particularly looking at the other document from Mr Segan, who makes all sorts of allegations. They were hardly referred to at all by the honourable member for Fadden.

TALK.START.PARA: —Political blackmail. He talked about it this morning.
—Order!
—Is he wrong also?

—Probably, yes, as the honourable member will undoubtedly be also because his track record in this area is one of almost total error. Mr Segan, who for two weeks was an acting senior examiner in Victoria-whilst in that acting position he wrote this note-was not a senior officer of the Civil Aviation Authority.
—Are you calling into question his qualifications?
—I warn the honourable member for Kooyong.
—He is not a minor officer but he is not the most senior officer of the CAA.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Would you like to indicate to me what your grounds are for warning me after one interjection?
—I am warning you for interjecting.
—Would you like to explain to me why, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—There is no explanation needed. If you continue to interject--
—May I assume for the purposes of this debate that anyone who interjects will be warned straightaway while you are in the chair?
—You have been consistently interjecting and you have been warned.
—Have you called me to order at any stage?
—You have been called now and warned.
—Can we establish it as a precedent that if anyone interjects you will warn him?
—Mr Deputy Speaker--
—I have not finished this. You are incompetent as a leader. Do not interrupt.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Chair can rule quite adequately on this point.
—Can we take it as a precedent that anyone who interjects will be warned?
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Is it orderly or within Standing Orders to constantly hector the Chair in the way in which the Leader of the Opposition is doing?
—It is not. I call the Minister.

—I simply say, in view of the time, that the CAA senior officers would certainly refute the allegations made by Mr Segan in many respects-I do not have time to go through the detail of that-in terms of the criticisms made and the suggestions that there is an inadequacy of approach to the approval of foreign pilots operating in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The second leg of this censure motion on me was for my statement that the Government has no part in licensing procedures for foreign pilots. I stand absolutely by the fact that the Government has not been involved in any way in putting pressure on the CAA about the licensing procedures for foreign pilots. We have not been interfering in that. That is a matter for the CAA. There is no proof whatsoever to justify this allegation, made at length in the Senate this morning and also in this House. All that the Opposition has is the circumstance I referred to during Question Time when there was a phone call to my office late one night from the General Manager of Ansett, who complained about the CAA. He was given the name of an officer of the CAA to speak to and his home phone number. That is supposed to implicate the Government, as though we are involved in some heinous activity to put pressure on the CAA. What a ludicrous, ridiculous suggestion. Am I not to tell Ansett anything about the CAA? Obviously it was the sensible thing to do, and that is all that was done. There are a couple of allegations about political interference, but there is no substance whatsoever in those allegations. Frankly, these officers would not know if there was or there was not. They are not in a position to know. I absolutely deny that there has been government interference in the licensing procedures for foreign pilots.

The third leg of this motion is that I misled the House by my statements that the testing of foreign pilots is being conducted in line with normal procedures. This is what I said in the House yesterday at Question Time with regard to foreign pilots:

. . . the CAA is ensuring through flight checks and oral or written tests that these pilots are competent. The tests are conducted in line with normal procedure by check captains of the airlines or by the CAA examiners of airmen.

That is the truth. I do not in any way go back on that statement; the statement stands. There is no suggestion that anything I said there is wrong. So I cannot see the point of the third dot point under the first paragraph of the censure motion accusing me of misleading the House. It does not have any substance whatsoever.

The motion says that I have failed in my ministerial duties to ensure the continued maintenance of Australia's high civil aviation standards. I refute that statement. This Government has done everything it can in the course of a very difficult dispute to ensure, first, that Australia had some level of civil aviation service and the highest possible level of service that we could provide in the extremely difficult circumstances of 1,600 pilots having resigned their positions; and, second, that we built up that capacity on the basis that we maintained our high level of safety in this country. That was the basis upon which we conducted the whole operation. I said to the CAA that that was the basis upon which we should be proceeding. Mr Freeland, the chief executive of the Civil Aviation Authority, this afternoon has issued a press statement. I will not go through the detail of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you write it for him?
—I certainly did not. The end of that statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Freeland said there had also been some suggestion of political pressure on the CAA to lower its safety standards during the current air pilots' dispute. Mr Freeland firmly rejected such suggestions `in fact' he said `the only instruction I have received has been a reminder from the Government not to allow any reduction in safety standards.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that in writing?

—It is in a press statement, issued to the press this afternoon. It is quite clear that the Civil Aviation Authority is conducting its operations as it sees appropriate in extremely difficult circumstances. It is trying as far as possible to assist the airlines to rebuild capacity, but not at the expense of safety, and with no suggestion from government that there should be any lowering of safety standards. There is nothing coming from the Opposition, nothing in these documents, which suggests in any way that there has been any government interference which would be pushing against the safety standards.

SPEECH.PARA: There are suggestions in those documents that in the opinion of those people safety standards have been compromised. In relation to the BAe 146 operation in Western Australia, it is clearly and undeniably wrong, and people listening to this debate should not swallow the Opposition line that foreign planes, ipso facto, mean an unsafe operation. We have foreign planes operating here all the time in normal circumstances. International foreign planes come here all the time. They fly not just in and out of Australia but around Australia. They carry tens of thousands of Australians every year. Does anyone suggest that that is totally unsafe and that we are destroying the safety of the aviation operation in Australia because there are foreign pilots in foreign planes flying around Australia in normal circumstances? Of course not.

These additional flights are operating on a similar basis. There is no reason whatsoever for the people of Australia to be scared by the Opposition into believing that there is an unsafe operation. They should recognise the Opposition's motive. It is to try to destroy the Government's attempts to defeat the pilots. They are the friends of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. They have done everything possible to stop this Government from resolving this dispute in a satisfactory way; and this motion of censure is just part of that process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a weak defence the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) has put up. It must surely be the weakest defence ever presented by a Minister in this Parliament in response to a censure motion directed against him. We want to make the point perfectly clearly that very serious allegations have been made against this Minister and about the handling by the Government of this whole air safety issue; and the Minister has not answered them. Let us get the point abundantly clear before we go any further. There has been no defence advanced by the Minister in answer to some very serious allegations made about both him and the Government's handling of the air safety issue at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: Before going any further, it is time that some facts were put on the table. We are debating certain statements that have been made, not by two low ranking officers in a department but by two quite senior officers concerned with air safety. Those documents have not yet been tabled. To this point the Government has refused permission for them to be tabled. We want to get one thing very clear before we go any further. I ask for leave now to table the two statements by the two gentlemen concerned, namely, Mr Segan and Mr Lewino.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—No, we don't table--
—Leave is not granted.

—Leave is not granted; so there we are. The Minister is prepared to give this off the cuff defence, but the Government and he are not prepared to let the people see the substantial and sustained allegations made against him and his Government. The Government wants to stifle the facts so that the people do not have access to concerns expressed by two senior officers, not just about something concerning money, not just about some issue of public policy, but about the safety of people in aircraft in this country. It should be understood very clearly that the Government is refusing leave to have those documents tabled so that the people can see the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: What has the Minister said in response to some very serious allegations about the compromising of air safety standards? He said, `Well, yes, there is some internal dispute here and there; only an internal dispute, of course, about whether a check captain is authorised properly to check other captains before they are allowed to fly'. That just wipes off some internal disputes. He says, `Oh yes, there is some difference of opinion here and there, a difference of view'. That is the off the cuff defence we get.

I suppose that it fits in very well with the standard of defence that we saw in Question Time today. When we pinned the Minister, when we found the smoking gun about a very serious safety infringement concerning the Air Maritime aircraft, what was the Minister's reply? It was, `Oh, the air traffic control was wrong. It was not the case that the pilot was wrong. It was just a trifling matter of the air traffic control being wrong'. What we say to the Government is that, because of its hamfisted handling of this matter, it has brought civil aviation and air safety to the pass where, if what the Government says is correct-that the air traffic control was wrong-there is a very serious situation so far as air traffic control and safety in this country are concerned. I suppose that the Minister can sit there smirking it off. Whatever safety infringement we raise, he smirks it off, laughs it off-

TALK.START.PARA: —He thinks it's funny.

—He thinks it's funny. He wipes it off, forgets about it. He puts it down as a difference of opinion. We are only talking about an aircraft being 76 kilometres off course, flying in the wrong direction, with a pilot who cannot understand directions given to him by air traffic control, and only 100 or so passengers on board. Only that-yet the Minister sits here smirking, wiping it off and simply saying that it is a difference of opinion and that the air traffic control was wrong. He is the Minister and he does not escape responsibility by saying that the Civil Aviation Authority is an independent body. The Minister is responsible and he is abrogating his responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us listen to just some of the things which indicate how the Minister has fallen down on his job and his lack of ministerial responsibility. He had these documents and it is a pity that he did not have the respect or the Parliament that would have led him to reply to some of the allegations made. For example, Mr Segan said that there is an erosion of operational standards. If this man is employed in this position, that seems to me to be a very serious allegation. He says that the administration of standards is `totally inadequate' today. That is the situation we have got to. The administration of safety standards, according to the public servant most intimately responsible for them, is totally inadequate. He says that some of the concessions that have been given are `tantamount to providing permission to break the law'. He says that the new standards of safety that are being set around the country these days are being `set by political blackmail'. He says that there are non-standard radio calls. Are non-standard radio calls being made? Is it true? Will the Minister tell us whether non-standard radio calls are being made between air traffic control and aircraft carrying Australians around the skies of this country. Is the allegation true or false? That is all we want to know. The honourable member for Gellibrand is the Minister, and he is responsible. Mr Segan went on to say that the exams administered to foreign pilots have been `relaxed without justification'. Is that true? Have the exams been relaxed without justification? If the Minister had any respect for his ministerial responsibility or for this House, he would reply to that specific allegation. He has not done so.

In his summary Mr Segan went on to make a very disturbing statement about an area of government activity. He said that for purely political reasons, against longstanding requirements, concessions on safety matters have been granted without due consideration of equivalent safety factors. Let us remember those words `without due consideration of equivalent safety factors'. That is a very serious allegation to make. It is not enough for the Minister simply to come in here and say that is nothing but a difference of opinion. His defence is that he says that it is a difference of opinion. We want a few more facts let out, if the Minister does not mind. The Australian people, especially those who are being conned by the Minister into believing that our air system is getting back to normal and that it is safe, also want to know.

The allegations go on, of course. It is not just one statement, but two. A second statement was made by Mr Lewino, and in some cases it is a matter of even more concern. Mr Lewino has made a number of very serious allegations. The Minister has not replied to any of them. Mr Lewino says that the operational managers who are also flying are getting fatigued. Can you believe it? The Minister is presiding over a situation which he is allowing to continue where operational managers who are flying aircraft with passengers are becoming fatigued. In his statement the Minister could have told us whether that is true or not, and he could have told us what was being done to rectify the situation. It goes on and on and on. A whole history of allegations is made there-not, I repeat, just by some underling but by two of the public servants responsible. Some serious allegations which have not been replied to give us in the Opposition and the Australian people very grave concern indeed about the system the Minister is presiding over.

It is not just that the Minister is presiding over a system which is very clearly unsafe but that he came into the Parliament yesterday and continued to promote the line that none of this exists at all, as he has done week after week. That is the burden of our complaint-that he has misled the Parliament and the Australian people. There is a very compressed way of looking at the whole case that he has presented over the last few weeks. When the Minister came in yesterday he said:

I am aware of allegations made by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots . . . that the CAA has compromised safety during this dispute. I totally reject that charge. Both the Government and the CAA are concerned to ensure that, in rebuilding our domestic aviation system, Australia's high safety standards are fully maintained.

That was yesterday's position. Today we have these two reports blasting those assertions completely out of the water, and the Minister has given no reply. All we get is the standard smirk, the standard brush-off.

TALK.START.PARA: —The joker!

—The joker. That is the only degree of seriousness that the Minister is prepared to give this matter. He holds himself out as being very firmly in control of all this. He says, `There is no problem. The Minister is in charge. It does not matter about aircraft flying 76 kilometres off course or air traffic control being wrong. `No, no problem at all', he says.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another illustration of just how wrong the Minister is. I would like to refer the House to another document which shows just how firmly in control the Minister is. As honourable members will recall, one of the Government's recent bribes-I know it is difficult to distinguish one from another-was to waive charges levied by the Civil Aviation Authority and Federal Airports Corporation. It is known-but not to too many people-that the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority were not too keen on waiving those charges so the Minister had to give them a direction. In the direction given to the Civil Aviation Authority he said:
I, Ralph Willis, Minister of State for Transport and Communications. . .

The document is signed by him. I presume that he would not have signed it unless he had read it. Can the House believe that when we read on we see that the Civil Aviation Authority is being directed to waive charges that are brought to the notice of the Federal Airports Corporation-not the Civil Aviation Authority at all. Presumably the direction given to the Federal Airports Corporation would be telling it to waive charges brought to the notice of the Civil Aviation Authority. I suppose the Minister would sign his own death warrant if it was put in front of him. I give the Minister some free advice: his notice is invalid and he would be very well advised to do it again if he wants to have these charges waived. The Minister would be well advised to follow that advice.

We want to put this matter in context. We have established beyond any shadow of doubt that the Minister for Transport and Communications and the Government have misled the Parliament and the Australian people both about the safety standards applying today and about the Government's involvement in the whole charade. I want to end by putting the matter into context because it goes further. We should ask the question: Why has the Government been involved in this situation? How has it come about that we have allowed Australia's fine civil aviation record to fall to this pass where we now have concerned public servants writing memoranda to draw attention to safety shortcomings?

The context is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-and the rest of the Government-has been concerned to carry out his vendetta and to pursue his manic preoccupation with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, one that he has had ever since he failed to force it into the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The day of reckoning has now come. The Prime Minister has been so extreme, histrionic and provocative in the dispute and so concerned about pursuing his manic vendetta that he has let-and other Ministers have allowed him to do this-the whole hatred which seems to be his prime motivation colour the way in which our civil aviation problems are being solved today. The problem is so great that the Prime Minister has allowed himself to be influenced in this way and to drag our civil aviation industry into a very unsafe state indeed. The two documents I have referred to are the evidence of it.

That is the context. The Government will now adopt any device-even breaches of air safety-to pursue its manic policy, the objective being to preserve the centralised wage fixed system and to destroy the Federation of Air Pilots. The Government can do what it likes about the centralised wage fixation system, but it must not continue to mislead the Parliament about air safety standards and the Minister for Transport and Communications should do something to exercise his ministerial responsibility, in which he is failing gravely, to ensure the safety of the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I did not want to interrupt whilst the honourable member for Menzies was making such a devastating case, so I left it until now. During the honourable member's remarks the Minister under censure and the Leader of the House interjected on three or four separate occasions but did not attract your attention across the table. I wonder whether in those circumstances, in the spirit of even-handedness, you would like to withdraw your warning against the Leader of the Opposition?
—The Chair is not putting itself in a position to be questioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This censure motion would have to go down in history as one of the most irresponsible, pathetic Opposition actions ever. Those opposite parade around about concern for air safety, the aviation industry, the tourism industry and the pilots dispute, and what do they do? They have indulged in every action they can dream up, raised every idea they can promote and suggested every fabrication they can concoct to create doubt and obstacles to a settlement of the dispute and to damage the industry. Let me say right at the outset to those opposite: `You have a problem. You are in this place--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I just want to say by way of introduction that we do not take the verbiage that you have been using in addressing me and other members lightly. You gave a response before that you were not putting yourself in a position to be questioned, but this is something that I place before the House at present. Whether in the chair or out, no-one has the right to assume unto himself that he cannot be questioned. I wanted the record to show that we will not tolerate this sort of nonsense, no matter who is in the chair.
—There is no point of order. The Chair is there to adjudicate on whether members are interrupting to the extent that they need to be warned or called upon to desist.
—You will recall that I was not doing that.
—You were doing that.

—I seek an extension of time to make up for the time lost. This censure motion is a ruse from an Opposition that is desperate to find its own way on industrial relations policy. Members of the Opposition have many conflicting points of view and many competitors putting their policy, and a Leader who does not understand what it is all about. Right through this dispute with the pilots, what has been the role of the Opposition? It has been to give aid and encouragement to the pilots; to abet them and give them succour. What is the effect of that? It is to prolong the dispute. Their tears about the disruption being caused to Australia are crocodile tears. It is utter hypocrisy. Members of the Opposition come into the chamber and try to convince the people of this country that international aircraft are unsafe. My dear-foreign pilots! How is that? Fancy having an Irish crew, of all things. How dare overseas registered aircraft be brought into this country! This is the same Opposition saying, `We want more international tourists here. We want an open skies international aviation policy so that any intrenational airline can fly here'. What we are seeing here is just rank opportunism from people who do not really care, who think that they can score some cheap political point regardless of the cost to this country or the fear, anxiety and worry that they may create for some people. But, most of all, we see their hypocrisy towards the tourism industry.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is faced with a situation where an elite group of people set up a demand for a 30 per cent increase in pay. If that had been acceded to, a wage explosion would have followed. From that wage explosion there would have been inflation and, after that, massive unemployment. Who loses their jobs? Not the pilots. The senior pilots are well paid; they can get by in a tough period. It is the ordinary people, the workers of this country, who would suffer. We will not let them suffer, nor do they want the Government to change the policy that it is pursuing. They know in their wisdom that we cannot afford a wages explosion in this country. They know what will happen, and they do not want to lose their jobs; they want the security of our maintaining record low un-employment in this country. That is what this dispute is all about. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) at the end of his comments finally got around to mentioning wages policy and the centralised wage fixing system. Some members of the Opposition are hell-bent one way or another on destroying that system. Playing along with the pilots is part of that process. They thought that they were on a winner. I can tell them that they are not on a winner. There are no winners in this kind of exercise, only losers. It is a battle that should not be happening. It is a problem that can be overcome tomorrow or in the next few days. If the Australian Federation of Air Pilots is genuine in what it is saying, that it is prepared to accept the terms of the contracts that have been signed for the pilots who are now back at work and that it is prepared to go back and accept arbitration-that is all it has to say-it should go and put its case before the Industrial Relations Commission, accept the Commission's decision and encourage the pilots back to work. The more members of the Opposition encourage the Federation, the more it encourages pilots not to go back to work, the more it prolongs the dispute, and the more damage and disruption is done to the tourism industry. That is really the issue.

This is a political campaign by a group of people who would have to constitute the most irresponsible Opposition that we have seen in this place. To set out on a concerted campaign to undermine public perceptions of air safety, to frighten people out of aeroplanes and to suggest that internationally registered aircraft which meet international requirements and the requirements of the Civil Aviation Authority of this country are unsafe, and to convince people that all those foreign pilots are unsafe and only Australians pilots can fly aeroplanes safely, is the height of irresponsibility. What members of the Opposition are about is attacking the economy and attacking the Australian people, and damaging the economic stability of this country.

Let us go to the problem of industrial relations policy. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) just does not understand. Members of the Opposition are not in the chamber; they have all gone. This is such an important issue to the Opposition and there is one Opposition member in the chamber plus one at the table. That is the measure of the importance of this issue. It is a cheap, irresponsible, dirty stunt.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are only three behind you.

—One of us is good enough for all of you, my friend. One is enough; we do not need them all over here. Where are members of the Opposition? This is just a stunt. That is all it is, and that is all this is about.
—There are none of them in the House.

—Where are they? Where is the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who does not support what those opposite are doing? The former Leader of the Opposition supports the Government. He has a nine-point plan and within the nine-point plan there is a one-point plan. The one-point plan is: let the pilots pursue their own thing and let each of them individually negotiate. At the same time the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) had a six-point plan. His six-point plan was to say that they could not get what they wanted under his system. Senator Stone had his own style. Senator Chaney, really the contortionist, had a whole range of them. Every day he had a new policy and a new approach that fitted in with whatever he thought the newspapers would run that day. But the one consistent person in all of this issue, right through, is the former Leader of the Opposition-who is looking to be the Opposition spokesman for industrial relations. He has his own policy; that is, dump the union, the Federation; no negotiations; let the pilots and individual airlines work our their own arrangements. He is the only person in the Opposition with any dignity in this whole issue. He was not here yesterday for the matter of public importance; he is not here again now. The issue facing the Opposition is what to do with the honourable member for Bennelong, how to contain him and how to reconcile his consistent responsible view-even though we disagree with it, at least he has the dignity of being consistent-with the Opposition's opportunistic, irresponsible approach.

SPEECH.PARA: As Opposition members go around this country trying to frighten people and convince them that aviation is unsafe, that aircraft that have been approved by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) are not airworthy, that aircrews that have been approved by the Civil Aviation Authority are not competent, what are they doing? They are frightening people away from air services. The next thing they say is that the air services will not operate, that there are not as many air services operating. Go to the airports, watch the aeroplanes come and go and ask the passengers. Opposition members will find out for themselves.

The Opposition asks the Government what it is doing for the tourism industry, while the Opposition itself is busily undermining the very services this Government is assisting with and the airlines are providing to get the tourism industry back on its feet and try to recover lost ground. Opposition members should talk to people in the tourism industry and explain to them the Opposition's double standards and hypocrisy. They should explain why the Opposition is trying to undermine the efforts of the airlines and the Government to get air services back to normal. As I said, as far as the Leader of the Opposition is concerned, what he says is all waffle anyway. He does not understand the situation. He waffles on about it regularly. The only consistent person is the honourable member for Bennelong.

There is a way through this. The decision of the Commission set out the roles of the various parties in this dispute. It will meet tomorrow at 11 a.m. to discuss the next step in the process. If there were one skerrick of integrity on the other side of this House, the Opposition would be encouraging pilots to get back to work. It would be encouraging the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to get itself back within the national wage case guidelines, to accept arbitration and to put a sensible and responsible view to the Commission and the parties involved. That is the positive and responsible way forward.

The Opposition will not do that because it thinks there are a few points to score. Those points will hang around the necks of Opposition members for years to come, as they sit on the Opposition benches. That is where they will stay. The public in this country understands what needs to be done. The public understands that it is not responsible to destroy wages policy and it is not responsible to grant to a group of people a wage increase that is more than most families in this country are required to live on for a year. It is more than most families earn in a year to rear their kids. The Opposition thinks that does not matter. It is prepared to do anything to undermine the system, to undermine the wages policy, to attack Australian families. The solution is for the Opposition to join in encouraging the Federation to adopt the right course, to get the matter settled and services back to normal.

I turn to the issue of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). We listened today to questions at Question Time which were effectively rebutted by the answers given by the Minister. The remarks that have been made against the Minister during the debate in this chamber can only be described as pathetic. There are probably a few fellows within the Civil Aviation Authority from the older days--

TALK.START.PARA: —CAA crashed one of its planes this year on landing.

—Is the honourable member for Farrer saying he wants to see a crash? He is trying to undermine the provision of air services in this country by people who are properly accredited with competence and aircraft which are properly passed as airworthy. The honourable member recognises that there are probably people within the CAA who have allegiances from the past to the Federation of Air Pilots, who might feel that there is a link, that they should be doing something to give succour and understanding to the Federation. Be that as it may, that is the organisation. The fact is that the Minister for Transport and Communications has effectively rebutted what the Opposition has put forward. The new proposal put forward by the pilots is a con trick. If they want to participate in the resolution of the dispute they should be accepting the terms that have been put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to finish on the subject of the role of the shadow Minister for tourism, aviation and sport. His is the role of doing everything possible to undermine services. He has a divided loyalty. On the one hand, he is hammering away with every bit of scuttlebutt, gossip, phone call, anything he can find to convince people that air services are unsafe and that the Government should be doing more. On the other hand, he bewails what the Government is not doing and what services are not being provided for tourism. He as an individual member of the Opposition has a case to answer. He has to explain why he is trying to destroy the redevelopment and regrowth of the tourism industry.

This censure motion should be directed at the Opposition. Day after day, week after week the Opposition has done its best to cause confusion, alarm, anxiety and damage for Australia's tourism industry, at the same time professing concern at the disruption to air services. The Opposition has contributed to that. The acts of the Opposition today, yesterday and during previous weeks have had one effect only and that is to prolong the resolution of the dispute and the resumption of normal air services in this country. Meanwhile, this Government will continue giving assistance wherever necessary in a reasonable way to provide alternative and supplementary services. The Government will continue to do that, as the Opposition provides in its own policy. The policy of the Opposition provides for assistance in appropriate circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —That speech by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) was a pathetic effort. If I were the Minister, trying to do the right thing, I would be donating today's pay as a Minister of the Crown to some worthwhile charity. I can assure the Minister that, on the basis of that performance-that rhetoric, that diatribe, that rubbish he has just given the House-he has not earned his day's pay. The only thing that has been good today is the Minister's imagination. He has been able to imagine that the most unbelievable things have been occurring in the pilots dispute during the last seven weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most fantastic forms of imagination on the Minister's side of the House is the view that somehow or other the Opposition is responsible for this strike. To use a pun, that is the greatest flight of fantasy that has occurred in this country for years. I can assure the Minister of that. He is a Minister of the Crown, he draws a wage as such and is a part of the Government, and the Government makes the rules. The Government determines what happens, not the Opposition. The job of the Opposition is to bring to the attention of the public, the voting people of Australia, just where failures occur in the administration of this country and where things that might be of concern to them are not being brought to their attention. It is on that basis that today the Opposition brings forward this censure motion.
