It does so because in the possession of the Opposition are two documents which would be of the gravest concern to any reasonable person.

The claims which the Minister, in his speech a few moments ago, was saying are our claims-that we are frightening passengers and so forth-are not our claims. They are not the claims of anybody on this side of the House. They happen to be the claims of two very senior officials within the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The Civil Aviation Authority is the body set up to administer the safety procedures of the civil aviation industry in Australia. Two of its most senior administrators say safety procedures are not good and that in the last few weeks they have gone backwards. They are saying that there is a serious situation and that safety standards have been compromised. Those are the claims the Opposition brings to the House today to put before the people of this country so that they can assess the truth. It is not what the Opposition says; it is what two senior Civil Aviation Authority people say.

No-one should be fooled for one moment by the comments of the Minister, who tried to make out that the Opposition was making up these things. The Opposition is only bringing to the people of Australia documents which would be of grave concern to every Australian-not just travellers on the airlines of Australia-because we are all concerned about the future and safety of our fellow Australians. There is no doubt, as a result of the evidence in these documents, that the safety of our fellow Australians is being put at risk every day. The Government claims that 15,000 to 17,000 people are currently using civil aviation services each day. If honourable members read the documents that we have tried to table in the Parliament today, they will realise that as a consequence of the Government's industrial relations approach every one of those 15,000 or 17,000 Australians who get in the air each day is having his life put at risk.

The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) today stands condemned before the Parliament. He stands condemned because the evidence provided by those two senior members of the Civil Aviation Authority condemns him outright. He is hung, drawn and quartered on this one. There is no way he can get out of it. The Minister laughs, but I remember his colleague-who is now just the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown)-laughing equally loud just a little while ago, before he resigned as a Minister. He resigned as a Minister because he misled the House. The evidence in the documents that we have tried to table indicates to the House that the Minister has misled this place. If he has the same degree of integrity as other members who have resigned for being found guilty of those same charges in this place in years gone by, he too would resign because he has been found guilty of misleading the Parliament.

The comments made by the previous speaker, the Minister for Industrial Relations are quite insulting to anybody of a reasonable nature. For example, he said that we were using this censure motion about the safety procedures in our aviation industry as a ruse. I can tell him that our concern about the safety of air passengers in Australia is not a ruse. It is a genuine concern, as it should be, of any reasonable Australian and any reasonable parliamentarian. Our concern is heightened because of what is in the documents to which I referred.

The Minister asked how we dared to question the qualifications of foreign pilots and the standards of foreign aircraft. As every member in the House would know, other countries do not have the same standards and safety procedures for the operation of their aircraft or for the training of their pilots as we have. This is why it is of great concern to us and why we believe we have a right to question the qualifications of those pilots who are now flying commercial aircraft in this country. Indeed, we have a right to question the procedures and safety standards that apply to those foreign aircraft that are currently plying the airways of this country. All we got from the previous speaker was a diatribe about the wages system. He, like his colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications, did not address the very fundamental issues of this censure motion. He went on about the wages system. We have heard it a hundred times; we all know about it. It does not address this censure motion before the House today.

The defence put forward by the Minister for Transport and Communications was very weak. He said that all the information in the documents that we are not allowed to table is no good and that there is no truth in the information. He said that he can verify it all because a senior public servant issued a press statement which disqualifies all the things that are in the documents that we have in our possession today. The basis of the defence that the Minister put forward in his speech today was built on a press statement put out this afternoon by a senior member of the Civil Aviation Authority. His defence does not stack up with the words in the documents of the two senior civil aviation authorities in the CAA. That is the situation that we have had so far today.

We have not been frightening people. The documents that we have in our possession are causing people right across Australia to be frightened. We believe that as a consequence of the censure motion today the Minister has misled the House and should therefore resign. Australians right across the country have a right to know what is going on. They have a right to be outraged-particularly those Australians who fly each day; particularly those 15,000 Australians, so far, who have lost their jobs as a consequence of the pilots dispute; particularly those Australians who own small businesses which are related to the tourism industry who have had their businesses' viability put at risk. Some of the latter are already going out of business. Honourable members opposite should speak to some of their friends in Tasmania to find out what is happening there. They should speak to some of their friends in north Queensland to find out what is happening there. They have been put at risk as a consequence of the Government's actions in the pilots dispute. The Government has put at risk all those jobs and businesses. Why has it done it? It has done it because it has some manic commitment to the centralised industrial award system that it has introduced. It is prepared to put at risk the lives of every Australian who flies. It is prepared to put at risk the jobs of people in the tourism industry. It is prepared to put at risk foreign earnings. It is prepared to strangle the fastest growing, probably the most exciting, industry that we have in Australia today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was.

—It was the fastest growing and most exciting industry that we had and it was our largest single export earner. The Government is prepared to put all those things at risk simply because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has an unbelievable and very questionable emotional attachment to the dispute and the Government has a manic commitment to the centralised wage fixing system. Every Australian has a right to be concerned about this.

SPEECH.PARA: In his response, the Minister for Transport and Communications said some things which most of us could find unacceptable. For example, he said that Captain Smith was an appropriate person to be used for the proper testing of foreign pilots in this country. It is interesting to read the document that the Government will not let us table. I assure the House that Captain Smith is a cause for concern. If we read the document we find that Captain Smith suggested that in the process of testing these first officers he should put two of them in the control seats; he should sit in the flight engineer's seat or the jump seat and authorise their licences to fly in Australia during a normal commercial flight. That is not acceptable. That is the standard of the man that the Minister allowed to authorise those foreign pilots to get their licences in this country. That is the standard of the man who the Minister thought was appropriate to license those pilots.

The situation is quite untoward. Proper licensing procedures have not been met. For example, the normal English language tests that are used to test foreign pilots to ensure that they have an adequate grasp of the language were not used. They were just left out. We find in the documents that we are not allowed to table that the oral examination that was put to those pilots was not of a normal type and that each of the French pilots got exactly the same questions wrong and exactly the same questions right. Surely that should cause people to be concerned, yet the Minister said that all the systems used for authorising the pilots were normal. I assure him that most Australians who are concerned for their safety in the air would not consider that those systems were normal.

I invite the Minister to imagine what would have happened had the Air Maritime aircraft crashed. According to the transcript of the conversation between the two air traffic control towers in Sydney and Melbourne which the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) read to the House, the French pilots could not understand the directions that they were being given. As a consequence of their lack of understanding of the language, they turned right instead of left. As a consequence of that, they were 76 kilometres off course. The situation could have resulted in a serious accident. How would the Minister feel had that been the case? How would he feel had the accident occurred? I assure the Minister that had there been an accident he would have been the man responsible. He would have been very sorry indeed that he had allowed the Prime Minister, the Leader of his Government, to bully him and his colleagues into allowing a reduction in the standards of safety applied to our aviation industry to take place.

A reading of the documents also shows that the Minister allowed the Government to become quite compromised with the commercial airlines system. If the Minister reads the document, he will see that whenever Ansett Airlines of Australia seems to want to do something, it seems to do it. Whenever Ansett wants control, influence or guidance, it seems to get it. The compromising situation highlighted in these documents is cause for concern. Why is it that Ansett has this relationship with the Government? Why is it that this Government is prepared to compromise safety procedures in order to facilitate the best commercial interests of Ansett Airlines? I am sure that honourable members on this side of the House could give me a very precise answer.

The censure motions moved today by the honourable member for Fadden and the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) are overwhelming. They highlight to the Parliament precisely how the Minister for Transport and Communications has misled the House, how precisely the standards of safety have been reduced in the aviation industry here in Australia, and just how far this Government is prepared to go to maintain its manic commitment to the centralised industrial award system. As a consequence of these documents, which the Government has refused to allow us to present to the Parliament so that everybody in Australia can see them, there is no doubt whatsoever that the Minister for Transport and Communications has misled this House and should resign today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government and the House have complete confidence in the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), in the Civil Aviation Authority, and in its procedures. We will demonstrate the reasons why we and the general public should have that confidence in some detail over the next 15 minutes, though not as much as we could if we had a little longer; but the reassurance will be sufficient in that period.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say one thing about this censure motion. The House of Representatives has been broadcast all day today, so those few masochists out there listening to us will not be aware that this debate has been run all morning in the Senate. The general public may also not be aware of the fact that the Government does not have a majority in the Senate; in fact, the Government is in a significant minority in the Senate. The Senate's position is arbitrated by a number of minority parties. We generally lose censure motions in the Senate. The Government is regularly censured in the Senate. I myself have been censured on several occasions. The last time I was censured in the Senate it took me two weeks to find out. It is not unusual for a Government Minister to find himself successfully censured in the Senate.

What is unusual is for a Government Minister to find himself unsuccessfully censured in the Senate-that is, an unsuccessful attempt to censure him. This has been one of those occasions. It has not been possible for the Liberal Party of Australia, on the basis of the documentation it has brought into this place and on the arguments it has made, to sufficiently convince minority parties regularly prepared to censure this Government and our Ministers that the Minister concerned and the Government generally ought to be censured. A degree of commonsense has applied.

I will now go into detail as to why that confidence should be placed in us. The fact is-and this shows how far the Opposition is from government-that there is scarcely an area of Government activity in which advice or final determinations or whatever are made on the basis of a unanimous view among the personnel who offer that advice. I was an aviation Minister myself for 20 months. I note that some honourable members opposite have been aviation Ministers. It is now the turn of this Minister, whose administration of his Department is being debated today, to be an aviation Minister.

There has been nothing more contentious than the way in which the Civil Aviation Authority and its predecessors have conducted the regulatory environment in which they operate. Every issue in that regulatory environment has been the subject of debate. When I was aviation Minister I was the repository of endless submissions by honourable members opposite to change this or that civil aviation regulatory practice. Endlessly, those opposite claimed that the Civil Aviation Authority was overly restricted. They pursued that line month after month on the-

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't exist then.
—Well, it was the Department of Civil Aviation, administering the same regulations-the honourable member should get off his high horse-the same procedures and the same administration.
—Just a minor detail.

—We know the value of the honourable member's legal advice; it was obviously regarded very highly by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) and the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) in the course of their deliberations today. The fact is that there has been a constant effort by members of parliament who have an interest in the aviation industry to change the regulatory authority arrangements or at least the procedures by which these arrangements are carried out. That is a matter of debate. I draw attention to that fact only to indicate that the Civil Aviation Authority has been addressing those matters and has changed the regulatory environment and the procedures to some considerable degree. What has been presented by the officers in the documentation that the Opposition has to hand to some extent portrays a degree of ignorance about some of those fundamental changes in administrative arrangements. It is worth pointing out that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult for the Government to respond to these papers immediately for one simple reason: the original documents concerned have yet to arrive at the Civil Aviation Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us deliver them to you now.

—We do have copies of them. They appeared in forums outside the Government almost immediately they were written and well before they arrived at the central authority. I do not in any way, shape or form wish to question the motives of the authors of the document, but I do question the motives of those who had immediate access to them and were prepared to put them about in public so generously. I wonder what those motives might be. It is at least a sustainable view that those motives included an intention not to deal with safety but with the politics of this dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me pick up one or two of the points that have been made. The Opposition is concerned that the French pilots speak no English. Indeed, in one of the documents the suggestion is made that this happens to be the case and that difficulties arise from this. People whose native language is Serbo-Croatian, Italian, Japanese, Korean from time to time, Chinese, French and German, regularly fly into and operate within our air space. The ability to read, write and understand English is a requirement specified in civil aviation orders. This may be examined by a specific test or by observation at any stage during the training. Let me read from the advice of the Civil Aviation Authority to the Minister about the French pilots. It states:

The French pilots demonstrated this requirement initially by sitting for the examinations in writing in English and subsequently successfully completing approximately 40 hours of flying under supervision.
The complaint was made about the check captains that were appointed to do the BAe146 examinations.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did they lose their competence?

—I am getting down to dealing with the Opposition's allegations; which it did not. It turns out that the check captains who were appointed and who were the subject of a complaint are the same check captains who assisted in the preparation of the Ansett Western Australia operations manual for 146 aircraft when they were originally introduced in Western Australia about five years ago. They also trained and checked Australian pilots employed by Ansett Western Australia at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: One person whose reputation has had a bit of a raking over in this place is one Captain Smith. Obviously Captain Smith has had personality clashes with different members of the Civil Aviation Authority. That is unfortunate but not atypical. This same Captain Smith was responsible recently for setting up the entire Ansett operation in New Zealand. He is clearly regarded as a very senior captain. The bulk of the Civil Aviation Authority people have found him to be so, as they have been prepared to put him in that position. All these activities occurred well before the pilots dispute. Any criticism-again, the advice of the Civil Aviation Authority-of Captain Smith has not been borne out by the performance of the pilots whom he has trained and who have been independently checked by experienced BAe check pilots and finally by Ansett's chief pilot.

Another aspect of the ignorance of the Opposition, now so long in opposition, about the governing process, is its inability to establish a relationship between a leaked document of what purports to be conversation between two air traffic control operators and a Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report on the same incident. It is all very well for the odd air traffic controller, or a pilot, or a member of a ground crew, or anyone else in the aviation system, to have a complaint. This complaint is interesting but it has no real substance to it and no real value as an indicator of what may be a public problem until it has been properly considered by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. As the Minister tried to point out to the serried ranks of gibbons opposite him during Question Time, this particular incident was the subject of a Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report in which that organisation completely cleared the pilots of any wrongdoing. The Bureau pointed out that they were not off course; they were not going in the wrong direction; they were on course. The unfortunate Minister attempted to explain that to the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) and others during the course of his remarks but they chose not to listen to him as he attempted to mount his defence in that regard.

The simple fact of the matter is that to the extent that we have now had time to check out the repeated allegations and scuttlebutt that the Opposition has put forward in this place-as far as they can be checked out-every one of them falls down. These propositions are explained either as manifestly false or as products simply of assertion which have subsequently been counterchecked by more senior officers in the Civil Aviation Authority down the line and properly addressed.

That ought to be of great reassurance to the Opposition. It certainly ought to be of reassurance to the travelling public, as indeed should the statement by the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority. He is an independent statutory officer, independent as a result of our decision to give him that independence. That independent statutory officer has been prepared to say that he has not been under pressure by the Government to compromise the safety standards of his Authority. He is not a person capable of being removed from office by the Government. As a result of decisions by the Government he is no longer a public servant who is directly responsible to a Minister. He can state his course as he sees fit and he can state his views as he sees fit. He has stated his views quite clearly on this matter. They are: point one, that he has not been the object of pressure; point two, that on the particular complaints that have been made he has pointed out that they have been properly looked at by the relevant officers of the Civil Aviation Authority and found not wanting. He has also pointed out that there has been a matter of some dispute inside the Civil Aviation Authority for some considerable time now and at a time predating the pilots strike.

The Civil Aviation Authority has been responding to pressures, like those placed by honourable members opposite and others, about the speed with which the Authority carries out its procedures. One complaint made in that regard was that pilots who unsuccessfully completed examinations could be re-examined two days after unsuccessfully completing the examination instead of the normal 14 days. That does not alter the fact that pilots being re-examined still have to pass if they are to fly-whether they pass the examination two days after they initially fail or 14 days. The pilots who passed those examinations two days later under the accelerated procedures of the Civil Aviation Authority, did pass those examinations.

We have a situation where the Opposition attempts to seize on any particular item in this situation and attempts to cause public alarm and despondency because of the political position on this dispute. I do not take the same umbrage to the Opposition as does the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris). I do not see honourable members as terribly significant in this issue. They are more like a chorus in a Greek tragedy. Many features of this dispute are tragic. The protagonists happen to be ourselves, the airlines, and the people of Australia, whose economic interests have to be and are being defended by this Government in this dispute. Many unfortunate pilots have been misled by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. The Opposition is the chorus in a Greek tragedy. Its sole role is to wander around saying, `Oh, no', and attempting to look good. At least in that regard it has a Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) who is absolutely perfectly cast as an appropriate member of a chorus in a Greek tragedy. There is no need to consider this matter any more. The Minister has been well defended. He is a Minister in whom this House can have confidence. It will express confidence in him. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Jull's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) proposing a matter of public importance. I understand that the honourable member for Hume wishes to say something.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the eighteenth report of the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 298th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, entitled Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts-Activities 1988-89.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 298th report, the annual report of the Public Accounts Committee, will give some indication of the wide range of subjects covered by the Committee in its work. Time precludes a comprehensive discussion of that report, but I would like to highlight one particular initiative which is the centrepiece of the work of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee presented its 296th report on the reform of the Audit Office to the Parliament on 6 April this year. The report was entitled Ally of the People and Parliament-Reform of the Australian Audit Office. The report was the result of the first comprehensive inquiry into the work of the Audit Office in the 88 years of its existence. The Committee found that the Audit Office did not have the resources and independence necessary to perform its functions under the Audit Act to the satisfaction of the Parliament, nor had the Audit Office kept pace with reforms in the Audit Office in other jurisdictions.

The Committee made 78 recommendations, the most crucial of which were: firstly, that there should be legislation to establish the Audit Office as a statutory authority and to permit the Auditor-General to determine the terms and conditions of employment of Audit Office staff; secondly, that there should be repeal of the Audit Act 1901 and replacement by a new Audit Act and a new financial administration act; thirdly, that a parliamentary committee should be established to advise the Auditor-General on the Parliament's audit priorities and consider the Audit Office's finances in detail; and fourthly, that there should be the provision of additional resources specifically to allow for more efficiency audits so that in the next five years, 50 per cent of the Audit Office resources would be spent on efficiency audits as distinct from the 6 per cent which currently prevails. A further major recommendation was that the Auditor-General be reinstated as the auditor of all government bodies and have the right to appoint private sector firms as contract auditors.

This report has been fully supported by the Auditor-General, who presented his report to the Parliament on 7 September. There was only one recommendation to which the Auditor-General gave qualified support. The rest were given his full support. The Auditor-General has urged the Government to act to give effect to those historic reforms recommended by the Committee. Indeed, this has been the response of Auditors-General around the country and editorial writers of almost every major Australian newspaper.

The Committee remains totally committed to the report and believes that it is imperative that the Government accept the recommendations, as they provide a blueprint both for greater accountability and efficiency in government. The annual report that I have tabled contains summaries of the reports presented to the Parliament in the 1988-89 financial year as well as a summary of activities in current inquiries. The Committee notes that a Bill relating to therapeutic goods was introduced into the Parliament yesterday and that the resources for the Antarctic Division have been increased in line with the Committee's recommendations. In conclusion, I wish to thank all members of the Committee and the secretariat for their support during the year. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to move a motion concerning the death of Archbishop David Penman, the late Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(a) notes with deep regret the death of Archbishop David Penman, Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne;

(b) pays tribute to his life which exemplified service to the community based on an international outlook with a tolerance and understanding of others with differing views and from other faiths, scholarship, the forceful pursuit of ideas, concepts and ideals to advance the well being of Australians from all walks of life; and
(c) extends to all members of the Penman family its sincere sympathy in remembrance of an active life.

The motion speaks for itself. David Penman was a great Australian who made an enormous contribution to the development of Australia's history. He was a catalyst for action and at times created controversy. He realised that. I think he courageously involved his church in Melbourne into controversial issues. He took the church into the community in the broadest sense and he answered the challenge of the church in that way. He took controversial issues to the Anglican community. He gave the church that he loved so dearly that challenge, and he responded to it.

I believe that history will judge David Penman, the late Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne, as a man whom the Anglican Church needed at that time in the church's history in Melbourne. It is with regret that I have had to move a motion concerning the death of this great person. But I do so proudly, knowing that all those of the Anglican faith and of other faiths, Christian and non-Christian, had great respect for this great man.

TALK.START.PARA: — Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Archbishop David Penman was a remarkable community leader. His influence extended far beyond the Anglican Church of Australia and the Melbourne Diocese. His interests were global but his concern for individuals and for causes was striking. He was an organiser, a negotiator, a philosopher and a scholar. He had a rare understanding of the Muslim world, having gained a PhD in Islamic studies at the University of Karachi. He recognised that in the long term the cause of world peace depended as much on the resolution of conflicts within Africa, Southern and Central America and the Middle East as on the very welcome resolution of some of the outstanding areas of conflict between the two global powers, the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

SPEECH.PARA: I had some association with him, particularly in regard to his interest in African and Middle East causes. I had the advantage of having many discussions with him. He was an exhilarating companion, he had a lot of compassion, he was courageous and he was a man of vision. He has left us at a very inappropriate time and his loss will be felt for a long time, not just by this community but also by New Zealand, from where he came. He built up an extraordinary international network of contact with people throughout the world who recognised the moral force that he brought to his cause. His death at what seems to me to be the absurdly young age of 53 is something that we all deplore. I share with other members-still-a sense of shock and almost disbelief that he has gone.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship, which organisation Archbishop Penman assisted and to some members of which in particular he was most helpful, I add my strong support for the motion, and extend to the members of the Penman family my sincere sympathies. In the words of the motion moved in the Senate, I would celebrate with them the memory of David Penman's most effective and courageous Christian life and witness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that has been moved by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton). It is extraordinarily important that the House place on record its recognition of Archbishop Penman who, in five short years, made a remarkable stamp on the Diocese of Melbourne and an outstanding contribution in terms of leadership within the Church in Australia and the Australian community. He was a man who reflected, as most of us do, his past. Undoubtedly, his period of scholarship in Karachi and later his very extensive experience in Beirut and the Middle East underlay his very strong grasp of the issues involved in multiculturalism and his commitment to an understanding of Australian society which embraced that experience in an extremely positive way.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to add a personal note with respect to David Penman. When I first became the Minister for Social Security in this place he invited me to Bishops-court for an evening to meet clergy of the Melbourne Diocese, I think to get some indication of what my thoughts would be within the portfolio, which I think he understood bore some relevance to his understanding of social justice, but also to allow the clergy to present as early as possible to me their views on some of the issues that might be considered by the Government or me in the social security area. At that time I very much appreciated the hospitality offered by David and Jean, and I got a great deal out of that meeting in terms of thinking about some of the values and issues that are important in the portfolio.

I also recall the second occasion, when I was invited to attend a reception at Bishops-court to meet Archbishop Desmond Tutu. As has been referred to by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), he had a great interest in Africa; not only in African studies but, of course, in the course of events in southern Africa. I remember his obvious excitement and enthusiasm on that occasion, and then going with him and Jean to a great meeting with an overflowing attendance that was held at the La Trobe University at which Archbishop Desmond Tutu spoke for over an hour. He spoke without a note and had people quite entranced.

In my view David Penman was a very inspiring person, and his inspiration extended, as I suggested, well beyond the church. The recent weeks must have been an extraordinarily difficult time for his family. While I have had no personal contact with them, I have certainly felt for them during that time. I think all members of Parliament who recognise the great responsibilities that go with an office such as his would recognise that people such as David pay a price and would also feel, not only before but now, for Jean and the family in the period ahead. With those words and with great feeling, I support the remarks of previous speakers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not know that this motion was going to be moved; so I actually did make a 90-second contribution before lunch on the death of Archbishop Penman. However, I would like to be associated with the motion. David Penman and Jean have been close friends of my wife, my son and me, and we feel his loss very much. He had so much more to give the world and humanity and had so much more to enjoy in life, so it is a most tragic occasion indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: David Penman was all the wonderful things that have been said about him and, indeed, much more. He had a very indefinable greatness about him, including a truly great and gentle sense of humour. So I am delighted to support this motion on this occasion not only on my behalf but also on behalf of my wife and son. Children often have a capacity not to face up to the realities of death and not take death very seriously. No person's grave illness has touched my 10-year-old son more than David's illness. In the last two months he has been asking each day how he was, and it has been profoundly moving. I am very glad that the House has seen fit to move this motion for this very wonderful citizen of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to be associated with this motion, especially on behalf of my wife Anne, who has been involved in St Luke's in Frankston for many years and has also been involved in the action that has taken place in the church concerning priesthood for women. She has been quite active in this. I know David Penman was a great advocate of priesthood for women. He will be sorely missed by many people who believe that it is about time priesthood for women happened. He was a great man and did a lot for underprivileged people. He had a lot of battles within his own church, but he stood firmly for what he believed in. This motion certainly honours the memory of a very great person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) said he was not aware of this motion; neither was I. But I am grateful to the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) for bringing this motion before the House. I came from elsewhere the moment I heard it was being moved to at least associate myself with the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: David Penman was not someone I knew until he was appointed Archbishop. He was in every sense from that moment on a leader not only of a church but of significant movements for human beings throughout the world. We owe him more than we can express here. His tolerance, humanity and, above all, that sensitive and sensible leadership moved so many across so many socio-economic groupings. He is truly one to whom we can be grateful for, tragically, the short time that he was Archbishop of Melbourne. I trust that all that he achieved will be able to be followed through by whoever is appointed as his successor. He struck new directions, and it is important certainly from my own point of view as a member of his faith, his church, that such new directions which were forged be carried forward.

I will be attending the service tomorrow. In the meantime, I join with others in expressing my deepest sympathy to his family, together with the viewpoint that they can be aware that he gave so much which is appreciated by so many of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all members will share the comments that have been made in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems a very hard thing to do to move to less moving matters than the previous debate. On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the Committee's 299th report, entitled Compliance with the Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Compliance with mandatory reporting requirements for departmental annual reports to parliament should be a straightforward administrative matter. However, I believe that non-compliance with such requirements is a threat to our concept of democracy. The Public Accounts Committee was forced to produce this report I am tabling today because it found a substantial level of non-compliance. The reporting requirements for annual reports by the secretaries of Commonwealth departments are set down in guidelines approved by the Public Accounts Committee and presented in the Parliament by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). This procedure and the requirement that the reports be in accordance with the guidelines are provided for in section 25 of the Public Service Act 1922.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, in report No. 291, the Public Accounts Committee foreshadowed that it would review annual reports of departments for compliance with the relevant guidelines. This inquiry followed on from the Public Accounts Committee's report No. 262 in which the Committee considered the draft which became the current guidelines for departmental annual reports. Originally, this review was intended merely to confirm that the secretaries of Commonwealth Government departments were complying with the requirements that they include certain information in their 1987-88 annual reports to Parliament. Compliance by secretaries was, after all, mandatory under the Public Service Act itself.

During the inquiry the Committee became most concerned about the level of non-compliance with the guidelines. The concern was highlighted as the attention of each Commonwealth departmental secretary had been personally drawn to the guidelines by letter and, further, that the Committee had put on notice, by tabling a report in the Parliament, the fact that it intended to review compliance with the guidelines. What more could this Joint Committee of both Houses of Parliament have done to achieve compliance?

Even if departmental secretaries believed that the accountability requirements were excessive-and that is not what they told us-surely they can see that if departments do not report in the manner required by the Parliament the recent reforms in public sector management will be put at risk. Management for results and devolution involves a trade-off of more autonomy and control for more accountability. In this regard we were pleased to hear that some departments are taking steps to ensure that the problems of non-compliance will not be an attribute of the 1989 reports.

The Committee encourages all parties concerned with annual reports to take an active interest in ensuring that they are useful documents. If scope to improve the guidelines significantly is identified, this should be drawn to the attention of relevant bodies, the first being the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. For our part, the Public Accounts Committee has commenced a review of the guidelines which is intended to assist the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in redrafting those guidelines by giving a parliamentary perspective. The review will give the Committee an opportunity to consider its preferences for the guidelines prior to being required to consider the draft guidelines for approval under the Public Service Act.

The Committee awaits with interest the 1988-89 reports as they will no doubt comply with the requirements of the Public Service Act and thus provide information on the operations of Commonwealth Government departments. The Committee takes the view that the initiative and skill of departments should be reflected by their presenting the required information in a manner which is concise and accessible to the reader. At one of the public hearings of this inquiry one of my colleagues on the Committee said that the Prime Minister's guidelines seemed to have been `totally regarded with contempt by much of the Public Service'. I hope that annual reports will never again lead any of us to that conclusion and that this inquiry has contributed to that situation.

In conclusion I would like to thank my fellow Committee members, the various departmental secretaries and their staff and the staff of the Public Accounts Committee secretariat for their efforts in producing this report. This was not an inquiry which the Public Accounts Committee wished to conduct. In fact, it went to great lengths to avoid it. It has been an inquiry which has involved some considerable embarrassment to some senior Commonwealth Public Service managers. I am convinced that very important lessons have been learned as a result of this inquiry. Above all else, it has been a forthright assertion of the supremacy of the Parliament. I believe that that is a concept fundamental to Australian democracy. I thank the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, for Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The primary purpose of the Crime Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 is to review the Commonwealth sentencing legislation and the laws governing Federal offenders found unfit to be tried or not guilty on the grounds of mental illness. In addition, the Bill makes minor amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988, the National Crime Authority Act 1984 and Part VIIC of the Crimes Act 1914-spent convictions.

Although the Crimes Act 1914 was amended in 1982 following the Australian Law Reform Commission's interim report on sentencing-ALRC 15-to require that imprisonment be the punishment of last resort, except for serious Federal offences, and make State and Territory alternatives to imprisonment, such as community service orders, available to Federal offenders for the first time, this Bill represents the first significant change to Commonwealth sentencing law since the Commonwealth Prisoners Act 1967 was enacted over 20 years ago.

The number of Federal offenders in custody has been steadily growing from 244 out of a total prison population of 10,621 on 1 May 1985 to 517 out of 12,429 on 1 July 1989. These offenders serve their sentences in State gaols by virtue of section 120 of the Constitution and are subject to the same prison regime as State or Territory prisoners. This system can operate effectively only because of the significant assistance and cooperation that the Attorney-General and his Department receive from the officers of the State and Territory corrective services departments or commissions on a range of matters, including the calculation of sentences and the preparation of parole reports and such like. That assistance is greatly appreciated.

Because of the close association of Federal and State/Territory prisoners it has been the policy of successive Commonwealth governments to maintain intrastate parity of treatment for Federal offenders. The current Commonwealth legislation applies State and Territory laws relating to the fixing of non-parole periods to Federal sentences. However, the increasing divergence of, and frequent changes, both administrative and statutory, to State and Territory legislation have resulted in increasing use of administrative measures to ensure that Federal offenders are not disadvantaged.

In late 1988 the final report of the Australian Law Reform Commission on sentencing-ALRC 44-was tabled in Parliament. It is therefore timely that further and more significant amendments be made. The reform and review of the sentencing legislation to ensure its fairness and effectiveness and to ensure community confidence in the ability of the criminal justice system to deal with offenders are an important part of the Government's fight against crime, particularly organised crime. The new sentencing proposals are intended to complement the other major legislative initiatives by the Government in this area, including the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987, the Extradition Act 1988, the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988, the 1989 amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 to enable superannuation to be forfeited where a police officer is convicted of a corruption offence, and the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill 1989.

The Government believes that there is a need for a separate Commonwealth sentencing regime to ensure that Federal offenders are not disadvantaged because of the complex legal problems that may arise in a Federal system. This Bill provides a sentencing regime for Federal offenders which pursues the aims of certainty and fairness.

The requirement that imprisonment be the punishment of last resort has been strengthened. But where a court determines that a sentence of imprisonment is the appropriate penalty, that sentence will be certain. The Bill provides that where a Federal offender is sentenced to imprisonment, if the court fixes a non-parole period or makes an order for release on recognisance-a form of bond-this is the period that the person will actually serve in custody before parole eligibility arises or the person becomes eligible to be released on recognisance. Such periods will not be reduced by remissions from the non-parole or pre-release periods.

Great care has been taken to ensure that establishing certainty in sentencing does not result in harsher or longer prison terms. In those States where remissions reduce State non-parole periods, the Bill specifically provides that a Federal offender is to have his or her non-parole adjusted to take into account that it will not be reduced by remission. The Bill requires that the court explain to the person that the sentence of imprisonment is made up of a period to be served in custody and a period in the community subject to conditions either on parole or on recognisance.

As Federal offenders are persons who have been convicted of offences against Commonwealth law-for example, the importation of narcotic drugs, money laundering and fraud on the Commonwealth-they will include principals in large scale operations as well as persons who have played minor roles in such offences or persons who have committed relatively minor offences. Federal sentencing legislation therefore needs to provide a range of sanctions to enable the sentencing court to choose the sentence that is appropriate and proportionate to the offence. Although this Bill deals mainly with Federal offenders who are sentenced to imprisonment, it also ensures that a greater range of alternatives to imprisonment is available to persons convicted of Federal offences.

In addition to these important matters, this Bill also provides an innovative and humanitarian regime to deal with the difficult and frequently overlooked problem of mentally ill and intellectually disabled persons who come into contact with the criminal justice system. The existing legislation only provides limited options to deal with a person who has been charged with an indictable Federal offence where there is a finding of unfitness to be tried or not guilty on the grounds of mental illness. One of the most serious criticisms of the existing law is that a person may be kept in custody indefinitely, without any statutory requirement that his or her case be reviewed. Moreover, a person found unfit to be tried is kept in custody indefinitely without even a prima facie case being established that he or she committed the alleged offence.

The Bill provides a new regime for dealing with persons who are found unfit to plead, or unfit to be tried or not guilty on the grounds of mental illness. Sentencing courts are also being given additional options for persons who are mentally ill or intellectually disabled. The Bill gives magistrates courts greatly increased options when dealing with cases summarily. Hospital orders will be available in lieu of imprisonment, where mental illness has contributed to the commission of serious offences. Special bonds will also be available-psychiatric probation orders for mentally ill offenders, and program probation orders for intellectually disabled offenders. The new sentencing options of hospital orders and bonds give effect to the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendations.
Contents of Bill
A detailed explanation of the contents of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum. Accordingly the Attorney-General wishes only to refer to the more important features of the Bill:
The Bill repeals the Commonwealth Prisoners Act 1967 and amends the Crimes Act 1914 to consolidate all the general sentencing legislation in that Act.

Remissions that currently reduce the non-parole periods of Federal sentences in some States will not apply to sentences imposed after commencement, except remissions granted for prison warders strikes. In those States where remissions off the non-parole period apply, the courts are specifically instructed to take account of the fact that they will not apply to Federal offenders and to adjust the non-parole period accordingly.

Remissions that reduce the total-or head-sentence will continue to apply, if available under State law. In those States where remissions on the head sentence are not available, only New South Wales at present, the courts are specifically required to take this into account so that Federal offenders are not serving longer sentences because of the abolition of remissions for State prisoners.
Federal offenders sentenced to imprisonment prior to the commencement of the Bill will continue to have their non-parole periods reduced by remissions available under State or Territory legislation.

The new legislation provides for a Federal scheme for setting non-parole periods, instead of relying on State/Territory law. A non-parole period may only be set where the sentence is greater than three years.

Where the sentence is three years or less, and the court considers that the person should be released from prison subject to conditions, then, at the time of sentencing, the court may make an order for the person's release on recognisance, a bond subject to court imposed conditions relating to good behaviour and supervision et cetera.

Consistent with the Government's view that there should be certainty in sentencing, the Bill provides that a court sentencing a Federal offender to a life sentence may fix a non-parole period. A Federal offender serving a life sentence with non-parole period at the time this legislation comes into force, may apply to a court to have a non-parole period fixed. It is not mandatory that a court fix a non-parole period for a life sentence.

Where the sentence is greater than three years but less than 10 years and a non-parole period is specified, release on parole is to be automatic on completion of the imprisonment period with the Attorney-General setting conditions, where appropriate.

If the sentence is greater than 10 years, including a life sentence where a non-parole period is set, there is a presumption in favour of release on parole upon completion of the non-parole period. However, in these cases the Attorney-General has a discretion to defer release on parole. Where release on parole is deferred the Attorney-General must provide the prisoner with reasons for the deferral.
The Bill retains the `release on licence' mechanism to permit early release where a prisoner establishes exceptional circumstances.
The releasing authority for parolees and licensees will be the Attorney-General, instead of the Governor-General.
Procedures for the revocation of parole orders and licences have been revised.

The Bill provides that State or Territory pre-release schemes may be prescribed, subjected to eligibility conditions. These schemes enable select State or Territory prisoners to be released shortly before a non-parole period is served or a sentence has been served. Prisoners are subject to strict conditions and supervision while on these schemes. Any regulations prescribing a scheme will, of course, be subject to section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, which permits a regulation to be disallowed by either House of Parliament.
The Bill provides a new regime where a person, charged on indictment with a Federal offence, is found unfit to plead or be tried, or is found not guilty on the grounds of mental illness.

These changes, for persons found unfit to be tried, include procedures for determining whether the prosecution has established a prima facie case, and for establishing the person's likely fitness to stand trial within 12 months. Where a court finds the person will not become fit to be tried the person may be released on a bond or placed in custody for a period not exceeding the maximum penalty for the offence.

If a jury finds a person not guilty on the ground of mental illness, the court may either release the person with or without conditions or make an order for his or her detention in custody for a period not exceeding the maximum penalty for the offence.

In cases where a person is ordered to be held in custody either because he or she is not fit to be tried or has been found not guilty on the ground of mental illness, the Bill provides for regular review of the detention and for his or her release by the Attorney-General.

The Bill also contains a number of minor amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988, the National Crime Authority Act 1984, and the Crimes Act 1914. The substantive thrust of the Cash Transaction Reports Act is contained in provisions of the Act that are not yet in force. Honourable members will no doubt appreciate that it has taken time to establish the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, which is pivotal to the operation of the legislation. The Attorney-General is pleased to inform the House that the Agency is now in place and the substantive provisions of the Act are to come into force progressively from 1 January 1990. The staff of the Agency have been involved in extensive liaison and consultation with financial institutions, other cash dealers affected by the Act and law enforcement agencies. As a result of this process it became clear that the Act required finetuning. The amendments contained in this Bill will greatly enhance the implementation process and the effectiveness of the legislation. Certain amendments, such as that removing the requirement for an identification reference to be a statutory declaration have been made following representations from financial institutions.
The balance of the amendments to the Act, and those to the other Acts, are minor and self-explanatory. Those are the major features of the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989.
Financial Impact Statement

There is not expected to be any significant increase in costs or expenditure from the measures proposed in this Bill. In fact, savings in administration costs are anticipated from the abolition of remissions on non-parole periods and the introduction of automatic parole. On behalf of the Attorney-General, I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill would amend social security and veterans' affairs legislation to implement some of the measures announced in the Budget this year and several other program refinements of a mainly administrative nature. It also contains measures to enhance the effectiveness of the child support scheme. Over the past six years the Government has rebuilt the integrity of Australia's social security system. We have substantially amended legislation to support an overhaul of administrative systems. This Bill would amend the Social Security Act to continue this reform. Compensation recovery mechanisms will be made much more effective, family allowance and family allowance supplement procedures will be refined, assessment of domestic circumstances of sole parent pensioners will be overhauled, deferment periods for education leavers applying for benefits will be adjusted and unemployment and sickness benefits will not be payable to people who refuse to provide or apply for a tax file number.

Three amendments in the area of compensation recovery promote the administrative integrity of the social security system and help to ensure that the funds made available by the Australian public for social security go to those who most need them. Under present arrangements which apply where compensation payments and social security benefits overlap, the Department of Social Security tries to recover any money from the employer or the insurer. However, some employers and insurers pay out compensation before recovery is made even though they may have been alerted by the Department. This Bill makes it possible for the Department to take recovery action against employers or insurers to redress this situation.

The Bill tightens the Department's recovery powers to ensure that State compensation bodies participate in proper recovery arrangements. This Bill also provides that any outstanding money still owed to the Department once a client has been paid compensation may be recovered from his or her continuing social security entitlement.

Mr Deputy Speaker, sole parent pensions are payable to people caring for children who are not married nor living in a de facto relationship and to people caring for children whose spouse is in prison. It is paid because of the very special hardships and disadvantages caused by bringing up children alone. The administration of sole parent pension requires assessment of the domestic circumstances of some claimants and pensioners, to determine whether they are unmarried and not living in a de facto relationship. That aspect of administration has been most unsatisfactory for clients and staff of the Department. Without any clear legislative provisions, staff have been left to administer a program without clear rules and with no clear procedures. The results have necessarily been intensive investigations and arbitrary decision making.

This Bill would specify clearly the process for decision making in these cases. It would enable the Department to require sole parent pensioners and claimants for pension who are living in a de facto or marriage relationship to fully disclose their domestic circumstances to the Department. It would provide that, where this is done, the Department must weigh the evidence with a clear list of relevant indicia set out in the legislation and make a decision whether the person is, or is not, entitled to pension. The legislation would provide that, in the rare case when a decision maker is unable to come to a clear conclusion one way or the other, pension should cease, subject to continuation of pension pending resolution of any appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

The legislation would also provide that, when a pensioner or claimant has fully and honestly disclosed his or her domestic circumstances to the Department and it has been decided that he or she is entitled to pension, there should be no further investigation of the domestic circumstances of that person for 12 weeks, unless there is a significant change of circumstances. In this way, the Bill would guarantee a decision-making process which recognises the complexity of many cases in this area, and protects clients and staff from the indignity and arbitrariness of current arrangements.

The legislation would also specify-for the first time-matters which decision-makers must take into account in determining marital status issues for all purposes under the Social Security Act. This would lead to more structured, more consistent interviewing and decision making on these issues across all pensions, benefits and allowances.

The Bill refines provisions relating to family allowance supplement (FAS) when family income has fallen. These amendments flow from practical experience with the FAS program. Under current arrangements, families may qualify for FAS if their taxable income for the financial year ending in the previous calendar year is below certain levels. If the family's previous taxable income was higher than these levels, but its income has dropped so that taxable income in the current financial year will be at least 25 per cent less, the family can qualify for FAS on the basis of its current financial year's income.

From December 1989, FAS will be payable, even if the drop in income is less than 25 per cent, as long as total income is expected to be below the FAS income threshold. To preserve the effect of this amendment into the next entitlement year, families will retain their new, higher entitlement if this would make them better off than under a normal assessment based on their income for the previous financial year.

The Bill would provide for reassessments of FAS following amended assessments by the Australian Taxation Office or taxable income for the year which is the basis of a FAS entitlement. Under the provisions in the Bill, a downwards reassessment of taxable income would trigger FAS arrears for the client. With an upwards reassessment, an overpayment and reduction in FAS rate would occur only if the reassessment was more than 25 per cent higher.

Another amendment ensures that low income parents who are fulltime students receiving Austudy or a similar payment will not be excluded from entitlement to FAS through the operation of the income test. FAS will now be payable to these people at the maximum rate subject to the assets test.

From January 1998, the family allowance provisions will be changed to require recipients to inform the Department of certain notifiable events which occur during the calendar year. Events such as the allowee starting a new job or getting married are likely to generate an increase in income and, therefore, might affect the family allowance rate payable. Prescribing notifiable events in this way puts the family allowance system on a similar footing to FAS.

A refinement is also being made to the FAS notifiable events arrangements. Currently, FAS can be reassessed where a family's income increases following a notifiable event but only if the event occurred after FAS had been granted. It will now be possible to take into account a notifiable event occurring before grant to arrive at a fair and accurate entitlement.

This Bill includes a number of refinements to the unemployment benefit system to strengthen its principles of providing support to people when they need it, providing opportunities and incentives to unemployed people to get back to work and, in return for the community's support, requiring recipients to utilise the opportunities available to them.

In order to encourage school leavers who become unemployed to commence job search immediately, the four-week period of grace for education leavers to register with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) after leaving study will be abolished from October 1989. This means that the standard 13-week deferment period which applies to all education leavers would run from the date of CES registration as long as a claim for benefit was lodged within two weeks of that date. The Bill stresses the importance of job search by providing that, when a young person registers with the CES before finishing school, that registration would date from the last day of school for benefit purposes.

The requirements for payment of unemployment benefit and job search allowance include the need for the client to be actively seeking suitable work. It is often difficult to assess this when that person moves to an area where there are low employment prospects. At present, once a person has moved to such an area, it is usually sufficient for benefit purposes if he or she can demonstrate satisfactory attempts to find work in that area. The Bill turns this situation around in cases where there are no good reasons for making such a move. In future, a recipient of unemployment benefit or job search allowance who moves address and reduces his or her employment prospects as a result will have his or her benefit cancelled and, on reapplication, will have to serve a waiting period of 12 weeks. This rule will not apply when the move is to live with or near a family member of the beneficiary.

The Bill would provide for unemployment and sickness benefit to not be payable when the beneficiary does not provide, and will not apply for, a tax file number. At present, unemployment and sickness beneficiaries who fail to supply their tax file number are taxed at the top marginal rate of 50.25 per cent including the Medicare levy. As from November 1989, benefit will not be payable if claimants do not either supply a tax file number or agree to request one from the Australian Taxation Office. Any current beneficiaries who have not supplied a number by the date of effect or who are not prepared to request a tax file number will forfeit their benefit.

Lastly, this Bill incorporates minor amendments to strengthen the child support scheme. The special maintenance income concession for pensioners and beneficiaries who are eligible to apply for administratively assessed child support under stage 2 would be available only if an application is made to maximise recurrent cash entitlements under child support assessment legislation. The Child Support (Assessment) Act would ensure that child support agreements, instruments and orders are exempt from State and Territory stamp duties.

The Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act would be amended to ensure automatic withholding from salary or wages can be effectively and speedily applied in every case when a non-custodial parent defaults, regardless of the date of the order giving rise to the liability. It would also be made clear that automatic withholding can be used by the Child Support Agency to collect arrears of maintenance owing to it.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned).

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to put arrangements in place for the provision of general purpose assistance to the States and the Northern Territory in 1989-90, consistent with the decisions taken at the May 1989 Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting. The Bill will replace the States Grants (General Revenue) Act 1988 and the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act 1988. Both forms of general purpose assistance-general revenue grants and general purpose capital funds-are being provided under one Bill this year, because, as I will mention later, the arrangements for general purpose capital assistance are to be simplified in 1989-90.

The current estimate of general purpose funding for the States and the Northern Territory under the Bill totals $13,135m, or about 15 per cent of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays in 1989-90. As such, these payments constitute a major element of the Commonwealth's Budget. In combination with the global borrowing limits agreed at the Loan Council meeting, they also have a major bearing on the spending and borrowing of State governments.

General purpose payments to the States and the Northern Territory are estimated to decline by around 3 per cent in real terms in 1989-90. While the real reduction in general purpose funding is less marked than in 1988-89, it will add to the effect of the significant reductions in payments to the States and global borrowing limits of recent years. These reductions in payments and borrowings have been a key part of our strategy to ensure that all levels of government in Australia contribute to fiscal restraint-something that is essential in order to reduce pressures on domestic demand and the current account deficit. As a result of the funding cuts agreed in the last few years, State spending has been more restrained. Together with the strong growth in the States' own revenues, this has led to a decline in the State sector's net borrowings. Further restraint in State budgetary policies, however, is required. The level of payments provided for in this Bill will help ensure that the States continue to share in the burden of restraint.
General Revenue Grants

Most of the assistance to be provided under this Bill is in the form of general revenue grants, which are currently estimated to be $12,825m in 1989-90. The vast bulk of this amount comprises financial assistance grants, but it also includes special revenue assistance to the Northern Territory.

At the May 1989 Premiers Conference, it was agreed that the pool of financial assistance grants in 1989-90 would be determined on the basis of a reduction from the Forward Estimates at the time of $550m in savings; and a further $45m to fund the special revenue assistance for the Northern Territory. This implies a reduction of $595m in financial assistance grants, but net savings from the Forward Estimates of general revenue grants of $550m. Consistent with the arrangements in 1988-89, both financial assistance grants and special revenue assistance are to be adjusted for the difference between the actual increase in the consumer price index in the year to the March quarter 1990 and the forecast at the time of the Premiers Conference, so that the real level of assistance agreed at the Conference is maintained.

The distribution of financial assistance grants is to be determined on the basis of per capita relativities determined by the Commonwealth Grants Commission in its Report on General Revenue Grant Relativities, 1989 Update. As in 1988-89, the relativities are applied to a combined pool of financial assistance and hospital funding grants. However, in 1989-90 the entire `incentives' component of hospital funding grants and certain penalty provision adjustments are to be excluded from the pool of funds to which the per capita relativities apply, whereas only funding for acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) was excluded in 1988-89. These amounts are excluded from the calculations so that they are distributed on the basis of specific factors such as the State by State incidence of AIDS cases, rather than the relativities.

The Bill includes provisions for each State's financial assistance grants to be reduced so as to recoup 90 per cent of the additional revenue available to the States and the Northern Territory as a result of the removal from 1989 of exemptions for Telecom Australia, Australia Post and the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation from a range of State taxes and charges such as stamp duty and land tax. It is estimated that the additional savings to the Commonwealth from this measure will be about $70m. Because the States will retain 10 per cent of the additional collections, the net effect of this measure will be to enhance their fiscal capacity. Similar arrangements applied in 1988-89 when the Commonwealth recouped 90 per cent of the extra revenue accruing to the States as a result of removing the exemptions from payroll tax for a number of Commonwealth business enterprises.

Provision is also included in the Bill to make appropriate minor adjustments to financial assistance grants in 1989-90 and the base level of assistance in respect of the recoupment of payroll tax paid by business enterprises for 1988-89.

As noted earlier, the Northern Territory is to be provided with special revenue assistance in 1989-90 at a base level of $45m. Four States, including the Territory, received special revenue assistance in 1988-89 to ease the adjustment to reduced levels of funding and the new per capita relativities.

The Government will continue to move the Northern Territory to a financial basis comparable with the States. If special revenue assistance to the Northern Territory had been terminated in 1989-90, however, the Territory would have experienced a substantial fall in its general revenue grants.
General Purpose Capital Grants

The Bill also provides for the payment of $310.5m in interest-free capital grants to the States and the Northern Territory. This is the same amount provided as grants in 1988-89 under the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act 1988 and is to be distributed on the same basis as in 1988-89.

The arrangements proposed for 1989-90 do not, as in previous years, provide for concessional loans for public housing. These loans are being replaced by additional grants under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA). These additional grants amount to $310.5m, the same amount as the concessional loans provided in 1988-89, and will be distributed on the same basis. The distribution of the new grants will be adjusted over the period to 1992-93 to correspond with that for other general housing assistance under the CSHA. Providing these funds as grants rather than as repayable advances increases the value of the payment to the States and should allow them to provide additional assistance to the public housing sector.

One further change from the arrangements put in place last year is that under this Bill the payment of general purpose assistance has not been made conditional on State observance of the global borrowing limits. Such a provision was included in the States Grants (General Revenue) Act 1988 in response to the refusal of Queensland to agree to the resolution of Loan Council which set the limits for 1988-89. All States have agreed to the resolution for 1989-90. However, should any State in the future fail to commit itself to the global limits or fail to use its best endeavours to observe them, the Government would be prepared to propose the reintroduction of the provision to this or future legislation.

No provision is made in this Bill for payments of general purpose assistance to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). However, provisions in Appropriation Bill (No. 2) allow for analogous payments to be made to the ACT.
This Bill is an integral part of the Commonwealth's financial relations with State governments and the Budget. I commend the Bill to the House and present the related explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Jull) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The the Bill be now read a second time.

This is the companion Bill to the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989 which I will introduce in a few moments. This Bill effects the repeal of a substantial number of provisions of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, as well as making other necessary amendments consequent upon the transfer of these provisions to part xvb of the Customs Act 1901. The rationale behind the restructuring of the Commonwealth's anti-dumping legislating is explained in detail in my second reading speech on the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.
