PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, together with the companion Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989, proposes a series of amendments to the Commonwealth's anti-dumping legislation, contained in three Acts: the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975; the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988; and part xvb of the Customs Act 1901. The amendments contained in this Bill give effect to two substantive proposals and some other technical amendments. The first substantive proposal effects the restructuring of the provisions dealing with anti-dumping matters into discrete taxing and non-taxing Acts. This has involved the repeal of a substantial number of provisions of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, effected by the companion Bill, and the transfer of those provisions to part xvb of the Customs Act, effected by this Bill. A detailed analysis of the repeals and transfers, including a concordance of the provisions affected, is contained in the explanatory memoranda to both Bills. The purpose of this exercise has been to avoid possible difficulties arising out of the High Court's decision in Air Caledonie International v. the Commonwealth. That decision relates to section 55 of the Constitution and the treatment of taxing and non-taxing provisions, and it has raised doubts about the proper placement of some of the provisions in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975. The Government has decided to put those provisions beyond doubt by transferring them to the Customs Act.

I turn now to the second substantive proposal in this Bill, which is aimed at implementing the Government's recent decision announced on 10 September 1989 on the inclusion of a profit margin when the `normal value' of goods is being `constructed'. Dumping occurs when the price at which goods are exported to Australia-the `export price'-is less than the normal value of the goods in the country of export. This `normal value' is usually just the price of the goods in the domestic market of the country of export. Sometimes, however, that price is unavailable, for example because the goods are produced only for export, and not sold on the home market; or unusable, for example when the exporting country is a centrally planned economy. The normal value must then be obtained in some other way. One such way is to add up the costs of making and selling the goods within the country of export and, in appropriate cases, including a margin of profit. Such a normal value is said to be `constructed'. One possible reason why the domestic price might be unusable would be that the overseas company had been selling the goods in its domestic market at a loss, for an extended period of time and in substantial quantities. Under subsection 5 (9) of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, which is to be subsection 269tac (12) of the Customs Act, such sales would be considered not to be in the ordinary course of trade, and their price therefore not be usable as a normal value.

In 1986 the Government asked Professor F. H. Gruen of the Australian National University to review aspects of anti-dumping policy. Professor Gruen's subsequent report made many recommendations for change, most of which were accepted by the Government. Professor Gruen in his report noted, and deplored, an increasing propensity to use constructed normal values. He noted, too, that such values could be substantially above the actual domestic price. He therefore suggested that the number of constructed normal values should be reduced to the absolute minimum and that this be achieved by repealing subsection 5(9) of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. He went on to say that, if this approach were not adopted, more realistic normal values could be obtained by not including a profit in constructed prices. In the event, the Government decided to retain subsection 5 (9) of the Anti-Dumping Act, but to tighten some aspects of its use. In particular, it decided that, unless there were strong reasons to the contrary, a zero profit should be assumed when subsection 5 (9) was being used. However, this intention could not be achieved by amending subsection 5 (9) itself. The operation of that subsection might make it necessary to construct a normal value, but the method of construction-including the matter of a profit margin-was specified in three other subsections of section 5 of the then Act, any one of which might be used in a given case. The amending legislation passed by this Parliament last year therefore included changes to each of these three other provisions. In each case, the amendment was to the effect that a profit would only be included in circumstances specified in regulations to the Act.

The same legislative package created a new Anti-Dumping Authority, which came into existence on 1 September 1988. Shortly thereafter the Government referred to the new Authority the question of what regulations might be made to prescribe the circumstances when a profit component should be included in a normal value construction. The Authority held a public inquiry into this and some other questions referred to it, and at the same time received and considered many submissions, and reported in March 1989. In its report, the Authority distinguished sharply between the construction of a normal value because subsection 5 (9) had been invoked, and the construction of a normal value for any other reason. Subsection 5 (9) comes into play only when prices, in the domestic market of the exporting country, have been unprofitable for an extended period. Under the Authority's rationale, had the sales not been at a loss, their price would probably have been accepted as a normal value and `construction' of a value would have been unnecessary. The constructed value should therefore take account of all costs, so that sales at that price would not be at a loss; but there was no reason to include any profit. The Authority went on to argue that, when a normal value was being constructed for any other reason, a profit should indeed be included.

The margin of profit allowed would vary from case to case, and could sometimes even be zero. Like other components of a constructed normal value, it would always be so chosen as to obtain the best estimate possible of a fair price within the domestic market of the country of export. The Authority reasoned that the inclusion of a profit, which might be zero, in such cases would improve consistency. A company, for example, might produce two kinds of goods, export both to Australia but sell only one on its domestic market. For the latter goods, the domestic price-which would usually include some profit-could be used as the normal value. For the other goods, a normal value would have to be constructed. For consistency it, too, should usually include that same level of profit. The Authority considered, and rejected, the argument that profits should never be included in constructed normal values, to keep these values as low as possible. If the construction process tended to lead to overestimated normal values, it reasoned, the solution should be found in revising the process rather than in compensating for the error by an arbitrary exclusion of profit from all constructed values.

The Authority also considered arguments that the level, if any, of profit to be included should be decided by referring to the conditions facing the relevant Australian industry, such as its need for protection against dumped imports. This argument, too, it rejected. The Authority said in its report that it could not, `. . . see how the current condition of, say, the Australian lampshade industry can conceivably be relevant to the normal value of (say) Egyptian lampshades sold on the Egyptian domestic market'. The Government has considered carefully these conclusions by the Authority, and agrees with them. In its report the Authority went on to recommend regulations which might be made under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act to achieve these effects. After consideration, the Government has come to the view that these same objectives can best be implemented by amendments to what was section 5 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act.

Under other changes proposed today, that section will become section 269tac of the Customs Act. Its wording, as proposed to be amended, allows a profit, which may be zero, to be included in a constructed normal value except where the reason for construction is that subsection 269tac (12)-the equivalent of the old subsection 5 (9)-has come into operation.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Jull) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I take great pleasure in introducing the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 to the House. The purpose of the Bill is to provide, so far as the Constitution permits, for the establishment and maintenance of a national system of controls relating to the quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic goods that are supplied in Australia, whether those goods are produced in Australia or elsewhere, or are exported from Australia. This Bill will bring together and strengthen various pieces of Commonwealth legislation to provide protection to consumers of therapeutic goods and to assist Australian industry both locally and internationally.

Therapeutic goods are those goods for use for the prevention, diagnosis or treatment of diseases and other bodily conditions or which can be taken to be for such a use through advertising and other means. These goods cover a vast array of products ranging from those that have become essential to maintain the standards of health and well-being which we have come to expect to those that are merely for our convenience. The range includes substances extracted from biological sources such as vaccines and antibiotics, the large range of chemically made pharmaceutical products which we see in pharmacies, test kits for the diagnosis of diseases such as dip sticks to monitor urinary sugar, and a diversity of other therapeutic devices ranging from cyclotrons to contact lenses to bedpans.

At the present time it is estimated that on the Australian market there are over 14,000 medicinal drug products and perhaps 25,000 therapeutic devices. This is an estimate because currently many products can enter our marketplace without prior recording or scrutiny. Several factors have influenced the average life expectancy at birth of the Australian population, which has increased by 15 years over the past 65 years. Improved sanitation, improved education about health issues leading to changes in personal habits and improved nutrition have all contributed to this increase. What is clear, however, is that the availability of modern therapeutic goods has played a major beneficial role in modifying the impacts and outcomes of illnesses and contributed greatly to the quality of the life which individuals now enjoy. Many therapeutic goods are, in effect, man-made supplements to the body's own mechanisms to maintain its health status. However this manipulation of the still poorly understood and immensely complex checks and balances that occur in the body involves a substantial risk factor. One has only to consider the personal catastrophies caused by thalidomide, when it was given to pregnant women, to realise that there is a narrow margin for many therapeutic goods between benefit and risk or, put another way, for a drug to be either a medicine or a poison. In the same way a poorly made or designed device may be a hazard rather than a help. The potential damage is compounded by the huge international scale of mass production and distribution of therapeutic goods.

Three parameters are used to define the acceptability of a product for therapeutic use. The first is its quality which refers to aspects such as its proper manufacture, the trueness of the contents to the label and its compliance with any relevant product standards. The second parameter is its safety, that is its lack of toxicity or hazard or at least that the product has an acceptable level of risk compared to the expected benefits when it is used as directed. This aspect is often demonstrated from animal experiments and the information must be assessed in relation to how and why the product will be used. Surveillance for unwanted effects must also continue after a product has been marketed. The third parameter is the product's efficacy, or its effectiveness in fulfilling its intended purpose. Of course other social and economic considerations follow from these product specific aspects, considerations such as the need for the product and its cost. These are not covered in this legislation but for drug products are matters dealt with by the Department of Community Services and Health primarily through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the National Health Act. Together, consideration of these factors made the major contribution toward the rational use of therapeutic goods.

While therapeutic goods are used in both humans and animals, the Bill deals primarily with those therapeutic goods for human use. It complements the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act that deals with products for veterinary use and which comes within the jurisdiction of my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). Many therapeutic goods are used on or in humans, with the individual patient often having little choice about whether or not to use the product, or being able, by themselves, to assess the benefits of its use against the risks. The complexity of therapeutic goods, the diversity and size of the industry and the real risks represented by many products are such that self-regulation by the industry is not sufficient. In recognition of these circumstances therapeutic goods are worldwide, subject to a relatively high level of control.

The Bill provides a standard of regulation that is recognised internationally as being necessary to control therapeutic goods and which will bring Australia into line with the levels of product assurances exercised and required by its major trading partners. The Bill includes the three major elements recommended by the World Health Organisation as being necessary for effective regulation and which are utilised by several European countries, as well as Britain, the United States of America, Japan and Canada. First is premarket assessment of products for human use, this being an independent assessment of the manufacturer's data on the product. The Bill permits the assessment of new products prior to inclusion on the Australian register of therapeutic goods. Secondly is the assurance that good manufacturing practices are followed in the manufacture of the therapeutic products for human use. Although a product may be judged to be of an acceptable standard and would appear safe and efficacious on the basis of the premarket evaluation, the standard of manufacture may be so inadequate that there can be no assurance of its quality or consistency on a batch to batch basis once it has entered the marketplace.

The Bill requires that most Australian manufacturers are regularly inspected by authorised inspectors for compliance with codes of good manufacturing practice as a prerequisite for holding a licence to manufacture therapeutic goods. Thirdly is compliance with set standards for therapeutic goods for human and animal use. The Bill contains provisions for setting standards and provides for regulations for the independent sampling and analysis of goods on the market. All parties-government, industry, professional organisations and consumer groups-agree on the validity of these means of protecting the public from unacceptable products. The Bill is designed to replace the current potpourri of State, Territory and Commonwealth legislation which has evolved in a largely uncoordinated manner over the years, resulting in both disturbing overlaps in controls and unacceptable gaps. The current situation neither adequately protects the public nor benefits the industry. The Bill does not in general greatly increase the current levels of legislation but will remedy identified unacceptable gaps. An example of the gaps is the lack of comprehensive licensing of manufacturers. In the 1960s it was agreed that the Commonwealth would provide a pool of expert factory inspectors and that the States would license manufacturers of therapeutic goods on the basis of the inspections. To date only one State has a comprehensive licensing system and recent evidence that the Department of Community Services and Health gave to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts revealed that many manufacturers do not have an acceptable standard of manufacture. The fragmented licensing controls have meant that Australia has been refused membership of international inspection agreements through which we could gain information on the standard of manufacture of imported products and which would assist reputable Australian exporters to enter overseas markets.

Another example of the current inad- equate situation is the lack of scrutiny of locally made products. This is because the Commonwealth powers to carry out comprehensive premarket evaluations of products currently rely on the provisions of the Customs Act 1901 which applies only to imported products. The Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 will rectify these deficiencies. It utilises the Commonwealth heads of power over corporations, interstate trade, and imports and exports. It will change the focus of control from the point of import to the point of supply and will provide a substantially uniform, national system of controls. Industry and consumers alike will benefit from the legislation. For the industry the controls will protect the good reputation of reputable Australian manufacturers by weeding out unacceptable manufacturers and products.

The Bill will apply similar requirements to locally manufactured and imported goods and many of the costly and frustrating differences in requirements that currently exist within Australia should disappear. The standing of, and confidence in, Australian exports will, I am sure, increase and we will be able to enter cooperative arrangements with other governments and regulatory authorities. This is essential, so that we can compete in overseas markets, for instance, in the environment of the 1992 proposed European Community's trade agreements. Consumers will have the protection and peace of mind of knowing that new therapeutic goods, both locally made and imported, can be subject to scrutiny before approval for supply and that the products will have been manufactured to acceptable standards.

I will now give more detail on the major aspects of the Bill. The Bill contains provisions to establish standards for quality for therapeutic goods and it will provide for the uniform application of those standards to imported, exported and locally produced products for both human and animal use. The British Pharmacopoeia and the British Pharmacopoeia (Veterinary) will automatically be adopted as the primary sources of standards. These represent sets of standards, mainly for medicinal drugs, which are recognised internationally. Uniformity of standards between countries is desirable to facilitate international trade and assists the Australian industry.

The Bill also has provision for establishing national standards by ministerial determinations which are called therapeutic goods orders. Therapeutic goods orders are developed by a committee established by the regulations, the Therapeutic Goods Committee, which has industry and consumer representation. The Committee must advise the Minister on any proposed standard or changes to standards. National standards are required where there is an identified and proven need and where a suitable international standard does not exist. These can be created by adopting standards from other sources such as other pharmacopoeias or, in the case of therapeutic devices, standards developed by the Standards Association of Australia.

The Bill contains provision to establish the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. Inclusion in the register will represent approval for supply. It will be an offence to supply therapeutic goods in Australia or to export therapeutic goods from Australia unless the goods are included on the Register or have been specifically exempted from this requirement by the regulations to the Bill.

The Register will be divided into two parts: one part for registered goods and the other part for listed goods. Registered goods will require evaluation by my Department prior to approval for supply, the degree of evaluation being related to the perceived risks of that class of goods. This will include products such as prescription drugs, new medicinal chemicals and those therapeutic devices regarded as presenting significant risks to the patient. Where possible, existing expertise in the States will be utilised in the national system. For example, negotiations are well advanced to contract the Victorian Proprietary Medicines Advisory Committee to carry out evaluations of many non-prescription drugs.

The other part of the Register will be for listed goods. Listed goods will be those which by their nature and history of use represent a low risk and which will be included in the Register subject to compliance with standards and some other requirements relating to quality and batch-related safety, rather than a full evaluation. Included in this group will be most of the herbal products, the more concentrated homeopathic products, vitamin and mineral products and most therapeutic devices.

The regulations will exempt certain products from the requirement for prior approval for supply. These products include simple pharmaceutical formulations for external application and therapeutic devices which are seen as presenting no greater risk than consumer goods in everyday use. Also exempted are personal imports; that is, products for a person's own use or use by the immediate family, which are produced overseas and not available in Australia, provided the products are not injections or are not specifically prohibited. However, the current conditions for a personal import will be tightened to include a limit on the quantity imported of three months supply at the maximum dose of a medicinal drug recommended by the manufacturer. If it becomes evident that this exemption is being abused, it may be necessary at a later stage to amend this exemption.

Special provisions will also apply to goods not on the Register which are for use in treatment of specific individuals where other treatments have failed and to products for use in clinical trials. Although these goods will be exempt from inclusion in the Register, the Bill contains specific requirements for their supply. Products legally on the market at the time of commencement of the legislation will be entitled to immediate entry into the Register following application by the sponsor. Many of those will not have been evaluated and it is proposed to evaluate relevant products in this grandfathered category if the need arises, or selectively as resources in my Department permit.

It is possible that some products which have previously been rejected by the Victorian Proprietary Medicines Advisory Committee, yet which are legally sold on the Australian market, will be grandfathered. It is intended that these products will be reviewed as quickly as possible to decide whether each should remain on the Register.

The regulations will continue the existing expert committees which will advise the Secretary and the Minister on matters primarily dealing with the pre-market evaluation of products. These committees are the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee and the Therapeutic Device Evaluation Committee.

The other major part of the Bill is the provision to license Australian manufacturers. The issue of a licence will depend upon compliance with the Australian codes of good manufacturing practice which are of an equivalent standard to the codes of other major countries. A manufacturer's licence will be issued to cover a range of products which the manufacturer has sufficient expertise to produce. Manufacturers of certain imported goods will be required to provide evidence of their compliance with acceptable codes of guaranteed minimum price in the country of origin. The appeal provisions within the legislation allow for internal review of decisions with ultimate appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The details of the Bill have been the subject of wide consultation with industry, industry associations, consumer groups, professional and practitioner groups and State and Territory governments. The original proposal for the legislation has been substantially modified to take into account the comments my Department has received.

With the passage of the Bill, many of those provisions in the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations which are currently used to control the import and distribution of therapeutic goods will be revoked. Similarly, the Act and its regulations will replace the current Therapeutic Goods Act 1966 and its regulations. It is expected that the States and Territories will implement complementary legislation to cover products and the few manufacturers which are not encompassed by the Commonwealth controls-for example, unincorporated manufacturers who do not trade interstate. Model legislation will be presented to the States and Territories which would effect this.

The Department of Community Services and Health has the expertise and infrastructure to implement the provisions of the Bill. In fact, Australia has gained international respect for its performance in this area. The Department employs product evaluators, factory inspectors for good manufacturing practice, and incorporates laboratories which carry out post-marketing testing of therapeutic goods. Some increases in staff resources will be required and these have been agreed to by Cabinet. Cabinet has approved a fee structure that will recover from the industry half of the costs of the therapeutics program. The cost of the program was about $30m in 1988. The most substantial fees will be for the evaluation of products for registration and for the inspection and licensing of manufacturers. Fees will be associated with defined standards of service and the utilisation of the revenue from fees will be reviewed by a joint industry-government committee.

The legislation will not only provide the means to protect the Australian public from substandard, unsafe and ineffective products but will assist the Australian industry in maintaining a local and international reputation for quality products. For the first time, this legislation will provide Australia with uniform, national and comprehensive controls for therapeutic goods. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts, in its recent investigation of the therapeutic goods program, expressed particular concern about the present lack of such controls. I commend this legislation to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I take pleasure in introducing the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989 to the House. This Bill forms part of the package dealing with therapeutic goods and the background is set out in the second reading speech to the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989. The purpose of the Bill is to impose annual charges on the registration and listing of therapeutic goods and on the licensing of manufacturers in Australia of therapeutic goods. Details of the scale of charges will be finalised and established in regulations after further consultation with the therapeutic goods industry through a joint industry-government committee that has been approved by Cabinet.

The scale of fees and charges under both Bills will be such as to recover half of the costs of the therapeutic goods program from the industry. The program cost about $30m in 1988. I commend this legislation to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: UPGRADE AND REFURBISHMENT OF SOUTHERN ENTRY TO ADMINISTRATIVE BUILDING, PARKES, AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Duncan for Mr Holding) agreed to:

That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the House approves the following proposal contained in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House presented to the House on 4 October 1989, namely: Upgrade and refurbishment of the southern entry to the Administrative Building, Parkes, ACT.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF COMMONWEALTH OFFICES, LOGAN CITY, QUEENSLAND

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of Commonwealth Offices, Logan City, Queensland.

This is a proposal for the construction of a three-level office building containing some 5,600 square metres of usable office space. The building would also allow for future expansion at the upper floor level. It is proposed to construct the building in the Logan City central business district on Commonwealth owned land. Logan City is approximately 25 kilometres south-east of Brisbane central business district and is a new and thriving community with a very high growth rate. It has a relatively young population with a high level of dependency on Commonwealth services, particularly in the welfare area. On the ground floor, the building will accommodate the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service-an excellent service-providing direct public access to their services. Upper floors would also house these organisations together with district representatives of a number of government agencies. Secure car parking is to be provided in the basement.

Currently, in Logan City the Commonwealth occupies about 2,700 square metres of leased office accommodation which is inadequate in terms of size, standard and location. This proposal presents an opportunity to overcome these inadequacies and at the same time to curb the Commonwealth's commitment to rental outlays. Savings for leased space equivalent to the proposed building over a period of 15 years have been estimated at $14m. The administrative and technical needs of Commonwealth staff in Logan City can be satisfied through well planned and properly designed office accommodation. There are also major benefits to the public of this proposal. Ready access to a range of Commonwealth services in one convenient location will be provided, as well as access for the disabled. The Logan City Council is encouraging office development within the central business district and believes the proposed Commonwealth development will add stimulus to this initiative. Two groups within the Department of Administrative Services are involved in the project. The proposal is sponsored, and will be managed, by the Australian Property Group, and will be designed and constructed by Australian Construction Services.

On 13 April 1989, the House agreed to refer this proposal to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for examination and report. The Committee tabled its report on 5 September 1989 and has accepted the need for the proposal to proceed. In its report, the Committee recommended that additional public toilets be provided on the ground floor of the proposed building. The Committee also recommended that measures be introduced to ensure the security of Commonwealth staff and records. The Department of Administrative Services will incorporate these recommendations when it prepares the detailed design of the building. The Committee noted that the existing policy concerning the provision of car parking spaces at proposed Commonwealth office projects is to be revised by the Department. This review has commenced and will take account of the Committee's comments.

The Committee also stated that the existing Commonwealth policy concerning the provision of child-care facilities in Commonwealth offices needs to be reviewed. The Government recognises that the provision of an adequate network of children's services is essential to facilitate work force participation. Consistent with its commitment to equality of opportunity in employment and its policies on affirmative action, the Government's policy on child-care is therefore to support and encourage community based work-related child-care facilities. The primary objective of the existing policy is to meet the work-related child-care needs of all families including those who work in the public sector. The Committee's comments have been brought to the notice of my colleagues the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who is responsible for the Government's children's services program, and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) for consideration as a Public Service condition of employment issue.
The Committee has recommended that the project go ahead at an estimated cost of $9.6m at April 1989 prices. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose this motion, but it is worthy of comment. The report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works is of considerable interest. It is as notable for what it does not tell us in some regards as for what it does tell us in others. We are told that the building is to cost $9.6m. That is in present day dollars. Clearly it will eventually cost in excess of $10m. This is while the Treasurer (Mr Keating) maintains interest rates at 17 plus per cent. Bank bill rates are 18 per cent. In other words, the Commonwealth, were it to go to the bond market with $10m, would be able to get 18 per cent for it. We are told that, although the present bill for the areas being rented is $304,900 per annum, somehow or other we are going to save $14.53m over a 15-year period, about $1m a year.

SPEECH.PARA: The interest bill on $10m-the opportunity cost of the taxpayers' money-is $1.7m a year. So it appears that the Government is converting a rent outlay of almost $305,000 to an interest cost, or opportunity cost in this case. The Government certainly does not make any calculations in this report as to the opportunity cost of the $10m of taxpayers' money to be expended. However, $10m at 17 per cent is $1.7m. So the rental cost of this building to the Australian people is $1.7m, whereas the private sector is presently providing it for $305,000. It is time that members of the Government, all of whom are notable for their lack of business experience, and headed by the world's best Treasurer, a union bureaucrat who, at the age of 24, came to this place where he has been a professional politician ever since, acknowledged that those numbers are not very true.

There are other aspects of the Committee's report which are worthy of reference but which received no comment from the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan). The first aspect is the concern of the Logan City Council about traffic matters. There will clearly be a cost to the ratepayers because the Commonwealth basically says that traffic is the Councils' problem. The Council has indicated that it sees an increase in traffic movements of about 60 vehicles an hour, and all the Commonwealth is going to do is change the median strip, primarily so that its clients can get into the building.

There is not much being done to assist the local authority. Of course, that has to be taken in the context that presently the Commonwealth Government is being extremely mean to local government and State road authorities in terms of the funding available for road construction. In fact, we are well aware that local government in particular has had to impose very large burdens on its ratepayers to obtain sufficient funds just to maintain roads, let alone improve them. Here we are going to have a very large building with a substantial increase in traffic movements, estimated at 60 vehicles an hour in addition to the 230 that apparently already pass the door. The Government's attitude is, `That is your problem, mate, you deal with it'. I guess that the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), who is the local member, will be trying to explain to the local ratepayers why they have to put their hands in their pockets so that the Commonwealth can concentrate all its activities in a single area and, as a result, worsen the traffic problems as reported on pages 12 and 13 of the Committee report.

One wonders what efforts the honourable member for Forde made on behalf of the local ratepayers. I see that the honourable member made a submission to the Committee. I bet it was all about, `Let's build it, it's a great idea'. But it appears that the taxpayers of Australia will contribute in excess of $1m a year for the privilege and the Logan City Council will be up for substantial expenditure in improving the road system, whereas I gather that at the moment these various offices are spread around the district and do not concentrate the traffic to such a degree.

We also have a similar situation with parking. The Commonwealth says, `We are bigger and better than local government. Your rules do not apply to us'. We see that happening quite frequently. The Commonwealth is going to provide only 120 parking bays when Council by-laws apparently require 265. Again, that will put extra pressure on the local authority. The local authority has a provision for cash in lieu but the Government is declining to provide the cash in lieu. It is suggested that the matter be reviewed. I think the Minister is suggesting that one day the Government will do so, but not this time. So there will be considerable cost to the ratepayers of Logan City. I am sure that the ratepayers of Logan City have not been made aware of this by their local member; their interests have not been defended.

The other matter is child-care. The Government, which wants to push everybody else into child-care, seems to be deficient in this area. Because of the substantial interest costs now pressing home owners, many wives have to work. About 30 per cent of women in the work force have stated categorically that they would prefer to be at home giving proper attention to their home and family but can no longer afford to. Family life should not be a luxury but women find themselves being forced into the work force because families cannot afford the Treasurer's interest rates on their homes.

Quite clearly, if the Government is of the view that child-care is a responsibility of employers, it should be leading the way, and I do not mean with institutionalised child-care at the present level. It should take advice from the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, and assist the individuals concerned. The Government could provide a private enterprise facility in a building of this size to assist those women who have no choice today under this Government's grand economic plan but to take their children to work with them or put them in child-care facilities. I am sure that if those child-care facilities could be close to the individual's workplace, many mothers would be much more confident about leaving their children and would be able to pay some attention to their children during the lunch hour at least.

There is going to be a review. That is another gonna. There seems to be quite a few gonnas; the Government is gonna do this and gonna do that, but it is not going to do it with this building. The honourable member for Forde is well known for her utterances on welfare issues, but she has clearly failed her constituents in this case. She has failed to convince the Public Works Committee, although it has made a recommendation as a result of the submission from the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. But, basically, the Government has not heeded her pleas and her constituents will be the losers.

As we say, the Government is here to govern. It still suffers from the belief that it is cheaper to spend taxpayers' money building buildings of this nature. It is building them at a time when it is demanding of the business community that it spend less. These hundreds of millions of dollars worth of projects that have been presented to the Parliament in recent times are a classic example of government expenditure which may or may not be necessary but which certainly will contribute to further overheating of the economy. It is strange that business is being told to pay 20-odd per cent interest to embark on projects of this nature so that they will stop doing it. That seems to be the Treasurer's desire. But the Government is going out helter-skelter in its marginal electorates building these sorts of programs. However, it is the Government. We are not opposing the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Refurbishment of the Reserve Bank, 60 Collins Street, Melbourne.

The proposed public work is the refurbishment of the Reserve Bank of Australia premises at 60 Collins Street, Melbourne. The financial system, and the Bank's role in it, has been transformed in recent years by substantial deregulation, including abandonment of foreign exchange controls and floating of the Australian dollar. In the case of the Bank's Melbourne branch, these changes have resulted in some staff reductions, an increasing adoption of new technology and economies in total office space required for a consolidated operation.

The Melbourne branch has operated from its current premises since it was completed in 1966. Although structurally and externally sound and well located for its purpose, it is in need of substantial internal refurbishment to meet current standards for accommodation, amenity and operational efficiency. On completion of the works the Bank will occupy wholly or in part seven floors, with the remaining nine floors leased to generate income, estimated at $2.3m a year.

The proposed scope of work will include enlargements and upgrading of the ground floor lobby, upgrading of all office floor levels, including removal of asbestos fire retardant material in ceiling spaces, and installation of new ceiling, carpets and building services, including the extension of a sprinkler fire service to all levels of the building. A three-level basement housing the Cash Department will not be refurbished as part of this project.

The design is being undertaken by private sector consultants and future design documentation and construction will be undertaken on a project management basis, using a construction management project delivery system. The estimated capital cost is $25m at June 1989 prices. Funds have been budgeted by the Bank. This is a significant public work and one which will materially improve the operational base of the Bank. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a reference to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. It has yet to go through the processes that have just been referred to, so the Parliament will have another chance to consider this work. The Opposition does not oppose such a reference. The amount of money being spent by the Reserve Bank of Australia is $25m. Considering its form of accounting, presumably that, too, will be a charge against the Australian taxpayer. On many occasions before, when the Government was having difficulties in balancing its Budget, it was in the habit of calling our attention to profits of some thousands of millions of dollars that were transferred from the Reserve Bank to the Government. So any depletion of that profit will be noted, as occurred with the deal done the other day between the Government and four banks, when $200m worth of Reserve Bank profits were transferred to certain trading banks. I add that it was done on a benefit ratio, compared to their housing assets. Certain banks get a 50 times bigger advantage from that deal than others. It is very notable that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was showing a degree of nervousness about that and trying to tell us that it was ordinary people who might miss out. It is not ordinary people. The customers of some banks will get 50 times less chance to benefit than the customers of other banks. We do not oppose this proposal. We will consider it again when it returns to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
