DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL DEBT SINKING FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 October, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Debt Sinking Fund Amendment Bill 1989 amends the National Debt Sinking Fund Act 1966, which is about redemption and repurchasing of Commonwealth and State debts. Its operations are supervised by a National Debt Commission which comprises the Treasurer, presently the Chief Justice, the Secretary to the Treasury, the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, and the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department. The purpose of the amendment is to take the Chief Justice from the Commission. As an Opposition we have no problems with that; it has been done at the suggestion of the Chief Justice.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an interesting conjunction that at a time when we are talking about taking somebody off the National Debt Commission the debt crisis that Australia faces is absolutely horrendous. This has been a wide-ranging debate and I find absolutely fascinating the way in which the Government is treating an opportunity to talk about the greatest crisis Australia has faced economically-our overseas debt crisis. I illustrate how important it is by saying that in the first 82 years of Federation our debt rose to approximately $35 billion; in the last six years of Federation, since 1982-83, it has risen by another $100 billion. If people were to put that on a graph they would realise the significance of what I am saying tonight: that this millstone around our national neck is horrendous. It will impact not only on my children but also, I believe, on my children's children because of the excesses of this Government and the lack of framework to prevent this rich country of ours sinking into a huge debt with enormous consequences.

The debt can be described in many different ways to get across just how bad it is. In 1983, on average, each Australian man, woman and child represented $2,000 in overseas debt. That figure is now past $8,000. In other words, it has quadrupled in six years. That is a quite incredible state of affairs for a country that is rich in mineral resources and agricultural products, has sophisticated communication systems, and until the last few weeks had an effective transport system. This country has gone down the chute in a quite dramatic and tragic way.

Another way of expressing the problem is to compare the net debt with that of some other countries. The net debt of Australia as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) has gone up by a factor of five in the last eight years. Just to get a comparison, we can look at Canada's record. In 1981 its net debt as a percentage of GDP was 25 per cent. What is it now? It is 24 per cent. If we look at Australia's net debt as a percentage of GDP, in 1981 it was 6 per cent. Now it is 30 per cent. We have a horrendous problem in relation to our net debt as a percentage of GDP. It is a huge change from the circumstances that Australia enjoyed only a few years ago. Per capita we are the seventh most indebted country in the world. In absolute terms Australia's gross foreign debt is exceeded only by that of the United States, France and Canada.

I want to read tonight from an editorial that appeared last year in the Australian Financial Review which brings home the reality of the overseas debt we are faced with, right down to the grassroots of this society. The editorial illustrates that overseas debt affects ordinary Australians and feeds through into the interest rates for small business people and housing. Ultimately the ordinary worker has to pay for the mismanagement the Government has imposed on this country over the past six years. The editorial, about 12 months ago, said:
Although few ordinary Australians realise it, the high foreign debt level has a number of effects on their daily lives-and the future of their children.
The most direct effect is on interest rates. Foreign investors demand higher returns in Australia than in countries with much lower debt ratios as they fear further depreciations of the $A.

As a result, interest rates on government and statutory authority bonds have to be higher than otherwise would be the case. These costs are then passed on to ordinary Australians through higher government charges and taxes.

Other interest rates-including housing rates-are also affected. If the differential between the rates on bonds and other government bonds becomes too narrow, then foreign investment falls and with it the demand for the $A and the exchange rate. In such circumstances, the authorities have no real choice but to let the rates creep upwards.

. . . At the same time as Australia has been borrowing heavily overseas, more and more of its savings are being invested overseas by Australian companies. While total private investment in Australia increased by only 5 per cent in real terms over the past six years, Australian investment abroad has increased ninefold.

That editorial in the Australian Financial Review makes a very clear judgment. That is not what the Opposition is saying or what I am saying; it is what the editorial is saying. It has predicted very clearly the pattern that has occurred over the past six or eight months in this country. Now it is ordinary Australians who are suffering. They are paying the penalty for the mismanagement of this economy, which has allowed our overseas debt to blow out to enormous proportions at this stage in our history. Our children will be paying for this in the years to come.

We could go on for quite some time about the way in which this impacts on the lives of all Australians. What is required to bring about changes to this great country, which has a great future if it is managed properly by a good government? I can suggest a few things which I believe are very important. There is a great need, first of all, to reduce demand for foreign capital. There is a need to increase domestic savings. We have to put in place mechanisms which will encourage Australians to finance developments in Australia so that demand for foreign capital will be reduced.

Secondly-we hear about this regularly, but the Government does very little about it-productivity should be improved in the workplace, in transport, in shipping and in management. Overall, our goal has to be to boost exports and to lower imports. We have seen how the Government's intransigence in regard to Australia's economy has kept the dispute between the airlines and the pilots going for the past seven weeks. Sadly, that is due largely to the confrontationist approach by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). This dispute would never have gone on to this extent if the Prime Minister had not poured petrol onto it. The opportunity exists now for a compromise to be found so that this country's productivity can be brought back on the rails. The way in which this Government has intervened in this dispute has meant that it has continued much longer than need be, and that is a great tragedy.

Lastly-we have hammered the Government regularly and asked it to do something about this-there is no choice for this country but to get wage increases, interest rates and inflation in line with those of our trading partners. This country will not make progress until we actually achieve that. The reality is that, even though the Government claims that our inflation rate has come down, it is still much higher than our trading partners' rates, and this is of grave concern vis-a-vis this country's future. The same applies with wage increases and interest rates. Australia will have a great problem getting back onto its feet with housing loan interest rates at 17 and 18 per cent and interest rates for businesses at 22, 23 and 24 per cent while our trading partners have interest rates of half that. Until we address these factors, and until this Government gets a grip on the macroeconomy of Australia, we will continually be faced with this huge crisis of our overseas debt.

I conclude my remarks by saying that we do not oppose what is being proposed in the Bill. However, it is significant that we are removing from the National Debt Commission a person who has a great standing in this country. At this stage in our history, instead of removing somebody of that stature, maybe he should be staying on and giving some firm direction, and not just legal advice, which was the purpose of his appointment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Simmons) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989[COGNATE BILL:COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 August, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill 1989 with the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Amendment Bill 1989. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to lead the debate from the Opposition benches on the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill and the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Amendment Bill. These are basically minor technical housekeeping Bills; nevertheless, I am delighted to have the opportunity to talk about borrowing and the performance of the Hawke Government in that respect. It is important to recognise, first, that a levy was imposed on borrowings on all Commonwealth semi-government authorities and government-owned companies other than those engaged in the business of financial inter- mediation such as the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The levy is currently set at 0.125 per cent per annum and is designed to take account of the benefit these enterprises receive in terms of access to financial markets by virtue of their Commonwealth ownership. By ensuring that the effective cost of borrowings to these enterprises is more directly comparable with that faced by private sector borrowers, the enterprises are encouraged to take full account of the cost to the community of their investment decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that I read that section from the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) was to draw particular attention to the nature of this borrowing levy. There are a couple of important points that need to be made about that. The first is that we should recognise that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) boasts on most occasions about his fiscal performance in the sense that he claims to have reduced the Commonwealth's contribution to the public sector borrowing requirement quite significantly over the life of the government, and draws attention to the fact that in recent years he has increased that Commonwealth Budget surplus to about 2 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) this year. It should also be recognised that the deficit on the part of Commonwealth Government agencies and corporations to which this levy applies has gone up quite dramatically and in fact now significantly offsets the size of the surplus that has been achieved on the Commonwealth's own Budget account. The obvious reason for that, of course, is that a substantial number of items have been moved off Budget during the life of this Government, and it is important to recognise that that has occurred.

I return to the quote concerning the nature of the levy, and the fact that it is imposed on Commonwealth semi-government authorities and government-owned companies in order to facilitate their access to international financial markets. It is worth asking the question: Why do some of these authorities bother? What are they really getting in return for this borrowing levy? When Australia had an AAA borrowing status in international capital markets it was something worth having, and these authorities probably did not feel too badly about paying a levy for the right to borrow as if they were the Commonwealth Government and had AAA status. Now that Australia's credit rating has been downgraded by Moody's Investors Service from AAA to AA1 and, most recently, to AA2-Standard and Poor's, the other rating agency, is now carrying out a review of our Standard and Poor's rating-I am sure a number of these authorities have started to ask themselves what they are paying for, why they are paying for this access when the bottom line has been a significant increase in the effective cost of their borrowing over this period. It was about three years ago that we rated AAA. The practical effect of the downgrading of our international credit standing over that period has been that the cost of borrowings to these agencies, as well as to the Commonwealth, has jumped quite significantly.

It is important for the Government to recognise that, while it might find this levy to be a very convenient revenue device for raising, in this year's Budget, about $11m from these authorities, it should look at the other side of the coin and at its responsibilities in relation to that levy. It would then run a much tighter, more effective domestic economic policy than has been the case. In this regard it is important to recall some of the things that Moody's Investors Service said at the time it recently downgraded our credit rating, for the second time in three years, from AA1 to AA2.

I think the most telling point was that Moody's drew attention to the fact that our debt service ratio has fallen out of line with other countries that were AA1 rated since September 1986, when Moody's downgraded us from AAA to AA1. Basically, Moody's said that the Government has failed to address our fundamental economic problems over that period. As a result, our debt level and service burden have increased dramatically over that three-year period. More important is the point that Moody's drew attention to the fact that Australia's relative external debt position will probably worsen before it stabilises, and that it will probably not stabilise until the middle 1990s at the earliest. Moody's emphasised that the Government has no medium term response to this problem.

Of course, the Government's own figures-produced recently by the Economic Planning Advisory Council through a number of scenarios that had been run on various econometric models around Australia, looking at the circumstances under which our international debt may stabilise, and when-led to the conclusion that the middle 1990s was probably the most optimistic one could be. In fact there are scenarios which, perhaps more realistically, show our international debt stabilising in the late 1990s at the earliest.

In making its assessment Moody's drew attention to a number of factors which ought to be on the record. It emphasises the Government's inability to control excessive dom- estic demand growth. In recent days we have seen considerable continuing evidence of that fact. Although the Government claims to have been addressing that issue quite directly and explicitly now for 18 months, by putting up interest rates and running a tight monetary policy, there is still very little evidence that the economy is actually slowing down. There has been, until recently at least, some evidence to suggest that the housing sector and other parts of the building sector are slowing down, but the most recent data even in that area has shown a pause, and the decline in activity in that sector has stopped. There are a number of pieces of anecdotal evidence running around financial markets now to suggest that the banking sector has increased its lending in the month of August. It will be interesting to see what happens when those statistics are released.

Here we are, 18 months after the Government started to tighten monetary policy, with record level home loan interest rates, even when the Treasurer has tried to hold down some of those rates artificially. Borrowing costs-that is, interest rates-for small and large business are in the range of 21 per cent to 25 per cent. There have been recent significant increases in Bankcard lending rates, in some cases, and personal finance rates and there still is not much evidence that demand is slowing down. The principal reason is that relying solely on monetary policy, particularly in an environment where both the fiscal and wages policies have recently been eased, will not necessarily slow the economy down in the near term; indeed, it can be counterproductive.

The Government has clearly eased fiscal policy twice in the last 14 or 15 months. It increased expenditure between the April-May statement of last year and last year's Budget, and this last Budget saw a further increase in expenditure. More importantly, the Government delivered unfunded tax cuts on 1 July. I am not about to say that tax cuts are not essential for a lot of people in this country who have been hit to leg over a period of six years under this Government, but they were unfunded tax cuts on top of an easing of Government expenditure in an environment of a significant easing of wages policy over the last 12 months.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure you can cast your mind back to about 12 months ago when the Treasurer first launched this idea of a wage-tax trade-off, and spoke of there being a zero wage increase in return for the tax cut that was in prospect. The tax cut in prospect was always around $20, but the zero wage increase was the key element of that trade-off. The Treasurer is on the record as saying that he thought there would be a zero increase in average earnings in return for that tax cut. By the early part of this year he realised that Messrs Kelty and Crean, the two de facto Cabinet members, could not deliver a zero wage increase and so he readily accepted a substantial wage increase. It can be summarised, loosely, as 6 1/2 per cent earnings growth for this financial year- 1989-90-in return for that tax cut.

That was the first major easing of wages policy. We are now in the midst of the second major easing of wages policy. For one reason or another, earnings growth has already broken out well above the agreed 6 1/2 per cent, and it looks like coming in during this financial year at somewhere between 8 per cent and 9 per cent at the absolute best. That is a substantial easing of wages policy and fiscal policy over the last 18 months. Indeed, in my view, the Government will be lucky to get away with an earnings increase of between 8 per cent and 9 per cent, under its centralised system and the pressure it is now under, in the course of this financial year. All the elements are there, in terms of the structure of the labour market and the extent to which that labour market has tightened in recent months, for a substantial wage break-out. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not talk in terms of wage break-outs any more. It all happens within the system. There has even been a desperate effort to get the contracts that have been offered to the pilots validated as if they were within the system. We will see substantial wage increases, whether they are within or outside the system, in the course of this financial year and probably beyond.

In all those circumstances the one balancing factor has been monetary policy. More and more weight has been put on monetary policy in the last 18 months. We have record levels of interest rates and no visible evidence that the monetary policy is doing its job. As I suggested, it is probably counter-productive in the near term because it has appreciated the exchange rate, cheapened imports and worsened the balance of payments. It has also fed directly into the consumer price index and worsened our inflationary situation. Finally, that sole reliance on monetary policy has stalled, if not threatened to work directly against, the much needed structural adjustment that will allow us to trade out of our present international difficulties. The only way we can turn our balance of payments around is by getting up our production, productivity and exports. A high monetary policy that is directly attacking investment and which in time will choke off that investment through high interest rates will take away the very much needed capacity that should flow through to create additional production and additional exports.

To go back to the first point made by Moody's, the Government has demonstrated a continuing inability to control excessive domestic demand growth. Secondly, Moody's mentioned the insufficient progress in generating additional export earning capacity and in restructuring industry to achieve productivity gains. Productivity gains are a bit of a misnomer under this Government. At best they are productivity zeros, and they may be productivity negatives because productivity is stalled and nothing in the Government's policy will see any significant recovery in productivity under the centralised wage determination process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except the employment growth.

—There has been plenty of employment growth. If I did not worry about the bottom line, I could create jobs too. That is what Moody's is saying: if we do not worry about how much international debt we have, we can create as many jobs as we like. The Government claims to have created between 1.4 and 1.5 million jobs. That represents, per job, about $65,000 in international debt. We could build the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) the biggest house in the street if we did not worry about the debt. We could buy the house next door and add one room, then another, then a wing and another wing. The next year we could buy the next house and so on. We could end up owning the street as long as we did not worry about the overdraft or the size of the debt. That is what Government members have done. The real question is whether those jobs will prove to be sustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a real threat inherent in the sole reliance on monetary policy. The Government will undoubtedly put already high interest rates across the board much higher before they do their job in order to stay with that strategy. Those interest rates will ultimately bite, the economy will come crashing down and all the jobs that the Government boasts about will be at risk. People in this country will then be locked into sustained high interest rates because of the external debt situation which has not been addressed, and will be at risk of losing their jobs at the same time. That is the only reason why the Treasurer is panicking at present and running all over the country to create circumstances to go to an early election. He knows that next year the circumstances will be a lot worse. The worst is yet to come by a long way. That is why the circumstances are being carefully manipulated and manoeuvred in order to create the atmosphere in which to go to an early election before the end of this year. The Treasurer knows that the worst is yet to come.

Thirdly, Moody's drew attention in its assessment to the continued slow pace of structural adjustment which makes Australia ill-positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle without further large increases in foreign currency debt. People forget that even the significant deterioration in our current balance of payments situation-as bad as it is, and it will turn out to be worse this year than the Government's forecast-has occurred in a period in which we have had very favourable world demand and activity circumstances and in which we have had very favourable world commodity prices. In that point, Moody's is asking whether we can imagine what that balance of payments will look like down the track if the world business cycle turns against us. If world activity slows, if world commodity prices fall, where will our balance of payments be relative to GDP or to any of our trading partners? It will be the biggest on our post-war record.

I know that honourable members opposite like to draw attention to the circumstances in 1981, 1982 and so on when, they say, we had a substantial balance of payments problem. But at that time we had a world recession and the biggest drought in this country this century. Now the current account problem is of the same order of magnitude as it was then, and in the best world circumstances the Government could have. Can members opposite imagine where they will be going next year?

TALK.START.PARA: —You were John Howard's adviser then.

—I am not one to take credit or to pass blame. I am just pointing out the fact that the situation existed in the worst world circumstances and the worst domestic circumstances. When circumstances started to turn around in late 1983 and early 1984, the Prime Minister ran all over the country claiming credit. Apparently he broke the drought. Clever fellow! As soon as that drought broke this country started to trade its way up a bit and look a bit better. I am putting to the House the argument that in those days the magnitude of the problem was about as big as it is now, and we have had very favourable circumstances. No wonder Moody's takes the point that I have just emphasised concerning the very precarious position this country is in going into the possible world downturn in the course of the next 12 to 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: The final comment that I wanted to take from the Moody's assessment of Australia which I think is very important, and one which must have got right up the whatever of the Treasurer, was the conclusion that the recent Budget did `fail to decisively address the issues of external imbalance and productivity'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member is ranging a long way from what the legislation is about in the matters he is now canvassing. Every five minutes he moves to a different issue. I suggest you return him to the Bill.
—I will listen carefully.

—The honourable gentleman on the other side does not like the fact that the bottom line of everything that I have said is borrowing. This Bill is the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill and I will keep mentioning borrowing every time, because that is the bottom line of all the points that I am making. I was talking about the levy on Commonwealth authorities charged by the Government in return for their use of the Government's guarantee. That guarantee is important in the context of this international financial market that I have drawn attention to. The cost of those borrowings is very heavily dependent on the assessment of organisations like Moody's, so there is a very direct link with the point that I was making.

SPEECH.PARA: To go back to Moody's final point, it emphasised that the Government's Budget failed to decisively address the issues of external imbalance and productivity. Undoubtedly the Treasurer was fairly shaken by all this. Let it be remembered that he took a particular dislike to Moody's. Who knows why, but in the last 12 or 18 months he has spent a fair bit of his time bucketing Moody's; in the Euromoney magazine and various other places. Where the opportunity presented itself he was quite happy to bucket Moody's and its professional standing. He took a very hard line when its representatives came to Australia to review our credit rating. He refused to let officials from government agencies like the Commonwealth Bank, the Reserve Bank and the Treasury speak to Moody's to put their side of the story. Subsequently Moody's downgraded us, and that was apparently totally justified by the list of facts that I have drawn attention to.

A second group, Standard and Poor's, the other major international rating agency, is apparently now in Australia. That is very important from the point of view of the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill. This time the Treasurer has decided to take quite a different tack. He is letting the Standard and Poor's representatives talk to officers of the Treasury and the Reserve Bank. He is trying to kill them with kindness, having failed with economic thuggery in the case of Moody's.

This country has a fundamental debt problem. It is the major policy challenge before the Government and it is one area to which it has principally turned a blind eye for six years. International debts have quadrupled over the life of the Hawke Government. Gross debts are now approaching about $140 billion. Net debt, netting off our international reserves, is about $110 billion. That is a phenomenal amount of money-about $6,500 to $7,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. All we ever get from this Government is false argument and misrepresentation as to the nature of the problem. Never do we get any serious attempt to deal with the problem or to create the circumstances in which we could trade out of it.

When Moody's recently reviewed our international credit rating the Treasurer attacked Moody's. Both he and the Prime Minister used the argument that the Commonwealth is not a significant borrower; that it is not borrowing on international markets now, and therefore it does not need Moody's. He forgot to mention that the Commonwealth still has a substantial amount of outstanding debt, the interest rates on which will be significantly influenced by any downgrading by an organisation such as Moody's. He also forgot what is inherent in the nature of this levy on the Commonwealth public sector, semi-government authorities and Commonwealth corporations, that is, that Moody's was not grading just the Commonwealth debt; it was grading the debt rating across a wide range of public and private sector organisations.

If one looks at the list of those whose ratings were under review one sees organisations such as the Australian Industry Development Corporation, the Australian Resources Development Bank, the Australian Wheat Board and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, in addition to the Commonwealth of Australia. One also sees private sector banks such as the National Australia Bank Ltd and the Westpac Banking Corporation. One sees various State government instrumentalities such as the State Banks of New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria, the State Electricity Commission of Victoria, South Australian Finance Ltd, the South Australian Government Financing Authority, the Queensland Treasury Corporation, Qantas Airways Ltd and so on. The Government, as the Reserve Bank of Australia annual report was quick to point out, has a widespread responsibility for our international debt. The bottom line is that the debts are there; they need to be serviced. Of course, the rating of the Commonwealth is only part of the story; the rating of all those other public sector and private organisations was at risk when Moody's considered our international credit standing a few months ago.

I have one final comment on the Bills. As I said at the start, we see them as a fairly minor housekeeping operation. They change the nature of the base of this levy. Two new authorities-the Civil Aviation Authority and Aerospace Technologies of Australia-are being included in the list of authorities subject to the levy. The Australian Capital Territory Electricity and Water Authority is to be deleted from the date of ACT self-government. In those circumstances, the Opposition would support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an extraordinary speech by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson)! It sounded like his speech during the Budget debate all over again. Undoubtedly that is what it was. The honourable member for Wentworth was not here when these Bills, the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill and the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Amendment Bill, were called. The Government had to call a quorum to get him out of the dining room. He then came in and simply repeated what he has said here a score of times, principally what he said during the Budget debate. It was quite inadequate, and it was the longest speech I have ever heard on a very minor Bill. In some ways what he said was interesting because he has changed his tune very strikingly. Only a month ago he was saying that the Government's policy was so tight that the economy would suffer a deep depression. He is now saying that the Government's policies are not tight enough and that we will not suffer such a depression. He seems unable to make up his mind. He blames the Government for not getting its forecasts right but he completely reverses his own forecasts.

SPEECH.PARA: His comments on macro-economic policy, which have nothing to do with the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill at all, deserve a little comment because they also were all over the place. He said that he wants wage cuts. It would be interesting for the whole Australian labour force to know that he wants wages cut. But he does not take account of the fact that because of the growth in productivity, because of the effect of the accord on the rate of inflation, real unit labour costs have already fallen substantially. He said that we had unfunded tax cuts. I am not sure what he means by that. In fact, we have a Budget surplus of $9m. Quite clearly, all the tax cuts that were provided were funded from existing revenue.

He talked about the need to improve the balance of payments. We all agree with that. But he would like an even tighter economic policy, an even tighter fiscal monetary and wages policy, which would drive the economy into depression. Surely what is required is not only control of imports, a reduction in the level of imports through some lowering of economic activity, but also a much more positive and creative approach to building up the level of exports. One of the principal successes of the Government is the high level of private investment. The present high level of private investment will lead to a better base for future economic growth, which will allow not only import replacement but also export expansion.

The honourable member for Wentworth talked as if he wanted tighter monetary policy. That would drive up interest rates. How else would he get the depression that he claimed to want? The real danger of driving interest rates any higher is that it would attract more capital from overseas, keep the exchange rate high and delay the kinds of adjustments to exports and imports required to remedy our balance of payments problem. His analysis and his prescription were internally inconsistent.

It is important to remember what this Bill is about. It is a very simple and modest little Bill designed to impose a levy on certain borrowings of Aerospace Technologies of Australia, the Civil Aviation Authority and subsidiaries of certain Commonwealth authorities and corporations; that is, to offset the benefit that those authorities receive from having a government guarantee for their borrowings. At present, the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act imposes a levy on the borrowings, other than from the Commonwealth, of certain authorities and Commonwealth corporations. The levy replaced the Commonwealth guarantee charge. The charge was imposed on bodies which used an explicit or discretionary Commonwealth guarantee when borrowing funds. Such a guarantee allows bodies to borrow at a favourable interest rate as repayment is guaranteed by the Commonwealth. So the risk of default is reduced.

During the operation of the charge, Commonwealth authorities found that they could borrow on similarly favourable terms without relying on a guarantee because lenders were aware that the Commonwealth was unlikely to allow them to default. As a result, bodies found that they could bypass the charge and still borrow on terms favourable to them due to their semi-government status. The principal Act which this Bill will amend already imposes the levy on organisations such as Australia Post, Telecom Australia, Aussat Pty Ltd and so on.

The other Bill that we are debating-the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Amendment Bill-deletes from the Act the borrowings of the Australian Capital Territory Electricity and Water Authority because the Authority now reports to the ACT Government, following self-government. The Bill will increase revenue by about $200,000 a year. The total Act, therefore, generates revenue of about $8.7m a year. It is a very minor Bill but it draws attention to a major reform the Government has introduced to the management of public sector corporations. The Government has corporatised most of the authorities in the public sector so as to devolve to their boards, councils or commissions the responsibility for the policies of those organisations. The Government sets broad guidelines for those boards and their senior management and they are responsible for the whole performance and functioning of those authorities. It is a dispersal of responsibility. It improves the identification of the location of responsibility. It gives them greater control over their own affairs.

The results of that corporatisation have been excellent. We had a particularly good example yesterday when the Commonwealth Banking Corporation announced profits of $866m for 1988-89. That is a return on shareholders' funds of 14.6 per cent. Some of the honourable members on the other side like to throw abuse at public authorities, saying that they cannot manage their affairs efficiently. I would like to hear them argue that a profit of $866m did not suggest a high level of efficiency and improvement in productivity. Another particularly good example of that high level of productivity is in the airline industry where Australian Airlines Ltd has had a better return on shareholders' funds than Ansett Airlines of Australia has had for some years. We know that in the last year or two Australian Airlines has notably improved its performance. It has a higher level of the air traffic in Australia than has Ansett and it has developed a very efficient method of operation.

It is relevant in this context to look at the Opposition's policies about public authorities because it does not impose any reasonable, gradual reforms like the corporatisation that the Government has introduced. It proposes instead the draconian policy of privatisation. The Opposition says that everything which it declares to be wrong with the public authorities can be fixed up by privatisation.

I dispute, as I have been doing, the Opposition's claim that there is anything wrong with the public authorities. Not only are they delivering their services effectively but also they are doing that particularly efficiently. The principal claimed justification from the Opposition is wrong. The Opposition has put out a policy statement-one of the few that it has released-called `Privatisation, the Australian Way'. I would like to look very briefly at the four reasons the Opposition gives for claiming that privatisation would improve the efficiency of these organisations. Let me say by the way that there is no evidence at all of a systematic difference in efficiency between the public and private sectors. It is a difficult issue to resolve empirically rigorously but various researchers have tried to do so. Their evidence suggests that there is no systematic difference between the efficiency of substantial, large organisations in either the public or the private sectors. There are some inefficient public authorities but quite clearly there are many inefficient private companies. There are many efficient public authorities and there are many efficient businesses as well.

The documentation that I have found on this matter-I have done a fairly careful literature survey and I will quote some of the more conclusive evidence-suggests that there is no systematic evidence that public enterprises are less cost effective than are private firms. It is quite clear why this would be so. There is a great difference in the capitalisation, the technology, the management skill and the market situation of organisations in both sectors and their performance will depend on each of those factors.

I return to the four reasons that the Opposition gives for claiming that privatisation is justified. The Opposition suggests, first, that that is a necessary condition for public authorities getting the funds they need. That clearly is not so. For a start public authorities can get most of the funds they need from retained earnings but to the extent that they need additional equity that can be invested in them by government using a borrowing that the government makes. It is not necessary to have a cent of tax revenue put into the equity of public authorities because the equity can be obtained by government through borrowing in the financial markets. The effect of that borrowing will be very little different from the effect of a share issue by a private business. There is no sense in which it could possibly be argued that borrowing by a government to invest in a public authority will crow out the private sector. The Opposition's first point has no rational justification of any kind.

The Opposition's second claim is that privatisation would lead to greater efficiency and an improvement in economic performance. I have already shown that the performance of many of the public authorities is extremely good. But the Opposition goes on to suggest that its claimed identification of poor performance in public authorities comes from, for example, lack of managerial autonomy. That certainly cannot be true because under the corporatisation policy of the Government, managers have autonomy. That point carries no validity of any kind. The Opposition claims that the public authorities' purpose which includes their community responsibilities inhibits their effective operation. That is certainly not true if those social responsibilities are important. The Government sets up those authorities largely to provide a service, part of which includes their social responsibilities. If those initial responsibilities are important it is justified in that activity going on in the public sector.

It is claimed by the Opposition that public authorities experience rigid and entrenched labour practices. That problem is being addressed through award restructuring. It is claimed that privatisation would increase competition. The Opposition cannot increase competition in natural monopolies, by definition. In the case of some of the public authorities which are already in competition with private businesses, for example, the Commonwealth Bank, to sell it off would reduce competition because it would increase the danger of collusion. I could go on and on but I will not.

The third claim is that privatisation would increase consumer benefits. That is clearly not so. The experience in Britain is sufficient to refute that. In the year after British Telecom was privatised the number of complaints to British Telecom went up by 70 per cent on its previous full year in public ownership. British Telecom concentrated on providing good service to business and let its services to domestic consumers drop right off. The level of efficiency of delivery on domestic services deteriorated severely. That is what consumers have to expect if public authorities are privatised.

The fourth point made by the Opposition is that privatisation increases the opportunity for employee participation. That can be achieved in lots of other ways, apart from selling shares to employees. The Commonwealth Bank today announced that it had bonus payment arrangements with its employees because of its good profit performance. That is an obvious way of ensuring that there is a direct benefit for employees from their high profit performance. None of those four justifications-the only four justifications which the Opposition gives in this paper-has real justification at all. They can all be shown to be empty and hollow. Clearly what members of the Opposition are proposing through their privatisation policy is based on their ideological position. They do not want the public sector to have any power at all to be able to operate on behalf of consumers in the community. They reject that leverage that public authorities give the Commonwealth Government. If they were sold, the situation for consumers and for the community at large would be severely undermined. I hope that the community at large will recognise that and oppose these policies of the Opposition.

That having been said, I am grateful to have had the opportunity to deal with these broad issues in this legislation. This legislation is a small step towards improving the corporate management of public authorities and I strongly support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill 1989 and the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Amendment Bill 1989 are a small but important step in implementing an overall government response to increasing the efficiency of the public sector and making sure that it is responsible in Australia's best interests. To put it in some kind of context, it makes sure that public enterprises are placed in a borrowing framework no more advantageous and no less advantageous than other commercial companies in Australia. They are treated fairly and properly in that environment. It fits in with a whole range of other government initiatives which are set out to make sure that the public sector in Australia is treated properly and with those objects in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just mention three other legs of government actions that have been taken with respect to Commonwealth government business instrumentalities. First, for many years government enterprises were not subjected to obligations to pay rates to local government authorities. That has been resolved and tidied up now so that such instrumentalities pay rates to local government. Of course, that decision has been a remarkable boon to local government authorities, which have collected substantial benefits, and it has put Commonwealth government business enterprises on exactly the same commercial footing as other companies that transact commercial arrangements in the community.

Secondly, these instrumentalities, these corporations, have been subjected generally to State laws. In the past, many Commonwealth instrumentalities have been exempt under the shield of the Crown doctrine and have not been subject to the ordinary State legislation that applies to other commercial entities. The Commonwealth is now tidying that up with legislation that was debated in this House just some weeks ago. Under that legislation, government business enterprises will be subjected to the full range of ordinary State legislation with a reserve power in the Commonwealth to make sure that laws which are aimed at discriminating against Commonwealth government business enterprises can be struck down by way of regulation. Essentially, that also puts in place a regime of law that treats Commonwealth government business enterprises in a proper commercial framework.

Thirdly, the Commonwealth has dealt with these enterprises, in terms of their own internal management and their structure, to make sure that they work on a much more goal-oriented method and without the kinds of constraints that were inherent in previously rigid structures in the management and reorganisation of the objects they are seeking to serve. All those policies are in place, not simply as incidental and random selections of policy, but as a coherent response to make sure that the Government gets the best out of its own government business enterprises. Referring to the comments of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), it is making sure that the public, which owns those enterprises, gets efficient results from a fully competitive and aggressively managed Commonwealth business enterprise sector. That is something this Parliament should be proud of; it is something that went without remark from the Opposition in this debate.

Let me turn to the contribution of the Opposition in this debate, because it really slid away from any substantive examination of these issues. I suppose I would have to say that the way in which the Opposition approaches policy formulation is one of the most interesting Stiffy and Mo acts that the Commonwealth has ever seen. We have the fairly glib reassurance of the recycled Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock)-platitudinous assertions-that all will be well under a Liberal government, and the kind of bland reassurances that are designed to soothe the electorate into some kind of sense of potential pleasure at his elevation. We have side by side with him the Hanrahan of Australian politics, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). He says again, `We will all be ruined before the year is out'. But we have been hearing this tune since Hanrahan became the shadow Treasurer, and we are still waiting.

What did we hear tonight? We heard a recycled Hanrahan with a slight variation on the theme of his Budget address to us. His peroration from the Budget night had to be recycled, because, obviously caught this time with his pants around his ankles, he was saved by the good nature of the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), who is seated at the table, who was courteous enough to call a quorum to permit him to come to the House, from whence his travails had taken him, to give us the wisdom that he sought to instil upon this matter. Unfortunately, the wisdom he instilled in this matter was by reading verbatim from the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris). When that exhausted his knowledge of the matter-and that was within about 30 seconds-he then gave us the benefit of what I thought was a most interesting digression-interesting because it exposed some of the positive ideas that really have made up this tirade from the man who would have us believe that we will all be ruined.

One of the most interesting things that he said was that we had unfunded tax cuts. This man, who has berated the Government and has said to the Government, `You do not understand your economics', said that we had unfunded tax cuts! This Government is running a surplus of $7 billion. What an extraordinary assertion for him to make. We then had the usual scare tactic about debt. One of the most extraordinary performances of a person in public responsibility is to repeat the kind of cheap gutter-press logic that every man, woman and child in Australia owes a certain sum of debt. When the Hansard is published, I shall be interested to see the exact figure that was referred to by the shadow Treasurer, because I suspect that, unless there is some doctoring of the Hansard, that will illustrate not only that he is a rather gloomy man but also that his mathematics are none too sharp either, at least in the heat of debate.

The point that is put forward is that somehow, collectively or individually, we in Australia owe some massive amount of debt. What nonsense! The Commonwealth owes not a cent in public debt. The Australian public does not owe anything in terms of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth, by virtue of its surpluses, its repayment of debt, its constraints in its own borrowing program, is now in a position where it is a net repayer of debt. The debt, such as it exists, is in bulk private debt. The growth in the debt sector has all been from the private sector.

Not one Australian man, woman or child, save perhaps for those who have not yet ditched their shares in Bond Corporation, will be subject to the slightest vagaries if Mr Bond falls victim to his present travails. Not one Australian man, woman or child, save perhaps those who have invested in shares in Elders, will be troubled by the fact that that corporation has borrowed extensively to finance its developments. It is quite possible that the investments that have been made by Elders are wise investments. I think it is unlikely that my friend at the table, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), will suggest that the investments of Elders are other than wise. Nonetheless, they are investments that have substantially run up the indebtedness of that corporation and they are the debts that are being aggregated and added together with the other corporate debts of Australia.

What is the shadow Treasurer really suggesting? Is he suggesting that we should reregulate the financial markets and put some system of financial controls upon the capacity of Australian corporations to borrow outside this country or within it? Is he really trying to become a dinosaur, a throwback of the Liberal Party to the pre-Menzies days even? It was an extraordinary tirade. At the end of the day the Liberal Party seems to be looking for some fortunate ill-adventure that might befall the country. We have the extraordinary situation where the Opposition is seeking to sponsor a challenge to an arrangement between the Government and the banking sector that will keep down the cost of interest rates to the public. Quite obviously, what members of the Opposition would love to see for their own selfish and narrow political advantage would be another rise in interest rates. But what contempt does that show for the Australian public? With what gratuitous foolishness does it think the Australian public will greet that kind of mischievous malaise? We have the kind of approach that has been used in respect of credit rating, the gleeful seizing upon bad news, the selling of Australia short, the looking for opportunities for Australia to be brought undone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am reluctant to raise the matter but I think one has to raise the issue of relevance. This Bill is about borrowing. A point of order was taken on the previous speaker from this side of the House about the matter of relevance. Whilst it is interesting to listen to the honourable member for Denison in this almost Shakespearian recital of his views, I think it would be appropriate if he were brought back to the matter before the House.
—The compass of the debate is fairly wide but I trust that the honourable member for Denison will remember the point of order, which I accept.

—I accept your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker. I thought it wise, however, in the course of this debate to throw a little cold water on Mr Hanrahan and his rather gloomy predilections. I will come back to the thrust of this Bill. It is a simple one. It implements just one more aspect of this Government's micro-economic policy, making sure that the public corporations of Australia are in a fit state to discharge their responsibilities at this time in Australia's economic development, at this time of the twentieth century. It is making sure that they are geared up, that they are efficient, that they have the managerial skills and the framework of economic and social responsibilities we require of corporations in this modern day to respond to Australia's economic and social needs. For all those reasons, this Bill deserves the support of the House. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: I was nearly at the conclusion of my remarks. The interest of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) in my speech suggests that I continue, particularly for those who are interested in an analysis of Australia's economic problems. I found it particularly interesting when we discovered that the reason Australia was in difficulty in the declining years of the Fraser Government, when the present shadow Treasurer held the reins as an economic adviser, was the drought. It really does continue the fairly rural theme of this Ferrari-driving Hanrahan. He really is a man who has taken his responsibilities so seriously that the failure of economic discipline in the Fraser years can be attributed to the drought. His gloomy predictions of ruin for Australia, made on a daily basis, can be given as much weight as those of the apocryphal Hanrahan in the poem that we love so much.

I conclude by saying that we still look forward to a bit of learning, a bit of growth in terms of the capacity of the Opposition to respond to Australia's structural difficulties. In the earlier debate we heard a suggestion that Australia was facing a wages blow-out. What a prescription for economic doom-an assertion from the shadow Treasurer that Australia is facing a wages blow-out. It comes from a party that has no policy whatsoever for wage containment. It has no constructive contribution at all to make in terms of wages policy. We hear the dire prediction that this year, under the system the Government has put in place, the accord, we are facing a wages blow-out. We cannot permit Australian political debate to be so debased that what passes for a contribution to debate in this House is merely a series of criticisms designed to create a climate of fear and misunderstanding in the community without any constructive response or contribution at all.

The shadow Treasurer was late to this debate. He has been late in making a contribution on tax policy. The Opposition is late in making any statement at all in respect of wages policy. We are still waiting as Australians to hear any constructive contribution at all in relation to the difficulties we accept we face but which the Australian Government is moving constructively towards resolving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not originally intend to enter this debate. All that was necessary to be said was said so ably by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), and the matter was fully dealt with. Having listened to the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), with whom I have crossed swords before, I feel obliged to make a few remarks. The point the shadow Treasurer was making was that, with the imposition of this levy by the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill, Commonwealth authorities are thereby making some payment in return for the privilege of raising their money in effect under a Commonwealth umbrella as if they were the Commonwealth-in other words, getting the credit rating of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would be correct to suggest, as I believe the shadow Treasurer suggested, that they might well be asking just how this benefit they are paying for is faring. After all, until three years ago we had a AAA credit rating, which has now been downgraded to AA1 and further. That affects the terms on which they can borrow. So the authorities, along with the Commonwealth, are losing ground in the market in terms of the rate at which they can borrow. Of course, they might well ask what benefit they are getting from this levy.

The reason for that downgrading, which affects the whole borrowing situation, is the misguided overall policy of this Government. That was the point the shadow Treasurer was making. The most telling index of that is the mounting overseas debt, which in gross terms is now approaching $140 billion. That is a vast sum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Owe no man anything.

—Owe no man anything, my colleague says. We are a long way from that precept. The shadow Treasurer did mention that if one does a simple division of $140 billion by the population of Australia, which is about 16.5 million, it is of the order of $7,500 per head. That is the simplest piece of arithmetic. One does not need to be a wizard to work that out. The incidence is about $7,500 per head; so for a husband and wife and two children it is a total of about $30,000. Directly or indirectly, this country as a whole has to pay the interest on that borrowing, the service on that borrowing. There is no escape from that. It is no good saying, `The Commonwealth is actually paying off debt. It is Bondy or somebody else who has incurred all this debt'. That may be, but directly or indirectly the nation has to foot the bill, as the Reserve Bank of Australia made amply clear in its recent report. All this stuff the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says about the Commonwealth paying off debt, that it is mainly private debt, is totally irrelevant. The nation as a whole is responsible for servicing that debt. There is only one way in which we can service it, and that is in terms of an excess of earnings overseas over what we pay overseas. Otherwise, where are the funds coming from to pay it? In effect, the nation as a whole has to earn that surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: That incidence, directly or indirectly, of roughly $7,500 per head for a family of four is about $30,000. The cost of servicing at 10 to 15 per cent would work out at about $4,500, or about $90 per week. The debt has gone up from $29 billion to $140 billion since the present Government has been in power. Is it any wonder that there is pressure on living standards, when there is a direct or indirect cost there of the order of $90 per week for a family of four? Of course, they do not write the cheques, but in order to make that payment, resources have to be transferred into net exports, into additional export production or additional production for the replacement of imports. Part of the process is that housing has to be cut back in order to transfer ultimately the resources. So the man in the street knows that housing rates at around 17 per cent are wrong. He does not know much about the national debt, but that is an indirect effect of the size of the national debt. Resources have to be transferred out of private consumption. People just cannot have as many VCRs and all the rest of it as they may want, desirable as that is for their quality of life. Resources even have to be transferred from domestic investment.

In point of fact, the quantum of that transfer amounts to about 4 percentage points of gross domestic product. Just as we have now a deficit in the current balance of payments of the order of 5 per cent, going on to 6 per cent, of gross domestic product, at least 4 percentage points have to be transferred into net exports to cut that back down to what is a historical norm of about 2 percentage points of deficit which can be reasonably serviced, especially to the extent that it is long term capital import. So 4 percentage points have in effect to be transferred. I stress that, from an economic point of view, it is not easy to effect that transfer. It is a lot easier to effect it, though, to the extent that we can more rapidly increase production and productivity in this country. The more rapidly we can increase the total of supply, the easier it is to bend some of it out of housing, some of it out of private consumption, some of it even out of private investment, though we are loath to do that, and a good deal more out of government, and put the extra four points into net exports.

If we have a good look at the economic history of this country, we are going well to bend resources from these areas into another area such as net export at the rate of about half a percentage point a year. That is why, as I recall the shadow Treasurer stressing, we are not going to solve this debt problem overnight. It is going to be a long haul. It could be all of eight years at that sort of rate I have mentioned. Bending half a percentage point a year to get 4 percentage points, that is eight years. Even the most optimistic scenarios that the Government can come up with would not suggest that we can stabilise this overseas debt-not start to cut it back but stop it going up and imposing a greater and greater burden, directly and indirectly, on the nation-probably before 1994-95. That follows from the analysis I have just given-that if one bends it about half a percentage point a year, if one is lucky, that is about eight years.

The difficulty is that the Government does not sufficiently address this problem. Indeed, it tends to act as if it is unimportant. As I have said, the Prime Minister has said that the debt is mainly private and that we do not have to worry. We do have to worry because if we do not begin to generate extra net exports in order to pay for our debt we are in all sorts of potential trouble, particularly if there is any turn down in the world economy. With the most recent monthly balance of payments deficit at $2.6 billion we are in the worst strife ever. That is nearly $100m a day. From this time yesterday to this time tonight, at that rate, we have gone an extra $100m into hock. It is as if money grows on trees.

The problem has to be addressed directly and explicitly. Proper efforts should be made to convey to the Australian people where the problem lies. We got into a problem in 1986, when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) spoke about a banana republic and we heard the Prime Minister say on air that we had a situation akin to war. That was the very phrase he used in 1986. The same problem confronts us now but it is even worse, compounded, as the debt has risen to $140 billion. We are set to continue on that path. We have the same problems now as we did in 1986 but now the Prime Minister and the Treasurer do not want to say anything about it. They have an election coming up and they hope that, on their present course, they can get to the electors before the whole thing collapses around their ears. I say this particularly in light of the fact that the honourable member for Denison was talking a lot of absolute tripe.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is praising him.

—That is praising him, as my colleague says. I will not use a stronger word, given parliamentary procedures. We heard the honourable member go out over the airwaves reassuring the Australian people while the danger to the economy is there for all to see.
—You tell him.
—Don't encourage him. He has to sit down.
—On that note, I will accept the honourable member's enjoiner and desist.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 16 August, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
