DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) BILL 1989[COGNATE BILL:HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 September, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill concurrently with the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sat here for the last hour and a half-if you will indulge me, Mr Deputy Speaker-listening to the previous debate, which was most interesting because it was about economics. The discussion we are about to have concerns a completely different subject but I want to make an observation, having heard my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), a fellow Tasmanian, and his economic analysis. I want to compare that with the economic analysis of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who is a professor of economics.
—Order! The honourable member will remember his own point of order regarding relevance.

—I was seeking your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, so if I can just finish this one sentence: the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) is also a professor of economics. I hope that the honourable member for Denison reads their speeches because at the end of the day they both said the same thing-it does not matter how the debt is incurred, someone has to pay for it. That is the problem that we as Australians face.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill 1989 and the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1989 are being debated cognately. They have had an interesting and long gestation period. The Opposition will support with pleasure both of these Bills. Later in the debate I will point out in some detail why that is so.

At least in this place concern about the matters covered by these Bills began back in 1982 when the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation investigated the matter of chemicals. It came forward with two reports-one in April 1982 and one that was tabled in December 1982, I think. Recommendations were made-which I would like to refer to in due course-that we ought to be far more concerned about chemicals, particularly hazardous chemicals, and that certain steps ought to be taken at the Commonwealth level. In 1989 we finally see the recommendations made in those two reports adopted, broadly speaking, and included in these two pieces of legislation. But since that time there has been a very deep and growing community concern about broad environmental matters and particularly about chemicals and their disposal, and about waste in general. Part of this broad international and Australian concern is reflected by the fact that this legislation has found its way to this chamber at last.

Earlier this year the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal was passed under the jurisdiction of the United Nations. At least the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill picks up the convention. When we have passed the Bill it will enable Australia to become a signatory to the convention, and I will talk a little more about that later.

I think a broader point needs to be made first. Waste and chemicals of all kinds have become the focus of increasing public concern and media coverage in recent years. I suppose that most of us would be concerned about the volume of waste produced in our own households. That is something we can identify with quite easily. Who of us does not feel a pang of guilt as we flush chemical solutions down the sink, and who of us is not disturbed by images of waste in our municipal dumps where we are effectively burying real money in the ground in many cases?

Many of us who have followed the environmental debates and the chemical debates in this country will be appalled at the sight of ships such as the Zenobia, the Khian Sea or the Karin-B roaming the world seeking places to discharge their toxic cargoes. As some articles and comments suggest, we are seeing the development where people are looking to the Third World as a new dumping ground for poisons. Part of the concern that led to the convention earlier this year occurred because of these ships. If one has a look at the more popular press, one can see articles such as the one headed `The global poison trade', which talks about a voyage to nowhere of a ship called the Khian Sea which left Philadelphia on 31 August 1986 and as at November 1988 was still at sea looking for somewhere to discharge its incinerator ash toxic waste cargo. There are deep concerns about where that waste is going and the pressure that is being put on poor Third World countries to be the recipient of those wastes. This issue is not just an Australian issue; it is an international issue. Indeed, it is important to recognise that fact and to recognise the significance of this legislation and what it means. That is why all parties in this Parliament are supporting this legislation.

I will go back to the 1982 report of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. As I said, the first report was brought to this chamber in April 1982. The then Chairman of that Committee was a Liberal Party member, the former member for Petrie, John Hodges, who has now departed from this chamber. Interestingly, if I recall-I was not here at the time-he is a chemist himself. The report made many recommendations. As to the basis of it, I will quote Mr Hodges:
The report of the Committee is a unanimous one, with members feeling strongly about the inadequacies of the present situation.

That was the management of hazardous wastes, which falls between the ambits of the States. Clearly, something needed to be done. The report went on to say that there needed to be far more detailed work done on chemical waste storages, transport and disposal. The report detailed interesting international examples, at that time, where waste had caused grievous bodily harm to citizens in different parts of the world, and it quoted some examples in Australia. Since 1982 there have been many other examples. That was the start of the concern about hazardous wastes and their movement. I will come to the second committee report a little later.

I will talk a little more about the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill. Although it is order of the day No. 6, in my view it is the more important of the two Bills. This legislation proposes a system for the control of the import and export of hazardous wastes by use of a ministerial permit. The objective of the exercise is to ensure that such wastes are disposed of in an environmentally acceptable manner. As I said, the Basel Convention of earlier this year basically put that proposal forward and national parliaments of various kinds are being asked to put legislation through to give effect to some control of the transboundary movements of such wastes. The method by which we are doing that is by putting this ministerial permit system into place.

While the Bill adopts definitions and principles found in the Convention, it should be noted that the Commonwealth clearly possesses the power to regulate this matter through existing constitutional powers over customs, exports and imports. Consequently, adherence to the convention does not, I believe, increase the Commonwealth's power over the States nor make improper use of the external affairs power. The permit scheme provides that all decisions made by the Minister are subject to judicial review, and the scheme will be self-financing as there will be a fee of up to $4,000 prescribed to cover the costs of administering the Act. It should be noted that the scheme excludes control of radioactive wastes as these are not dealt with under the Convention and, in any event, are the subject of other Australian legislation already in this place.

I have talked a little about the background and the concern. As I said, it is broad concern to the international community that the Third World countries are being prevailed upon to take much of this toxic waste, and there are many examples of that concern, one of which I have already quoted. It has already been under scrutiny. Back in 1984 the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) had an agreement under the United Nations environment program which took over its work in 1987, and at the same time steps for a regional control mechanism were being developed within the Association of South East Asian Nations.

Under this pressure we finally had the United Nations environmental program involved with this Convention. The final session was approved by 105 of the 116 participating countries. The Convention has so far been signed by 34 countries, including Canada, France, the Philippines, the European Economic Community (EEC), Belgium, Italy, Norway and Sweden, and several others are yet to sign. Concern has also been expressed about the need to develop a far stricter code within the EEC and for OECD countries, and a lead has been taken in this area by the British Secretary of State for the Environment, Mr Chris Patten. Indeed, I obtained a statement from the British Secretary of State for the Environment. Mr Patten makes this observation, which, given that this debate has some international significance, I think is worth reading into the record. He states:

Effective concern for the environment requires deep commitment, cool judgement and the sound application of scientific principles. If we proceed by panic and scaremongering we will only serve to discredit the cause of environmental improvement.

That is quite important because several points need to be underlined. One is the scientific principles that need to be adopted to the environmental debate. As many members would realise, much of our toxic waste is shipped from our shores-that is because we do not have a high-temperature incinerator-to Pontypool in the United Kingdom. There are many issues that we could be involved in here such as applying our own scientific abilities to provide our own country with a high-temperature incinerator. Indeed, this Bill brings forward more quickly the need for Australia to address this issue in a far more positive way. I admit that there are working groups in place, but the need for Australia to be proceeding to deal with toxic waste in a far more effective way is now paramount. Indeed, in May this year when I spoke in the debate in this place about the Sea Installations Bill, we strayed a little from the topic then and we talked about the London Dumping Convention, which is all about the dumping of waste at sea. The Basel Convention does not go that far, but it does make an interesting observation. The front of the Convention instructs the secretariat of that Convention to proceed to review the London Dumping Convention. There perhaps needs to be more attention to that Convention as it relates to the dumping of waste at sea.

That is particularly important. Some Australians have watched this issue quite closely. Ships have come to Australia, picked up waste, and steamed out, and polychlorinated biphenyls have been incinerated and dissipated into the sea and so on. Dumping at sea is an interim measure. It is not a solution to the problem of toxic waste. The point I am making is that as a world community we cannot continue to allow a continuation of dumping toxic waste at sea. The best method is high-temperature incineration. We in this country ought to be utilising our scientific skills, in conjunction with the British or others, to develop a high-temperature incinerator. This will not only help our environmental needs but will also help many of the smaller countries in our region to deal most environmentally effectively with their wastes. There is a dollar in it, too. If that is not motivation enough, combined with the positive impact it would make on the environment, then I would be very surprised. I urge the Government, as I did in May, to accelerate consideration of how we are going to deal with toxic wastes in this country, because I think we have a very positive role to play.

I will return to the outline of the proposed scheme. An operator seeking to import or export hazardous waste must get a permit from the Minister, who must be satisfied that the applicant is a fit and proper person to receive a permit-indeed, that clause is subject to an amendment which the Government is proposing, which we agree to-that he has adequate insurance cover and that, further, the waste can be disposed of safely in an environmentally acceptable fashion, and that the receiving country has agreed to accept the waste in question. Decisions on permits will be subject to judicial review, but a permit may be refused if the Minister considers that, having regard to Australia's international obligations, the waste should be dealt with in another way, if it can be disposed of safely within Australia or the grant of a permit is contrary to the public interest. It is a wide discretion, but it is a sensible discretion and it does put in place at least some control on the movement to or from Australia of waste. It allows the Commonwealth to play a role. I might add that this Bill does have the support of all States. It also has the support of the Australian Environment Council and, in that sense, it is a big step forward for Australia and ought to be recognised as such. It should also be recognised that a lot of the hard work and the flag-waving on the need to act on this matter was done through the work of people like John Hodges in 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Brian Howe?

—I will tell the honourable member for La Trobe who else was involved. The honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe), was involved, Dr Klugman was involved and Dr Jenkins was involved. I am sure there were many other good people involved as well. The Committee enjoyed bipartisan support and did good work. It is important that this Bill has come before the House today, and the Opposition supports it.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the amendments which have been circulated and which I should mention now concerns the need to vary the Bill to enable prosecution to take place against the Crown. As I understand it, the Government will accept that amendment. In these days of arm's length statutory authorities, we believe it is important that the Crown is not immune from prosecution and the reach of this Act.

I now move to talk a little about the second Bill. This Bill also picks up some interesting issues raised by the activities of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation in 1982. It is from the second report of that Committee that this Bill flows in part. That report was prepared under the chairmanship of the Hon. M. J. R. MacKellar, the honourable member for Warringah, who knows a lot about chemicals as he is an agricultural scientist of some note, I understand. He has been a member of this place for some years and is a very senior member. Reading the report and his tabling statement, one gets the flavour of the urgency of the issues he was raising.

I shall point out some of the issues he talked about. He said that occupational health was of particular interest to the Committee at that time because people wanted to make sure that the use of chemicals in the workplace-and there are many chemicals used in the workplace-was done safely. He said there needed to be a national coordination of approaches to chemicals. Indeed, as I recall, that Committee proposed a coordinating council to ensure that the range of information needed in Australia is met, that the cost is effective and that the best use is made of overseas data banks. Not a lot happened in that area, unfortunately, but finally something is happening tonight.

That Committee talked about the split of responsibility for occupational safety and health between labour and health authorities. The honourable member for Warringah said then that it contributed to the ineffective control of chemical hazards. In a sense, I think that problem still lies because the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill is to be administered by the Department of Industrial Relations and the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Import) Bill is to be administered by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. We still have not really got our coordination together. We have now started to get the principles into legislation and these Bills will pass both chambers, but the coordination in the approach to chemicals is not yet at a stage, certainly at a national level, that it could be. Progress is obviously slow; nevertheless, there is progress.

The point the honourable member for Warringah made in 1982 ought to be kept in mind by the present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and, indeed, the whole Cabinet as they consider the next steps to be taken to ensure that the approach to chemicals and hazardous wastes in this country receives the very best coordination, not just at a Commonwealth bureaucratic level but also between the Commonwealth and the States. As I said when speaking about the previous Bill, the States also support the industrial chemicals Bill, and that is an important step.

The purpose of the industrial chemicals Bill is to establish a national scheme for notification and assessment of industrial chemicals. It is designed to ensure that there is adequate information on any possible hazards associated with chemicals imported or manufactured in Australia. The Bill will not directly regulate the use of chemicals; that will remain the responsibility of the States and Territories. However, under the scheme established by the Bill, the existing regulatory agencies will be provided with far better information on which to make decisions about regulating chemicals.

If the information base were made more widely available, it would avoid the problem that occurred in Mississippi in 1972 when a waterhole was drilled next to a dump and, unbeknown to anyone, grasshopper killer poison which had been put in the dump many years before leached into the water supply and 20 people died from arsenic poisoning. That is the sort of thing that can happen and is still happening. We saw what happened with chemicals in Bhopal, and there are many other examples. That is the sort of thing these Bills are trying to avoid. If these Bills are about getting better information and making it available, then each and every Australian should be supporting them.

All new chemicals will be notified to Worksafe Australia, which is to administer the scheme, together with a notification statement of the intended use and properties of the chemicals. The information will be assessed to determine the potential hazard to occupational health and safety, public health and the environment. We are trying to have a legislative scheme which puts out information into the workplace to alert people to the hazards of using particular chemicals. The Bills go so far as to require details about labelling. Labelling of chemicals warrants far more attention than it has received. Any toxic-based chemical should be labelled with instructions as to what should be done if, by accident, in a household or other area there is improper human contact or use. All of us who have young children know the risks that are run. Worksafe will be obliged to prepare and distribute assessments of the chemicals within a specified time frame. Such assessment would normally include recommendations for the safe use of the chemical. There is also provision for the selective assessment of existing chemicals where there are particular concerns about possible hazards.

There are a number of issues that should be addressed. The chemical industry supports both pieces of legislation, but it must be understood that the chemical industry is already subject to a vast array of regulations governing aspects such as storage and transportation. It is important that any new legislation is not just legislation for its own sake. It needs to fit into a proper mosaic of regulatory control. This Bill was forwarded to the Business Regulation Review Unit, which supported the introduction of a national notification and assessment scheme. It believes such a scheme would lead to higher levels of public safety and lower costs in the manufacture and use of chemicals. We would all welcome that.

The Business Regulation Review Unit proposed some modification to the scheme contained in the Bill. I do not know whether the Minister will have the opportunity to sum up, but he might like to comment on this point. The unit argued that all new chemicals should be automatically approved where they are already included in recognised inventories of major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. It was argued that this would avoid duplicating work done overseas, reduce costs and release resources to develop information on chemicals that are already in use and are of concern. The counter argument is that the Bill already provides for the use of overseas assessments. Under the provisions of the Bill, where a new chemical has been notified and assessed under a recognised equivalent scheme of another country, that notification and assessment will suffice provided the assessment is accessible and relevant to the proposed use and exposure profile of the chemical in Australia.

The difficulty in automatically approving chemicals on overseas inventories is that simply being on the inventory of an OECD country does not mean that a chemical has been assessed for potential health or environmental hazards. Automatic entry for chemicals listed overseas without any assessment would perpetuate the current situation where chemicals can come on to the Australian market without any information as to health or environmental hazards and appropriate safety recommendations. That issue needs to be cleared up. I do not think any of us would want chemicals that may have been accepted in other jurisdictions coming on to our market without undergoing some scrutiny as to their environmental impact, given that they may be used in a completely different environment from that in which they have normally been used. That point needs to be considered.

As I said, the Australian chemical industry has endorsed and welcomed the Bill as being consistent with the industry's policy of placing a priority on health, safety and environment issues. The Australian Chemical Industry Council is very concerned that failure to establish a national notification and assessment scheme would lead to the establishment of separate schemes in the States. According to a representative of the Council, this would be a disastrous outcome and would greatly increase the cost burden on the industry as well as leading to longer delays before new chemicals are brought on to the Australian market.

I am informed that the Council was closely involved in the preparation of the scheme and considers that the final version of the Bill will meet all the significant concerns of the industry. The Confederation of Australian Industry has also been closely consulted in the preparation of the scheme and supports the Bill. As was so ably pointed out in 1982 by the honourable member for Warringah, who chaired the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, we need to concentrate far more on making available to the workplace information on the dangers inherent in dealing with many of the toxic chemicals.

We support the two Bills, as would all thinking members of the chamber. The Government proposes some minor amendments and I am proposing an amendment. I hope they will proceed. I again make the broad point that the issue is of international concern. The Bills have taken a long time to come to this place. No-one ascribes blame for that, and it is good that they are here.

I come back to one other point that I believe is important-the future and the opportunities that Australia might have in dealing with waste. We need to concentrate on recycling where we can. Not all waste can be recycled, but much of it can be. There are great opportunities for Australia to be involved in the waste recycling business and the waste disposal business. As the Secretary of State for the Environment in the United Kingdom pointed out, a lot of that business will rely on our scientific abilities and the proper utilisation of those abilities.

I pay credit to some of those in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) who are involved in many different areas in waste disposal. In the manufacturing technology area of CSIRO they are developing an electric arc technology for hazardous waste disposal and an image analysis and waste reduction in a cutting operation. In biotechnology they are involved in research into the disposal of high strength organic wastes by biodegradation and genetic engineering of new microbial strains. In the coal technology area they are doing research into the upgrading of waste materials from coal processing, combustion and so on. In the mineral products area, they are researching high temperature processing. In environmental mechanics they are producing design rules for the construction of repositories to ensure long-term safe containment of wastes. In chemicals and polymers they are involved in water and water waste treatment, including magnetic ion exchange for heavy metal recovery from sludges and liquid effluence.

In the wool industry, an industry which is vital to Australia, especially when we consider the need to develop our external earnings from trade, new work is being done in wool scouring and wool grease treatment. We have been a world leader in the wool scouring industry, and new environmental methods may well mean an enhancement of that industry because the industry would add tremendous value to our primary wool product. There are many examples of our scientists already involved in the waste and recycling industry. I offer the encouragement of the Opposition to those involved to press on. They enjoy the support of the Australian community. These issues are now receiving far more community attention than they have done in the past. That is good, but we need to pursue the opportunities that are there, not only for our sake but also for the sake of our region and for the better environmental protection of the broader world community. I welcome the Bills and have pleasure in endorsing them and offering the Opposition's support for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill 1989 and the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Export and Imports) Bill 1989, the provisions of which are long overdue. As usual, I found myself in agreement with a lot of what the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who preceded me in this debate, had to say. Perhaps there was only one difference of opinion I had with him. Whilst I do not want to denigrate the work of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), who was Chairman of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation when the final report was produced, I point out that he did not have a very big part to play in the total work of the Committee. The person who had a big part to play throughout the work of the Committee was the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe), who is now the Minister for Social Security. A lot of the work that was done through both reports of that Committee was due to the very hard work put in by the honourable member for Batman.

SPEECH.PARA: In brief, the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill establishes an inventory and assessment system for some industrial chemicals. The hazardous waste Bill establishes a permit system for the export and import of hazardous waste. Both Bills cover penalties for the unauthorised import or export of certain chemicals and waste. It is very interesting that the honourable member for Bass referred to the fact that our toxic wastes are exported to Pontypool in Wales in the United Kingdom. We are very fortunate tonight to have in the gallery Mr Paul Murphy, who is the member of parliament for Torfaen, which is the area which covers Pontypool. I am sure the honourable member for Bass was not aware that Mr Murphy was in the gallery. He would have been very interested in the comments the honourable member had to make and in the passage of these Bills through the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he a left winger?

—He is a member of the Labour Party. I am not quite sure in what area the honourable member for Gippsland would put that, but certainly we are all interested in the passage of these Bills. One thing I noted when the honourable member for Bass was talking is that there is no disagreement between us in approving these Bills. Whether Mr Murphy is left, right or anything else, the honourable member can be sure that he is with us in what we are doing in the House tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: As I pointed out, in 1982-just prior to my becoming Chairman of the Committee in 1983-the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation presented two reports on hazardous chemicals.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has never been the same since.

—It has waxed on in even greater strength since I have been Chairman. The inquiry into the management of chemicals hazardous to health and the environment was most extensive, involving some 2 1/2 years of public hearings and inspections all over Australia. At the public hearings evidence was taken from 170 witnesses and the Committee received 169 submissions involving 3,761 pages of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: On 29 April 1982 the Committee tabled its first report on the storage, transport and disposal of hazardous chemical wastes. In its second report, tabled in December 1982, it covered all the other aspects of the nature of hazardous chemicals and the damage they can cause if not managed and regulated properly. I take this opportunity to commend the Committee on its reports and to note that the Committee has comprised present Ministers, ex-Ministers and an ex-Speaker of the House-a distinguished Committee indeed. There was a long delay. Some five years afterwards, in 1987, the reports were tabled. A joint task force was set up by the Commonwealth Government, and the New South Wales and Victoria State governments presented a preliminary report in July 1988. The report recommended comprehensive regulatory and management arrangements for hazardous and intractable wastes.

The present Bill provides a regulatory structure while at the same time giving Australia the opportunity to ratify the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal. The Convention was approved by 116 countries giving their assent on 27 March 1989. The approving of both Bills by the Australian Parliament enables Australia to honour the provisions of the Basel Convention, which prohibits the export of hazardous wastes from the shores of convention countries to those countries which have not consented to the import. It requires countries treating and disposing of wastes to do so in an environmentally sound manner.

Inevitably, because of State and Territory constitutional responsibilities, it will be necessary for the present legislation to be complemented by State and Territory waste management legislation. I will define what is meant by hazardous chemicals. I can do no better than quote from the second report of the Committee on Environment and Conservation. It is important to give the full text of what the report has to say about the nature of hazards:

7. Chemicals can be hazardous to man and the environment through their toxicity, through being bioaccumulative, persistent, carcinogenic, mutagenic, teratogenic, corrosive, radioactive, explosive, flammable or strongly reactive. Chemicals may create a hazard during part or all of their `life cycle' which includes their development, manufacture, handling, transport, storage, use and disposal. In fire and other emergency situations, chemicals may become more hazardous than they are normally . . . While many chemicals in commercial use have little or no adverse potential effects on man or the environment, others pose quite serious environmental and health hazards. These hazards are not always immediately obvious.
8. Some substances, such as lead and mercury, accumulate in the body over time, consequently increasing their toxic effects.

The report goes on to detail many examples of damage from hazardous chemicals involving severe ill health and often death for many human beings. Sometimes the incidents happen quite irresponsibly when the manufacturers of the hazardous chemicals attempt to dispose of them illegally. Often, however, they occur through sheer ignorance of the dangers of the chemicals.

When I first became the Labor candidate for the seat of La Trobe in 1979, just prior to my election, a future constituent sought my help about the legal use of hazardous chemicals. The constituent owned a nursery, which was situated next to a disused quarry. The local fire brigade habitually used the quarry for fire preventive practice, using discarded materials from a paint factory to ignite large tree stumps. The resultant fires not only produced huge clouds of black, acrid smoke but also produced chemical runoffs which percolated through to a stream running through the nursery and very close to the local primary school. Fortunately, I was able to ensure that the practice was discontinued before any serious damage occurred. That is possibly the reason why I am now the member for La Trobe. This is an example of how the ignorance of the local fire brigade was traded upon by the paint manufacturers, who had found a cheap way of disposing of waste products from the factory.
Of course, the incidents described in the report are far more serious. One case from Michigan in the United States of America was particularly serious. The report states:

. . . in 1973 polybrominated biphenyls (PBBs), used as a flame retardant, were inadvertently mixed with animal feed. Despite many thousand farm animals being destroyed, human food was contaminated with this persistent chemical. Ninety-seven per cent of the State's population still have PBB in their bodies. While some symptoms of poisoning occurred fairly quickly other long-term hazards such as cancer and nervous system disorders may take decades to become apparent.

That is the sort of problem that these toxic chemicals produce. There have been similar serious cases in Australia, including in my State of Victoria. Unfortunately, the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) will not have time to speak tonight. When he does speak, when the Parliament resumes in two weeks time, he will detail some of the more serious occurrences quite close to, and possibly in, his own electorate of Dunkley.

As the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) pointed out in his introductory speech, the Federal Government is considering the possibility of establishing a high temperature incinerator. This was mentioned by the honourable member for Bass. The Victorian and New South Wales State governments are also involved in the proposal, which could be sited in New South Wales and operated by a New South Wales Government agency. The construction of a national high temperature incinerator was proposed by the 1987-88 joint task force on intractable waste. Whilst I do not need to be persuaded of the need for such an incinerator, I do have some concerns. There is the danger that the establishment of the incinerator will encourage industry to continue with the same practices which produced the highly toxic waste in the first place with no incentive to minimise the waste. The cost of using a high temperature incinerator must be sufficiently high to act as an incentive for industry to engage in research into recycling intractable industrial wastes-I know that the honourable member supports me in this view-for example, changing manufacturing processes which will minimise the production of intractable wastes and identify substitute products, which can be manufactured without the production of hazardous wastes.

I would like to quote from a discussion paper on policy priorities for the environment produced in my office by Ms Karen Large, my electoral research officer, in which she suggests the policies which should be given priority in the prevention or minimisation of hazardous and intractable wastes. Firstly, she advises;
(i) The establishment and implementation of national standards for the regulation of the generation, transportation, recycling and disposal of hazardous waste.
To some extent these Bills cover those matters. Secondly, she advises:
(ii) The development of these national standards to include the establishment of detailed consultative arrangements involving industry, unions, environmental and other community groups.
I do not see that in these two Bills. Thirdly:

(iii) National standards should emphasise the following hierarchy of waste management processes: prevention, minimisation, recycling, treatment (physical, chemical, biological and incineration) and landfill as proposed by the Joint Taskforce.
Fourthly:
(iv) Amendment of the AEC's National Guidelines for the Management of Hazardous Wastes to reflect this hierarchy of management.
Fifthly:

(v) The establishment of effective targets for the implementation of waste minimisation targets including financial incentives, subsidies, grants etc for research and schemes which promote waste prevention and reduction.
There is nothing like that in these two Bills. Sixthly:

(vi) Financial support for the development of processes which have a potential application to specific problems in hazardous waste management, such as on-site and on-line destruction of intractable waste and the in situ decontamination of soils (eg chemical or biological methods).
Seventhly:
(vii) Extensive public consultation prior to the siting of any high temperature incinerators.
I hope that is going on in New South Wales. I expect that it is going on. Eighthly:
(viii) High temperature incinerators to be under Federal Government control.
The trouble is that the Government is not allowing this to happen; it will be under the control of the New South Wales Government. Ninthly:
(ix) The operation of a high temperature incinerator to include monitoring of pollution risks from airborne particles and waste sludge.
Again, I expect that the New South Wales Government is doing that. Tenthly:
(x) The use of high temperature incinerators to be conditional on industry supplying plans for waste prevention and minimisation.
Finally:
(xi) A national strategy to identify contaminated sites and clean them up.

The Federal Government should definitely become involved in that area. I thoroughly support those policies and I hope that the Federal Government can give urgent consideration to their implementation. It is particularly important that we draw to the attention of small nations, such as many of our Pacific neighbours, the need for overseas based manufacturing companies to adopt the preventative procedures I have outlined to avoid the import of hazardous and intractable wastes into Australia for the purposes of high temperature incineration, as mentioned by the Minister in his second reading speech. I am quite sure that the honourable member for Torfaen in Wales would agree. It is his electorate that has to suffer the import of these intractable wastes for high temperature incineration, to which his constituents are opposed. I can understand why they are opposed.

In reading through the hazardous chemicals reports of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation it is very clear that much remains to be done despite the present legislation in relation to the management of chemicals which are potentially hazardous to health and the environment. As I mentioned earlier in my speech, a number of serious incidents in relation to the dumping of hazardous waste have occurred in Australia. The Committee referred to the problem in its first report as follows:

In its evidence and during inspections the Committee was often told that the future use of individual waste disposal sites, while not decided on, would probably be for playing fields or recreation areas. This seems a common practice for closed municipal waste sites after a settlement period and it is said to be quite safe. The Committee is concerned about the safety of closed hazardous waste landfill sites being used for such purposes. Evidence was given that playing fields often become inundated through irrigation and/or rainfall, and some upward movement of leachate could be expected. In addition care would be required in digging trenches for facilities and other earthworks associated with playing fields.

It would appear little is being done to locate old dump sites. One reason might be the likely cost to governments in cleaning up these old sites. Regulatory authorities seem to prefer to wait for adverse effects to become obvious rather than locate old sites, assess their hazard and, where necessary, recover or contain wastes before their effects are widespread.

In this Parliament we all know that there have been many such cases since the Committee produced its report. Whilst it is true that the legislation must be implemented by State and Territory governments to ensure that standards are adopted for the safety of hazardous waste disposal sites after closure, I am concerned that the Federal Government does not appear to be taking a lead in these matters, particularly in the identification of sites of past hazardous waste disposal. The Standing Committee made several recommendations on the problems of past hazardous waste disposal sites which the Federal Government does not appear to have taken up. I would be interested in the comments of the Minister on these matters.

The Standing Committee also dealt with the responsibilities of the Federal Government in relation to hazardous chemicals management. This is one of the areas where we get into the problem that we always have in Australia about Federal constitutional rights and State constitutional rights. The report goes on to state:

In addition to the Commonwealth powers discussed above there remain several important constitutional responsibilities. One of the biggest single problems in hazardous chemicals management is the fragmentation of legislative, administrative, research and assessment efforts around Australia. Evidence before the Inquiry shows beyond any doubt that effective assessment and control machinery requires a well coordinated national approach with considerable reliance on effective machinery in other countries and at the international level.

These Bills identify that problem, and are overcoming it, which was set out in the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal. The report continues:

The Committee believes the Implied Power to be an important one in connection with the problems raised by the present Inquiry. With this power must go an equivalent responsibility on the part of the Government which exercises it.
The Committee went on to make a recommendation which I think is important to relate to this Parliament. The Committee recommended:

If State Governments fail to introduce effective and comprehensive legislation and administrative machinery for the regulation of chemical hazards by 1985, the Commonwealth legislate to control these hazards to the fullest extent of its power.

When we come to an important matter like this-a very serious matter-I think it is about time that the Commonwealth Government should be prepared to override the States in these constitutional responsibilities. Constitutional lawyers have made it quite clear that we have this power. I believe that the matter is so serious that we should exercise this power in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that the clock has gone well on and that I have only a few minutes in which to speak on the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill and the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill, there being a two-week break before I have the opportunity to finish my speech. In this House we are mostly familiar with a very common definition of Parliament; that is, it is a place where someone gets up to speak; says nothing; nobody listens; and then everybody disagrees. Tonight, with regard to these two Bills, we have heard the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), who is also the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. Both speakers have had quite a bit to say that has been very relevant and very important. Everybody has listened and there has not been any disagreement. It is very pleasurable to get up-even though I have only a few minutes left-to speak on these two Bills which should be of interest to all of us who are concerned about developing legislation which meets the practical challenges of regulatory protection of the environment. That is something which is very much to the fore in the thinking of everybody today.

SPEECH.PARA: The first Bill establishes a national scheme for the notification and assessment of industrial chemicals. That Bill is designed to ensure adequate information on and regulation of any possible hazards associated with chemicals imported or manufactured in Australia. It is, quite simply, a response to inadequacies in the information and regulatory systems covering industrial chemicals in Australia. The second Bill proposes a system for the control of the import and export of hazardous waste by the use of ministerial permits. Its objective is to ensure that such wastes are disposed of in an environmentally acceptable manner not only here in Australia but also overseas. It is the legislative embodiment of the domestic and international obligations to protect other humans and the environment from the dangers posed by hazardous industrial wastes.

The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) and previous speakers have detailed the provisions of these two Bills. I do not want to waste time going over those details again. Instead, I want to make some general comments about the background and context of the two Bills. I want first to note the tardiness which still appears to have characterised the bureaucracy and the Executive in bringing this legislation before the Parliament. As two of my colleagues, the honourable member for La Trobe and the honourable member for Bass, have noted tonight, all the matters dealt with in these Bills were first raised in two reports by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation nearly seven years ago.

When one re-reads the two reports of the inquiry into hazardous chemicals one discovers a comprehensive analysis of the problem along with specific workable and urgent-seven years ago-recommendations on the three main areas covered by these two Bills. Those three areas are, firstly, the need for data bases, licences, monitoring, regulatory coverage and sanctions in the areas of chemical usage and waste disposals in Australia. This was an urgent recommendation made seven years ago. The second area was the need to clarify the Commonwealth's role and powers in this area and to structure coordination and cooperation with the States. This was pointed out very clearly by the honourable member for La Trobe. The third area is the need for international machinery to require international movement and disposal of wastes.

Two days ago in this place I raised the matter of the Executive's tendency to ignore the committee system in policy making, especially in regard to reports on environmental matters. Seven years ago the Executive was alerted to the policy and legislative responses needed to deal with the dangerous and immoral inadequacies of our regulatory framework in the areas of hazardous chemicals and wastes. If the Government and the bureaucracy had more respect for the committee system, the important work of the Environment Committee on hazardous chemicals and wastes-most of which has been incorporated in these Bills in any event-could have been benefiting this community and the global community for the past six years. I refer to these Bills and the reports of the Environment Committee in 1982 as a clear example of the important role of the parliamentary committee system and as a clear example of the way the Executive continues to ignore that system to the detriment of good government.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: South West Africa People's Organisation-Toxic Waste Disposal-Child Support Agency-Mr Eddie Kornhauser-Environment

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today in the grievance debate I was questioning the desirability of the Government's moral and financial support for the communist-backed terrorist organisation, the South West Africa Peoples Organisation (SWAPO). That debate was cut short due to other matters being debated, so I take this opportunity to conclude my remarks on the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: My main concern lies with stories of SWAPO's brutal and dreadful atrocities now filtering through from returning refugees. Despite the ridiculous stance of the United Nations that SWAPO is `in the sole authentic representative of the Namibian people', it appears that that is far from the case. Even John Carlin, an anti-South African, has written in the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 September an article entitled `The liberators with blood on their hands'. That article states:

For many years, there has been a sort of international conspiracy to project SWAPO, the most pampered `freedom fighters' the world has seen, as the incarnation of all that is fine and noble and heroic.

They were fighting South Africa. They were black. They were the underdogs. They were sacrosanct. There was no need to examine the detail: the fact that they were a far-from-democratic organisation run along Stalinist lines of command; that on the battlefield they were ineffectual; that they milked huge amounts of money from international organisations, much of which they have been unable to account for.
Worst of all, no-one noticed, or chose to notice, the atrocities they were committing against their own followers.
John Carlin writes of beatings, torture and atrocities that many people he interviewed suffered at the hands of SWAPO. He says that prisoners were:
. . . dropped into hot, dank, stinking mud pits seven metres deep and incarcerated there for years.
He continues:
In the case of one 24-year-old woman I spoke to, Elizabeth Simasiku, it was eight years. Typically, a mud hole with the dimension of, say, a squash court would hold 40 people.

A trap door at ground level would be opened only to allow prisoners out to do forced labour, or twice a day, to relieve themselves. Food was scarce and vitamin-deficient, provoking all manner of illnesses, sometimes ending in death.
Another woman said that she would not confess to trumped-up charges for offences that she had not committed. She said:
They tied me naked to the back of a car and dragged me four times across a river.
John Carlin writes also of strong racist elements in the SWAPO leadership. He says:

. . . what drove the SWAPO leadership to such madness? There is a clear pattern in the selection of the so-called `agents': they did not belong to the Kwanyama tribe, to which virtually the entire SWAPO military high command belongs and, in almost all cases, they were unusually well-educated. Thus there was a Pol Pot-like strand of anti-intellectualism, compounded by a consistent fear that these brighter SWAPO cadres would wrest power away from the ruling clique.
Elizabeth Endycott writes in the Spectator of 16 September of similar experiences. She says:

The holes, where so many dissidents were held, are room-sized pits, often dug by the prisoners themselves, covered with corrugated iron and scrub so that they cannot easily be seen, even from quite a short distance. Swapo never permitted the Red Cross to inspect their refugee camps.

The pits held as many as 36 people dressed only in singlet and underpants, which were never washed or changed. Tins were provided for lavatories and every morning prisoners had to climb a vertical ladder to empty them; otherwise they never saw the light. They were allowed to wash face and hands perhaps once in three months. Water was the only drink, and food consisted of rice or `mealies', cooked without sugar or salt and served in a communal bowl. Beatings were frequent, especially when the guards were drunk; many prisoners went mad, were taken away and never seen again. Deaths from TB, beri-beri and other diseases related to malnutrition were frequent. Medical care was non-existent.
Women and girls were frequently taken out and raped; children were born in the pits . . .

In conclusion, I believe that this Government and the United Nations should open their eyes, take heed of these reports, stop their biased charade of placing SWAPO beyond criticism and cease their unwavering support for this corrupt and uncaring organisation. We should call for the release of all remaining prisoners. We should also cease pouring taxpayers' money down this communist sinkhole, such as the $1.8m that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau recently sent it. Our time, money and energies would be much better directed towards working for free and fair elections in Namibia and a smooth and successful transition to independence in that country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 May 1989 I said in this House:

SPEECH.PARA: Some time ago at Hastings in the Flinders electorate, the BP refinery was pulled down. A huge amount of toxic waste was pulled out from that refinery and put into drums which were supposed to be taken to the dump at Tullamarine.

That information was given to the local press and quite a story was published on 13 June 1989. An article on the front page of today's Mornington Leader, which is headed `Poison waste denial', states:
Claims in June by Dunkley MHR Mr Bob Chynoweth that toxic waste had been buried in Hastings were refuted last week by the MLA for Mornington, Mr Robin Cooper.
The article then states:
Mr Cooper has described Mr Chynoweth's claim as a `cynical beat-up about toxic waste dumping in Hastings'.
If my claims are a cynical beat-up, I would like tonight to describe exactly where that waste is buried. On 16 June I received a letter which states:
Dear Mr Chynoweth,

I have enclosed a map relating to my phone call to you on 14.6.89 concerning the toxic waste. There are three different sites in the same paddock. The squashed-up 44s are still there and the overturned soil is obvious and can be seen from the road when looking up the driveway.

I have a map of the actual site. The site-it has been described to me by another source, so I believe it to be correct-is in Graydons Road, Hastings, about 500 metres from the corner of Boes Road. There is a depot, a paddock, a small cottage, a dam, a row of pine trees and a driveway leading up to the dump site. There are three dump sites there and another dump site is believed to be in an orchard which is further away. This is about 500 metres from the corner of Boes Road heading towards Hastings.

From what I have been told from different sources, this land was sold recently, just before my speech was reported in the papers. It was bought back again by a certain person, at an extra cost of course; but that toxic waste is still there. It is believed that there are about 1,000 drums of waste from the British Petroleum Co. of Australia Ltd refinery. Some of it is believed to be bituminous waste and the other is believed to be lead concentrate. These substances, which are quite deadly and poisonous, are believed to be buried at this site. There have been rumours throughout Hastings for many years now in relation to this matter. Now that I have given its location, I believe that it is about time the Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) in Victoria had a look at it. Recently there was a huge scare in Victoria as lead poisoning was found in Ardeer. The land which had been the site of a battery factory had been built on. Many people had to shift out of their houses as a result.

As I have said, this problem in Hastings has gone on for many years. It is time it was brought to the surface. If there is waste there, the EPA should have a look at it. I was told that, some time ago, there was an attempt to remove the drums. However, when some of the drums were dug up they actually split open. Pine trees were pushed over the top of the area and set fire to in an attempt to disguise the product that was spilt onto the ground. If there are 1,200 44-gallon drums there, that would represent a lot of waste. It is something that should be investigated very quickly and the land should be cleared. This matter should not be forgotten so that in future, whenever that area is built on or someone has a farm there, the people who live there should not be exposed to this sort of problem. Too much of this is going on all over the countryside. Many people and organisations are burying waste willy-nilly all over the place. It is about time that some severe action was taken against them and they were made to clean up the mess that they have created. If there is nothing there, I have made a mistake. However, I feel certain from the information that has been given to me that these drums are buried in and around this property and they should be cleaned up immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In November 1988 a woman in my electorate approached me in relation to the Child Support Agency. Her husband, from whom she was separated, had not been keeping up child support payments. The agency told her that they had to wait until her husband had reneged on two payments before they could issue a summons and then they would have to wait 28 days before the mother would receive anything. The Department of Social Security said they would see whether the former husband was employed. If he was, the agency would have the money deducted without summonsing him. It said the Department had a few teething problems.

SPEECH.PARA: On Thursday, 2 March, my office rang the agency. The girl spoken to in the Department in November was unavailable. They said they would check the case and ring back. On 7 March my office staff rang again as the agency had not phoned back. She was told legal action in the courts had been started. On 8 March the agency phoned and said it had issued a summons on 20 December but it had yet to be served. It said it appeared the husband was on sickness benefit and, if so, the wife would have to take him to court for a variation to the order. They would await the outcome of the summons before they advised further. On advising the mother, my office was told that the father was always on sickness benefit. When money was granted to her by the Child Support Agency he was on sickness benefit, but before the agency came into being she used to summons him to court every month and get the money quickly.

On 3 April 1989 we then rang the agency again and were told that it would check on the Department that had served the summons to see what was happening. My office told the agency that the wife had not received any payments since September 1988. The support agency said it would ring back. We then phoned the Department of Social Security for help because the mother had been without the payments for many months. It said it was making inquiries to the agency on several people's behalf, but getting nowhere.

On 5 April 1989 we received a call from the Child Support Agency. It informed us that it had contacted the father who said he had not received any letters from the support agency and because his letters had been addressed to a post office box number the courts would not proceed with a summons. The agency said it would reissue the letter to his home address but the father was going to take them to his solicitor for a variation because he was on sickness benefits. There was nothing the agency could do until the father went to court for a variation. In the meantime, the Department of Social Security informed my office that the mother was getting the full supporting benefit pension and was entitled to nothing else from them.

On 19 April we rang the outreach officer, who said he would investigate the case. On 26 May the Adelaide office rang and said it had arranged for the Sydney office to telephone us as a result of the outreach officer contacting them. On 2 June the Sydney director telephoned my office to tell me that it takes 28 days after catching up with a husband to serve a summons and that 30 per cent of cases were very difficult. Much of the difficulty is with Australia Post. The agency had to check that the post office box was the father's box and then get his address from Australia Post. This proved difficult until Australia Post was read the Child Support Act. There were also difficulties with the Privacy Act. He also said that because the mother was on social security benefits, she could not withdraw from the Child Support Agency. They realised how anxious the mother was but she was one of the 30 per cent who were difficult and costly to the agency. He informed my office that if the father did not pay up at the end of the summons and court action, the bailiff had the right to seize his property, including car, et cetera, and sell it to raise money.

On 10 July 1989 the agency telephoned and told my office that because of privacy provisions there was little it could disclose to us. It had started legal action. Whether the sheriff had served the action it did not know. It said it would be a long process but it would make every effort to recover moneys when his maintenance payment was registered with them. Because he was on sickness benefit the money could not be taken from his pay. It would have to seize some of his possessions which are not a necessity and then auction them to recover the money. That did not mean that the mother would receive all of the money owing. It was doing everything to recover the money but all cases were treated the same. Because of the Privacy Act there was little it could say. This could take months and the mother would have to be patient.

The mother was informed she could contact the Department of Social Security to see whether there were any payments coming for the future pay days, or could ring the Child Support Agency on the toll free number to inquire as to how her case was progressing. She would not be told much because of the Privacy Act. The mother was told, `Don't expect anything to happen in a short time'. On 10 September the mother phoned the toll free number. The agency told her that nothing, more or less, had been done and that she should go back to her Federal member as it was on the record that he had been inquiring. This has taken a year.

This case has cost my office, the Child Support Agency and the Department of Social Security countless dollars in lost time and effort, not to mention the frustration to my staff, and after one year the mother concerned and her child are no better off. I would be interested to know what other members are experiencing in relation to the operation of the Child Support Agency. If it is the same as my experience the whole child support legislation should be looked at to see whether it can be made to work. If it cannot it should be scrapped and let us start again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 and 5 September the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) rose in this House and posed a series of questions based on a transcript he acquired from Mrs Halfpenny in relation to her former husband, Mr John Halfpenny. The allegations contained in the questions posed by the honourable member were very serious. In answering those questions the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a very valid point in saying that all Australians should be given the right to be considered innocent of any charge, that they have to be proven guilty of those charges, and that all honourable members should bear that in mind before making allegations. I imagine that the Prime Minister was being a little hopeful in suggesting that allegations of these sorts should not be canvassed.

SPEECH.PARA: Later on that night of 5 September the honourable member for Parkes, during the adjournment debate, read into the Hansard a series of allegations which he claimed were made by Mrs Halfpenny in relation to her statement to the National Crime Authority. One of those allegations concerned a Mr Eddie Kornhauser, a resident of the Queensland Gold Coast. I will read from the Hansard what the honourable member said:

. . . she lists a remarkable series of events and pay offs given for reasons that we can only guess at. For example, in the 1970s she and her husband John lived for a period in Eddie Kornhauser's apartment in Spring Street, Melbourne, which she refers to as `an expensive apartment, taking up one whole floor'.

The clear allegation implicit in that statement is that Mr Kornhauser is in some way involved in improper, if not illegal, activities involving a pay-off concerning Mr Halfpenny. In response to that allegation raised in the House by the honourable member for Parkes, Mr Kornhauser's solicitors, Lyons of Brisbane, wrote to Mr Cobb pointing out that the statement had been made and also categorically stating that there was no truth whatsoever in that statement. I quote briefly from the letter from Mr Kornhauser's solicitor:

The statement which you attribute to Mrs. Halfpenny is not only completely false but demonstrably so. It is a matter of absolute fact that our client has never owned nor paid for an apartment in Melbourne. He has never provided Mr or Mrs Halfpenny with free accommodation and he certainly never `paid off' Mr Halfpenny.

With the greatest of respect, we would have thought that you would have accorded our client the courtesy of checking the basis of the allegations made by Mrs Halfpenny prior to making the statement referred to above in Parliament. The making of the statement and the clear imputation which arises therefrom that our client `paid off' Mr Halfpenny has occasioned serious and irreparable harm to our client.

Accordingly, we urge you to take the first available opportunity to inform Parliament of the true position as regards our client, that is, that he has never owned nor paid for an apartment in Spring Street, Melbourne or anywhere else in Melbourne, that he has never provided free accommodation to Mr or Mrs Halfpenny and that he never `paid off' Mr Halfpenny.

It was made perfectly clear to the honourable member that there was no substance at all in that allegation. In response to that letter, the honourable member wrote to the solicitors saying that he noted the objection taken by Mr Kornhauser and had no reason to doubt his claim. He had no doubt that what Mr Kornhauser says will be easily established through such mechanisms as the Australian Federal Police conducting land title searches, et cetera.

Mr Kornhauser then raised this matter with his local Federal member, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who apparently also raised it with the honourable member for Parkes. An undertaking was given that the honourable member for Parkes would come into the House and make it quite clear that the allegations were not true and that Mr Kornhauser denied them. The honourable member has had that opportunity today. He has spoken in the grievance debate. He has also spoken earlier tonight on the adjournment. He has made no attempt to set the record straight. It is all very well in the cut and thrust to make allegations, but surely it is only decent, when those allegations are explicitly denied and said to be demonstrably false, that the honourable member should have the decency to come into this House and set the record straight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard in the Parliament tonight a debate about the environment and concerns about hazardous chemicals and so on. I would like to spend a few moments addressing the so-called great environmental statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) only a month or so ago. It is very interesting to have a look at that statement and go through the fine print of what was said with regard to planting trees.

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody in this House would realise that in Australia there is a great need to have a lot more trees planted and that that would benefit this country in all sorts of ways. The statement was held up as a great and marvellous statement, and the goal was set for one billion trees to be planted in this country over a period of time. But when one has a look at the details of what was said, it is a complete con trick by the Government to say that this goal is a real goal. In reality, when one goes through the statement what one finds is that more than half, or 600 million of the one billion trees, are actually going to be natural seeding. The Government has made up an estimate and really tried to con the Australian public into believing that it is genuinely going to do something about the environment by planting trees, no doubt to help the greenhouse effect and to make a more beautiful environment for families to move around in. It is a great tragedy for a government and a Prime Minister, particularly at this stage of the environmental debate in Australia, to let Australians believe that it is going to do something about the environment when, in reality, it is going to do very little in this area.

Not only are 600 million of these one billion trees going to be natural seeding, but 150 million are already being planted by the forestry departments in Australia at the moment. If this project had never been brought forward to the Australian people, there would have been 150 million trees planted by the various State governments. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, being a member from Western Australia, at the State election it was said that 100 million trees were going to be planted by the Western Australian Government. So the one billion also includes the 150 million that the forestry departments were going to plant and the 100 million that the Western Australian Government already had in the pipeline. So it leaves us with a planting of 150 million trees.

So the real goal of one billion trees, that was given to us by the Prime Minister in effect may be even less. When one reads the statement one finds that the one billion trees was only a target anyway. It is a great tragedy that we are having the wool pulled over our eyes as a nation by the Government's statement that it is doing something in this area. In reality, there is very little substance in that part of the Government's statement. When there has been such a high profile debate on the environment and the need for more trees to be planted on our continent, it is a disgrace for the Government to mislead the country in such a way. It does not ring true at all, but it is typical of this Government that there is a lot of rhetoric and very little action. It gives the impression that we are going to green Australia over the next 10 years or so, but in reality very little is being done by the Government in regard to the environment. It is an absolute tragedy. It is a time to act in Australia, but this Government is not doing it genuinely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to join in this debate this evening, but I was prompted to do so after listening to the comments by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb). I did not hear his remarks in the grievance debate earlier today, but I did hear his comments this evening. I do not know why the honourable member for Parkes is such an apologist for the South African regime, or for whatever the South African right wing puts out. It seems that the honourable member accepts what is said at face value and without question and then comes into this House and repeats it. I am very surprised at this because I have a certain amount of respect for the honourable member for Parkes. In his own way, he is quite an intelligent member of this chamber. If he is so intelligent, I do not know why he always accepts what others say and then comes in and repeats it in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: He was very critical of the South West Africa People's Organisation (SWAPO). Whether he likes it or not, SWAPO is recognised by most world authorities as the legitimate representative of the people of Namibia. He has a tendency to make claims such as the ones he made this evening. He listed a number of brutalities and so forth which he claimed SWAPO was responsible for. He comes in here and makes these claims without documentation or he quotes some obscure newspaper article or journalist as his reference. That is simply not good enough. If he is going to make these claims, why does he not take as documented evidence one of the recognised world authorities such as the United Nations (UN), the Red Cross or some of the international human rights organisations instead of one journalist writing in some obscure publication.

This Government is not uncritical of everything that happens in southern Africa. The Government has criticised and commented upon matters of human rights that do not accord with this Government's view. We do support SWAPO. We do support fair and free elections in Namibia. If the honourable member for Parkes wants to be even-handed about this, it is a pity he did not speak out some time ago about the denial of human rights in Namibia under the previous regime. He would have a lot more credibility if he came in here and was a lot more even-handed about the denial of human rights. I do not think I have ever heard him speak in this chamber about the denial of human rights in South Africa. I have not heard him talk about the detentions without trial there. I have not heard him talk about the whips used on protesters, the dogs that have been let loose, the electric shocks that have been used on people in South Africa. As I said before, his speeches in this chamber would have a lot more credibility if he were more even-handed in his criticism.

The question must be asked: Why does the honourable member for Parkes always think he is correct? He comes in here and makes these statements. In his opinion, he is always correct, but he is often a minority of one. He is a minority against world opinion, the opinion of the UN, and the opinion of the people and government of Australia.

I support the assistance that the Australian Government has given to the frontline states. Under SWAPO, Namibia will become a free and independent society. South Africa and its apologists will continue to put out their scare stories. It is a great pity that a member of this Parliament will stand up here and put these stories to the Parliament as if they were gospel when, in fact, they are just propaganda for the South African regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the adjournment debate tonight we have seen cowardly and vicious attacks by two members of the Government on a member of the Opposition without--
—I would be very careful in proceeding along those lines. You may not reflect on members in that way.

—I take the greatest offence at the content, firstly, of the contributions from the two members of the Government and, secondly, their total breach of the convention of this place, their failure to warn the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) that they would make this vicious attack on his integrity. It is absolute cowardness on the part of the two members not to warn the honourable member for Parkes that this attack would take place.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw the term `cowardness'.
—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until Tuesday, 24 October 1989, at 2 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.
